abstract: Rebel Rams; The Stoppage in; Rebel Rains Stopped by Government
snippet: Rebel Rams; The Stoppage in; Rebel Rains Stopped by Government
lead_paragraph: The French Minister of State announced explicitly, in the last debate on the Mexican question, that orders had been given by the Government to detain the so-called Confederate ships, now building in the French ports, till their neutral character was clearly established. This announcement will give special satisfaction this side of the water. It is well understood that those vessels, four in number, were near completion, and were of a very formidable character. Were they to go forth on the business for which they were designed; the havoc they would do would be great; falling short of that which has been committed by the Anglo-rebel cruisers, only because the field has been thinned.

abstract: Judges of the Superior Court, Judges of the Court of Common Pleas and the Supervisors met yesterday in the chambers of the Board of Supervisors, Chief Justice ROBERTSON presiding, and proceeded to appoint a Commissioner in the manner provided by law. abstract: Command arrived at Vicksburgh
snippet: Command arrived at Vicksburgh
lead_paragraph: -- A telegram from Cairo, which we gave yesterday, announced that "nineteen boats had arrived at Vicksburgh; with Gen. A.J. SMITH'S command." This is the force which some three months since moved from Vicksburgh down the Mississippi, entered the Red River, convoyed by Admiral PORTER's gunboats, captured Fort De Russey, moved up as far as Natchitoches, joined the Banks expedition, took part in the Grand Ecore campaign, and by a timely and splendid blow saved the army of Gen. BANKS from a total route. It then steamed down the Red River as far as Alexandria, and from thence has gone to its confluence and up the Mississippi to its original point of departure at Vicksburgh.

abstract: The news from Gen. GRANT is up to yesterday morning at 6 o'clock. On Monday evening a  partial engagement occurred, brought on by the rebels making an attack on WARREN, who held our left, in which the enemy were driven back with severe loss, leaving their killed and wounded in our hands.
lead_paragraph: The news from Gen. GRANT is up to yesterday morning at 6 o'clock. On Monday evening a partial engagement occurred, brought on by the rebels making an attack on WARREN, who held our left, in which the enemy were driven back with severe loss, leaving their killed and wounded in our hands. While this engagement was going on a general attack was ordered; but the hour was so late, that only HANCOCK's Corps became engaged sharply, the fighting lasting until after dark. The results were very encouraging. Our troops charged and carried a rebel line of temporary works, and held their ground at the close of the action. Our loss was not fully ascertained, although Gen. GRANT says it was not large. Yesterday morning there seemed to be an effort on LEE's part to get behind the Chickahominy, on which is situated his first line of works. Gen. SMITH's forces undoubtedly formed a junction with Gen. GRANT yesterday. The location of the fight of Monday was on To-to-pat-a-moy Creek, within seven miles of Richmond. Our cavalry were operating, on the flanks, Gen. WILSON's division having been ordered to thoroughly destroy the bridges on the Fredericksburgh and the Virginia Central Railroad.

abstract: The Army of the Potomac has now reached the region of its movements under McCLELLAN two years ago. Wherein is its chance of capturing Richmond better now than it was then? We don't suppose that there is any great difference in the relative strength of the national and the rebel armies, in presence, at the two periods. Both armies are larger now, but probably with about the same ...
lead_paragraph: The Army of the Potomac has now reached the region of its movements under McCLELLAN two years ago. Wherein is its chance of capturing Richmond better now than it was then? We don't suppose that there is any great difference in the relative strength of the national and the rebel armies, in presence, at the two periods. Both armies are larger now, but probably with about the same preponderance in our favor. If the location of the armies is not materially different, nor their relative magnitude, why have we now so much better grounds for confidence?

abstract: Evening Post, where it was said to come from good authority, that Gen. BUTLER disregarded the urgent advice of Gen. GILLMORE to intrench himself, and that he suffered a serious repulse in consequence of this neglect. It is but justice to Gen. BUTLER to say that this statement proves to have been incorrect. A note from Gen. GILLMORE on the subject denies that he gave Gen. BUTLER any such advice, or that Gen. BUTLER's lack of success was due to any such reason.

abstract: In the Senate yesterday the credentials of Mr. BAXTER, Senator elect from Arkansas, were presented and laid upon the table. Mr. DAVIS submitted a resolution that the Senate appoint a Committee to investigate all charges of fraud and corruption and of sympathy with the rebels, which have been made in various ways, by various parties, against Maj.-Gen. BUTLER. The Revenue Bill was brought up, and a number of amendments relative to lucifer matches, small photographs, spirits and auctioneers' licenses, were adopted. An attempt was made to reduce the tax on oil made from coal, and to strike out the duty on coal from which oil is distilled, but it failed. In the evening session the consideration of the Revenue Bill was continued.

abstract: The Nomination of Gen. Fremont; Nominated for Vice President by Cleveland Convention; Nominated for President by Cleveland Convention
snippet: The Nomination of Gen. Fremont; Nominated for Vice President by Cleveland Convention; Nominated for President by Cleveland Convention
lead_paragraph: Radical Convention, yesterday, nominated for President Maj.-Gen. JOHN C. FREMONT, and for Vice-President, Maj.-Gen. JOHN COCHRANE. The platform declared for the Union, the Constitution and the laws, the suppression of the rebellion without compromise, the rights of free speech, free press and habeas corpus, the Constitutional prohibition of Slavery -- for integrity and economy, for confiscation, the right of asylum, the Monroe doctrine, the one-term policy, and so on. A committee of five was appointed to report a plan of party organization and a name for the party.

abstract: Butler, Col. A. J., Will of
snippet: Butler, Col. A. J., Will of
lead_paragraph: In re The Will of Andrew Jackson Butler. -- The citations in this matter were returnable to-day, but, in consequence of informality in the petition, (which was sworn to by the Executor, Maj.-Gen. Benj. F. Butler, at Fortress Monroe, before a Virginia judge,) the Surrogate postponed the probate till it should be properly verified. The deceased was brother to Gen. Butler, and accompanied him to New-Orleans when that city was captured. On his return North, some months since, Col. Butler was taken ill in this City with Southern fever, and died quite suddenly at one of our hotels, leaving the present will. By it one-half of his property is left to his brother, Gen. B.F. BUTLER, who is also named as executor, one quarter to the widow of deceased, who is resident in California, and one-quarter to be held in trust by Gen. BUTLER, till the son of deceased shall attain his 30th year. The property is said to be all personal, invested in Government securities. Gen. BUTLER states on oath that it amounts to only $200,000, which refutes the stories that have appeared in some of the newspapers, fixing it at two millions. This valuation is important, and may be the subject of investigation, as the Executor being a non-resident, must give security in double the amount, on taking out letters testamentary, and it becomes the duty of the Surrogate to inquire into the value.

abstract: Postal Money Order System
snippet: Postal Money Order System
lead_paragraph: -- The introduction of the money-order system, which has now the sanction of law, will be found to add no ordinary amount of labor to the Post-office Department, and especially to the large branch offices throughout the country. Although the transactions will not include what is properly exchange business -- the highest permissible order being limited to $30 -- yet the security of the mode of transmission, the perfect arrangements that can be made for sending remittances along the whole vast range of territory embraced in the operations of the Post-office, the speed with which mail matter is carried from the most distant opposite points, and above all, the reasonable rate of the charges for the service rendered -- assure us of the early growth of a vast business which will tax the utmost skill, ingenuity and energy of the officers of the department to set it in proper working order, at the beginning, and maintain it permanently in the same condition. For ten cents an order, in value from one to ten dollars, may be sent from New-York to San Francisco; for fifteen cents an order of ten to twenty dollars; and an order for thirty dollars may be had for twenty cents. The economy of the arrangement alone will thus bring to the department a number of customers which to those who may not have watched the progress of the system in Great Britain would appear incredible. And, in this view, we hear with satisfaction, that the Postmaster-General has determined to take ample time for perfecting the new machinery which will be found requisite before he authorizes the issue of a single order. There is no necessity whatever to rush into the business in slap-dash fashion. It demands thought, care, business tact, and the contributed experience of those who have worked the machinery elsewhere. And these are prerequisites which include most especially the element of time.
headline: {'main': 'THE MONEY-ORDER SYSTEM.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'THE MONEY-ORDER SYSTEM.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The private opening, Tuesday evening, of the Bankers', Brokers' and Merchants' Club House, No. 164 Fifth-avenue, was largely attended. Yesterday the spacious rooms of the establishment were thrown open to the public and during the day hundreds paid a visit to the "palatial mansion." The instititution is an entire new thing in the way of cluns. The cost of the establishment is stated at $100,000, and the annual dues of subscribers are fixed at $100, payable in advance. A circular issued by the club "claims for its patrons the sterling and representative men of New-York." The club is to be supplied with [???] of the standard journals of world and a bulletin is to keep the members posted "throughout the day and evening with the exact state of the markets."

abstract: On Monday, pursuant to an order which we published, the Seventy-first Regiment, American Guard, 800 strong, proceeded to East New-York for field exercises. The day was beautiful and the gallant boys seemed to combine pleasure with their duty, and enjoy themselves hugely. The regiment marched through Grand-street headed by their excellent band, (Dodworth's,) to the ferry. At Williamsburgh, crowds gathered at the ferry and along the streets, cheering the boys on their march. Transportation was here furnished them to East New-York. The ground selected by the Colonel was the same as used by the regiment on former occasions. Line was formed at 12 o'clock, and then dismissed for "rations." At 1 o'clock the drill and field exercises commenced, and continued until 6, concluding with a full dress parade. The band furnishing some choice music, which was received, as was the different movements of the regiment, with plaudits of praise by the large concourse of people, among which were many ladies who had gathered to witness the military skill of the gallant Sexenty first. The regiment returned to the City about 8 o'clock, well tired and several shades darker than when they started.

abstract: Nuisances--Public Health
snippet: Nuisances--Public Health
lead_paragraph: -- The Committee of the Board of Aldermen on Public Health have made their report on the more flagrant and dangerous nuisances brought under their notice in a late communication from the City Inspector. The committee have had under close and personal examination various fat-boiling establishments, beside a number of offal and hide-houses. They have also made something equivalent to a chemical analysis of various municipal malodors not heretofore catalogued, we believe, in the Health Department. And the investigation has brought the committe to the conclusion that the fat and offal-houses -- especially some of those on the north and west side of the City -- are noisome, offensive and intolerable to the utmost degree, generating disease in various malignant forms, rendering many dwellings in their neighborhood uninhabitable, and thus retarding the prosperity of the City, while imperilling the lives of the people. The committee have found, that there is the amplest power vested by the Legislature in the Board of Health, to effect a removal of the nuisances thus described, and they ask the Mayor to bring that body together to hear the committee's evidence, and take prompt and decisive action thereupon.

abstract: Bailey, Lieut.-Col., Promotion of
snippet: Bailey, Lieut.-Col., Promotion of
lead_paragraph: -- We are glad that Congress proposes promptly to recognize the services of the Wisconsin lumberman, Lieut.-Col. BAILEY, who constructed the dam on the Red River that was the means of saving Admiral PORTER's fleet. Admiral PORTER's report, describing BAILEY's labors and success, only reached the Government at the close of last week, and was published in the TIMES of Saturday -- on which day BAILEY was nominated for appointment as Brigadier-General, and yesterday action was taken in the Senate upon a joint resolution tendering him the thanks of Congress and awarding him a gold medal. This is proper action in such a case and in such cases.

abstract: CLOSING SERVICES AT  ST. TERESA'S ROMAN CATHOLIC CHURCH. The Roman Catholic world has specially dedicated the month of May for the purpose of honoring the Virgin Mother of God. During this month services are daily held in all the churches, at which the faithful who desire to honor the Blessed Virgin attend.
lead_paragraph: CLOSING SERVICES AT ST. TERESA's ROMAN CATHOLIC CHURCH. -- The Roman Catholic world has specially dedicated the month of May for the purpose of honoring the Virgin Mother of God. During this month services are daily held in all the churches, at which the faithful who desire to honor the Blessed Virgin attend. Tuesday being the 31st, was the last day on which these services are conducted. At St Teresa's Church, corner of Rutgers and Henry streets, the closing services were particularly interesting and impressive. This splendid church, but yet it might be said in its infancy, was thronged with a large and highly respectable congregation. Some one hundred female children, dressed entirely in white, emblematic of the purity of the Virgin Mother, walked in procession, chanting her litany and invoking her protection. One of the band, a handsome little child, offered aloud an eloquent prayer to the Mother of God, in which the congregation fervently joined. Those children then marched around the church, carrying a banner at their head, on which were inscribed the words: "Children of Mary." On the reverse side of this banner was a likeness of the Blessed Virgin, and underneath the words: "Ave Maria." Rev. Father BRIADY, assistant pastor of the church, made some eloquent and appropriate remarks upon the occasion. After solemn benediction the ceremonies closed. On next Tuesday the excursion of this church comes off at Jones Wood, Rev. Father Boyce is pastor.

abstract: Grant and Butler, the operations of
snippet: Grant and Butler, the operations of
lead_paragraph: -- On Monday afternoon the rebels assaulted our left, but were repulsed. At 12 o'clock midnight, they threw a heavy force upon our right, with intent to surprise it, but were again repulsed. On that same night, GRANT determined to advance our whole line as far as HANCOCK's front, and at daylight on Tuesday the movement began, accompanied by some resistance from the enemy. On Tuesday morning LEE's position was still on the north bank of the Chickahominy, holding a naturally strong line, which had been artificially strengthened during the last few days. Our correspondent telegraphs that GRANT on Tuesday began to threaten LEE's right, but the latter showed no signs of giving up his position, and was apparently even ready to assume the offensive.

abstract: At the meeting of the Board of Aldermen, yesterday, a preamble and resolutions by Mr. RYERS were adopted, disputing the legality of the order of the Legislature for a street-cleaning contract...
lead_paragraph: At the meeting of the Board of Aldermen, yesterday, a preamble and resolutions by Mr. RYERS were adopted, disputing the legality of the order of the Legislature for a street-cleaning contract to be made without receiving the sanction of the Common Council, and directing the City Inspector to advertise for proposals for a five-year contract to clean the streets, and to obtain the aid of the Corporation Counsel in drafting specifications; all of which would seem to mean that the Common Council will endeavor to establish that no contract involving the faith of the City can be made without their help. In passing the street-cleaning appropriation, ($300,000,) the words "by contract," in the Tax Law, were carefully excluded. In answer to a resolution of inquiry, the Street Commissioner sent in a letter giving the history of the Battery Enlargement contract. It was referred to the Committee on Wharves, Piers and Slips. The same information was furnished to the Board of Councilmen of 1863, but nothing resulted from it. The drafted ordinance previously submitted by the City Inspector, and designed to sustain him in carrying out his order requiring all butchers to remove their offal from the City regularly every day, during certain hours, was taken up and adopted. A resolution was adopted to permit the company who put down iron pavement in Nassau-street, several years ago, as an experiment, to remove it and restore the kind of pavement which theirs displaced. Adjourned to 2 o'clock P.M., on Monday.

abstract: The, and its Doings
snippet: The, and its Doings
lead_paragraph: Well, the motley set who went to the Lake shore to pitch nets to catch the wind, have pitched their nets. The platform and the ticket are up, and the witless fellows are gaping now to see the popular applause come rushing in. You would judge by their eagerness that the fate of the nation is dependiug upon it. They don't seem to have the least suspicion what a precious piece of foolery it all is.

abstract: -The annual meeting of the stockholders of the New Jersey Railroad and Transportation Company was held yesterday at the depot, in Jersey City, and was quite largely attended. The following is an abstract from their annual report: The receipts for the year ending Dec. 31, 1863, was $1,286,600 12; total expenses, $591,685 74. Increased receipt over the year 1862, $175,513 37, and increase in the expenses $132,723 31 The cost per mile run for 1862, was 89 58-100ths cents, while for 1863 it was 104 18-100ths cents. Amount of Government tax paid was $40,020 13. The stockholders were reflected.
lead_paragraph: -The annual meeting of the stockholders of the New Jersey Railroad and Transportation Company was held yesterday at the depot, in Jersey City, and was quite largely attended. abstract: By the Montreal Company's steamship Nova Scolian, which passed Father Point on her way to Quebec, and by the Australasian, which arrived at this port yesterday afternoon, we have four...
lead_paragraph: By the Montreal Company's steamship Nova Scolian, which passed Father Point on her way to Quebec, and by the Australasian, which arrived at this port yesterday afternoon, we have four days later European news; the Australasian's being to the 22d of May, via Queenstown. The prospectus of a company for establishing floating telegraph and light-ships at such points as Cape Race, has been issued in London, with a capital of £250,000 sterling. The Prince of Walos appeared as a public speaker for the first time at the Annual Banquet of the Royal Literary Fund. He is highly complimented by all sections of the press for the grace and tact with which he discharged the duties of Chairman. The privateer Georgia has been advertised for sale, with all her equipments and stores. The House of Commons reassembled after the Whitsuntide holidays on the 19th of May, and Lord PALMERSTON again appeared in his place on the 20th. On that day he had to meet an attack on the Government policy in China, by one of his own followers -- defending the policy of intervention. Mr. LAYARD announced in the House that the Government had official intelligence of the exodus of a large body of the Circassian people from Russia, and their appeal to the British Government for protection. The prospects as to the issue of the conference become every day gloomier, and it is said the French Government regard this state of things with satisfaction. Austria and Prussia demand the complete autonomy of the Duchies, their personal union with Denmark, material guarantees, and indeed almost the programme entire of the German Diet. The Swedish Minister in London complains that his private dispatches have been tampered with in passing through Germany. The Allied invaders are openly charged with virtually violating the terms of the armistice in their warlike preparations, and the exactions which continue to be made by the Prussian authorities on the inhabitants of Jutland. Measures are in progress at Berlin for the construction of a Schleswig-Holstein canal, to connect the North Sea with the Baltic. The Opinione, of Turin, of the 16th of May, says in regard to the Pope's illness, that it has increased to so alarming an extent that a secret bull has been issued, ordering a conclave composed only of the Cardinals present in Rome for the election of a successor to PIUS IX., before his death is announced to the public.

abstract: Piracy; Rappahannock; Rumball's Indictment
snippet: Piracy; Rappahannock; Rumball's Indictment
lead_paragraph: Mr. WILLIAM RUMBALL has been indicted by an English Grand Jury for enlisting seamen for the rebels, to serve on board the Rappahannock. It is gratifying to see such a step taken, for it indicates that the English Government is in earnest in trying to put a stop to these efforts of the rebels to fit out fleets from English ports. Seizing the vessels was a step in that direction. Indicting the men engaged in the business is a more decided one, and when one or two of them have been convicted the business will be probably stopped, if, indeed, it is not stopped long before that by the result of the grand trial now going on in Virginia.

abstract: At the present writing, the latest news we have from Gen. GRANT is furnished by our special correspondent, and is up to 10 o'clock Tuesday morning.
lead_paragraph: At the present writing, the latest news we have from Gen. GRANT is furnished by our special correspondent, and is up to 10 o'clock Tuesday morning. The details of the important operations of Monday evening and Tuesday morning are given in full. The rebel attempt on our left, it seems was completely foiled, while HANCOCK's movement on the rebel left, was successful in the extreme. During the night the rebels made an attempt to surprise HANCOCK and regain the position lost, but they were again severely repulsed with a loss of several hundred prisoners. During Tuesday morning our whole line was advanced so as to correspond with HANCOCK'S position, which occasioned considerable skirmishing, but no general engagement occurred. LEE occupies a good position north of the Chickahominy, and it is believed that most of BEAUREGARD's forces have joined him. Our cavalry administered a very severe punishment to the rebels on Sunday. The rebels admit a loss of one thousand men, and that they were badly beaten.

abstract: Brazil Mail Steamship Subsidy Bill
snippet: Brazil Mail Steamship Subsidy Bill
lead_paragraph: -- The final pas sage and approval by the President of the Brazil Steamship Subsidy Bill must be considered of practical interest chiefly as being the first step toward a revival of the system of subsidies generally for important ocean mail lines. The proposed Rio line has yet to secure the cooperative support of Brazil, with the contingent subsidy of $150,000, corresponding to the sum voted by Congress. Separate contracts will have to be made with the two Governments for the monthly service intended, and time will be required to negotiate the terms of the joint enterprise, so as to insure mutual benefit and mutual satisfaction in carrying it on. The Postmaster-General will have the entire charge and responsibility of framing the contract and determining the efficiency of its fulfillment. This will simplify the initiatory labor of the project, as well as give better assurance for its proper subsequent working than under the old system, which prevailed both in England and here, of dividing the labor and the responsibility between several departments -- the Treasury, the Naval Department and the Post-office, all having been allowed a voice in the arrangements.

abstract: the Retreater
snippet: the Retreater
lead_paragraph: BRAGG was celebrated for two years as an unparalleled retreater. "Another retreat of BRAGG," used to be a standing bulletin. But his successor, Jo. JOHNSTON, bids fair to surpass him in this characteristic. With the opening days of May, JOHNSTON began to retreat, and ever since then he has been steadily retreating from one position to another, from one mountain fastness to another, and from one river to another. BRAGG had the advantage of him in one respect -- he had a greater surface over which to retreat than is now left to JOHNSTON. BRAGG swept across two States in his southward retreats. JOHNSTON has already rushed across only half a State, but when he gets over the other half he will be down at the Atlantic Ocean.

abstract: The Mayor, Comptroller and City Inspector, as the commission to contract for the cleaning of the streets, for a term of five years, according to a special provision of the City Tax Law for 1864,  met at the office of the City Inspector yesterday, to open the proposals which had been invited for...
lead_paragraph: The Mayor, Comptroller and City Inspector, as the commission to contract for the cleaning of the streets, for a term of five years, according to a special provision of the City Tax Law for 1864, met at the office of the City Inspector yesterday, to open the proposals which had been invited for the contract. There were only two bids; one by PATRICK COYLE, of Brooklyn, at the price of $575,000 per year, and another by DANIEL D. BADGER, residing in East Fourteenth-street, at the price of $500,000 per year. Both proposals were "ruled out," being unacceptable, from the fact that the Commissioners are limited by law, to an expenditure of $300,000 per year for the work. After the opening the commission adjourned to meet at an early day next week. The Common Council have taken steps to make a contract, a resolution for the purpose having passed the Board of Aldermen on Wednesday, and will come before the Board of Councilmen next Monday. The Mayor states that parties desiring to compete for the contract, have objected to the specifications adopted by the commission, in that they leave the kind of boats to be used in removing filth from the City to the judgment of the City Inspector, do not give the contractor the street manure, nor provide dumping grounds, and by limiting the sureties to two parties, make it difficult to obtain security for so large a sum as $700,000.

lead_paragraph: The Cleveland Convention was simply a flank movement against the Administration. Hostility to ABRAHAM LINCOLN was its mainspring and motive-power. It was a congregation of malcontents -- of men who had griefs, and who sought revenge. Nothing more is needed to establish this fact than a glance at the names of those few among the delegates who were ever heard of before.

abstract: Harper's New Monthly for June, appeared somewhat in advance of its usual date, for the important purpose of securing the priority of publication of Mr. DICKENS' new story, "Our...
lead_paragraph: -- Harper's New Monthly for June, appeared somewhat in advance of its usual date, for the important purpose of securing the priority of publication of Mr. DICKENS' new story, "Our. Mutual Friend." As this has already been read, at a moderate computation, by every other man woman and child in the country -- excepting, of course, the few cold-blooded individuals occasionally met with who tell you they prefer to wait till a story is "all out" -- it is unnecessary to discuss its merits very elaborately. The first chapter -- a scene on the River Thames, where the unhallowed trade of the characters introduced, is rather indicated than described -- is a masterpiece. Afterward there is a sad fall "up stairs" into fashionable society, where failure is the result of the most elaborate painstaking, and every reader will fervently hope he may hear as little as possible of "The Veneerings." The writer feels his ground again on the lower strata of middle class life when among the "R. Wilfer Family," and the general impression left by the first installment is that many pleasant things are in store for the future, with indications of a more complicated plot than DICKENS has hitherto succeeded in successfully managing. "Wine-Making in California" and a "Chapter on the Coolie Trade," are the illustrated articles, the former chiefly founded on Mr. HARAZTHY's book. "Why I Wrote It," has an air of truth and nature about it that will engage general sympathy. "Your Humble Servant" comments philosophically and descriptively on the great plague of America, the unsatisfactory condition of domestic service. The usual variety of fiction, fun and poetry is found in the remainder of the number.

abstract: Col. CHARLES CARPENTER arrived in this city late on Friday night, in the sleamer St. Mary, from Brazos-Santiago. Col. CARPENTER contradicts the reported fight between the Mexicans and French at San Luis Potosi, but says that the troops under the...
lead_paragraph: Col. CHARLES CARPENTER arrived in this city late on Friday night, in the sleamer St. Mary, from Brazos-Santiago. Col. CARPENTER contradicts the reported fight between the Mexicans and French at San Luis Potosi, but says that the troops under the Mexican Minister of War, Gun. NAIGRETTE, and Gen. DOBLADO, were endeavoring to reach that point to cooperate with another column approaching from the west, and that a battle at an early day may be expected. The recent successes of the Mexicans had given them confidence, while the failure of the French to keep their engagements with the clergy has embittered that powerful class against them. He represents the Mexican army as being in a higher state of discipline and morals than at any previous time. The Mexicans have fortified Matamoras in anticipation of an attack by a French force from Tampico. The feeling is very bitter against MAXIMILIAN, and Col. CARPENTER is of opinion that attempts will be made to assassinate him. The street rencontre the account of which we published a few days ago, was caused by an effort to assassinate CORTINAS by two Frenchmen who had come from Tampico for that purpose.

abstract: -The seventh number of this very excellent publication surpasses all its predecessors in present interest. It contains a fac-simile of Col. DAHLGREN's instructions to the troops engaged in the recent raid upon Richmond, the capital of the Southern Confederacy. Col. DAHLGREN was the son of Admiral DAHLGREN, the well-known artillerist, and was selected to lead a bold attempt at a surprise of Richmond by Federal cavalry. The attempt failed; the greater part of the Federal force was killed or destroyed. DAHLGREN himself was shot in an encounter with some of the Richmond Home Guards. On his person was found a copy of his instructions to his men, and of an address, issued at the moment of starling, in his own handwriting. These instructions betray a deliberate intention to burn and sack Richmond, and to kill President DAVIS and his Cabinet. They were immediately published by the Confederate Government in order to show the true spirit in which the Federals are carrying on the war. But the Northern press, while admitting the instructions to be generally correct, asserted that the special directions as to the murder of JEFF. DAVIS and his Cabinet were interpolations and forgeries of the Confederates. To meet this charge the authorities at Richmond had an exact fac-simile taken of the original instructions. This fac-simile has been carefully lithographed for the Autographic Mirror; and it needs no expert to determine at a glance that every line and letter is in Col. DAHLGREN's own handwriting. This document alone gives a great historical interest to the present number. -- London Herald, May 20.

abstract: This noted female scout and spy, whose services in the Department of the Cumberland have won for her the notice of our authorities, and the loyal masses of the country, is still a great attraction at the Astor House, where she was, yesterday, visited by many citizens of prominence. In the morning an officer, recently returned from Virginia, called to show her a number of trophies taken from the rebels, consisting of battle-flags, signals, regimental standards, &c. A handsome carbine captured from a rebel officer at Antletam, was presented to Miss CUSHMAN by her visitor. In the afternoon, she rode through Central Park in dashing style, surrounded by a group of military friends, attracting general attention and exhibiting her graceful horsemanship.

abstract: Grant's Advance--The Cold Harbor Battle
snippet: Grant's Advance--The Cold Harbor Battle
lead_paragraph: The Chickahominy is an insignificant and easily passable stream, except when the adjacent bottom lands are rendered swampy by rains. The fact that LEE is fighting with his back to the Chickahominy, would seem to indicate that the stream is now easily passable, and that GRANT will not, when he reaches it, have to contend with the physical difficulties which delayed and ultimately paralyzed MCCLELLAN's advance. LEE evidently has thus an easy retreat behind him -- otherwise he would not now be fighting at Cold Harbor.

abstract: -- After Atlanta people are asking, what next? It will be easier to answer this query when we have Atlanta. But we suppose that after we take it, we shall establish there a secondary base and depot, such as we formerly established at Nashville and at Chattanooga -- after which we shall pass onward. The next step may be in the direction of Montgomery on the Alabama River, or Augusta on the Savannah, with the view of establishing by one of these routes communication with the seaboard. It will be necessary then to crack Charleston or Mobile. We shall crack them both.
lead_paragraph: -- After Atlanta people are asking, what next? It will be easier to answer this query when we have Atlanta. But we suppose that after we take it, we shall establish there a secondary base and depot, such as we formerly established at Nashville and at Chattanooga -- after which we shall pass onward. The next step may be in the direction of Montgomery on the Alabama River, or Augusta on the Savannah, with the view of establishing by one of these routes communication with the seaboard. It will be necessary then to crack Charleston or Mobile. We shall crack them both.

abstract: -A shocking accident occurred on the Morris and Essex Railroad, near Valley Station, Orange, this morning, resulting in the instant death of a boy named WILLIE MCCLUTE, son of PETER MCCLUTE of Orange, and probably a fatal injury to another boy, the son of ENOS CONTER, of the same place. The two boys were in a wagon, belonging to DAVID BELL, and while crossing the railroad track near the station were run into by the 6:45 o'clock train from Newark. The train was running at the usual rate of speed. It is supposed that the boys did not see it until it was close upon them, or until it was too late to avoid the collision. The wagon was entirely demolished and the boys thrown violently to the ground, killing one of them instantly and injuring the other so that his life is despaired of. One of the horses was also killed outright. The county physician has been notified; and an inquest will be held. -- Newark Advertiser, June 1.

abstract: The news from Gen. GRANT is up to 7 o'clock yesterday (Thursday) morning. On Wednesday evening, at 5 o'clock, an attack on the rebel position at Cold Harbor, was ordered by WRIGHT'S corps, supported by Gen. SMITH'S Eighteenth
lead_paragraph: The news from Gen. GRANT is up to 7 o'clock yesterday (Thursday) morning. On Wednesday evening, at 5 o'clock, an attack on the rebel position at Cold Harbor, was ordered by WRIGHT'S corps, supported by Gen. SMITH'S Eighteenth Corps, while HANCOCK, BURNSIDE and WARREN were held in readiness to advance their fronts. The engagement lasted three hours, and Gen. WRIGHT's corps succeeded in taking the enemy's works, and holding them in spite of all the enemy could do to drive our men out. Gen. SMITH also took a line in his front, but as they were commanded from the rear, they were not tenable. During the night several assaults, on our line were made by the rebels, but each time they were repulsed with loss. During the day previous, (Tuesday,) SHERIDAN's cavalry had a severe fight with the rebel cavalry and CLINGMAN's brigade of infantry, in which the latter were driven back with severe punishment.

abstract: Firing Too High
snippet: Firing Too High
lead_paragraph: In a Southern newspaper we find an account of the late fight near Calhoun, in Georgia, written by a rebel correspondent on the field; and in a Western paper we find an account of a subsequent fight a few miles south of Calhoun, near Rome, written by a Union correspondent on the field -- in both of which accounts there is a curious analogy of statement concerning the inefficiency of infantry fire from a cause which has often been pointed out. The rebel writer gives a highly colored account of a fight in which the "Minie balls of the Yankees poured over the rebel line in an unceasing stream," and adds: "But one thing saved us from a fearful loss of life, and it was that the Yankees fired entirely too high." The Union writer, after giving an account of the very desperate fight at Rome Cross-roads, says: "It was a matter of wonder, after the engagement, to ascertain that the loss in action did not exceed seventy-five. It could only be accounted for by the fact that the rebels fired too high, their balls striking always above our heads." Our soldiers in the field should be continually reminded of these facts.

abstract: From the quiet and unobtrusive way in which they do their work, few persons, perhaps, know that there exists in our midst a body of ladies calling themselves the "Association of Army Nurses," and having their quarters at Clinton Hall, Astor-place. Their object is to send women nurses to the field and general hospitals, and, so far, they have been very successful, the last party sent down by the association -- all educated nurses --being now at the White House. The class of nurses have tri-weekly lectures, free, by well-known surgeons, at the rooms of the Geographical Society, No. 5 Clinton Hall, to which lectures all persons are invited who feel an interest. To-night the lecture will be by Prof. RAPHAEL, on "Gunshot Wounds," while on Friday next Prof. HOLCOMB will teach on "The Eye."

abstract: The great purse and stake play or pay trot between Dexter, Shark, Lady Shannon, Empress and Hambletonian, which was to have come off yesterday, was, owing to the inclement state of the weather, postponed by mutual consent until to-day. This trot is exciting an unusual amount of interest, and large sums of money are pending on the result. There was a considerable attendance of the leading pillars of the trotting turf at the track yesterday, and from conversational indications we are induced to believe that several heavy matches are in embryo. Among others we should not be surprised if one was made between Lady Emma, the gallant victress of the trot at Union Course on Wednesday, and John Morgan, for a heavy stake. If the day is fair, there will be an immense attendance at the Fashion to-day.

abstract: Sidewalks, Stores on, Mr. Kinney's Authority Vetoed
snippet: Sidewalks, Stores on, Mr. Kinney's Authority Vetoed
lead_paragraph: -- A WALL-STREET APPLE MERCHANT SNUBBED. -- The Common Council having passed a resolution authorizing a Wall-street merchant, named Mr. BERNARD KINNEY, to open a store on the sidewalk on that thoroughfare, the Mayor has seen fit to veto the resolution on the ground that the sidewalk is presumed, as a general thing, to be intended for the use of foot passengers, the centre of the street being monopolized by horse-carts and other vehicles. There is reason in this view of the case. No one grudges the weather-beaten apple-woman her stall on the street; but it is generally supposed that traders of the presumed standing of Mr. BERNARD KINNEY might be accommodated in-doors, unless, indeed, there are special reasons for inviting them into the street. We believe it is a generally understood thing that Vesey-street is part of the public common, and that any one may pitch a tent there for general mercantile purposes without the permission either of the Common Council or his Worship the Mayor. But Wall-street is supposed to be reserved for street operations of a special kind, and on this ground -- if on no other -- the Mayor's treatment of Mr. KINNEY will probably be justified, although, as we are getting accustomed to every variety of nuisance, we do not know that so much need be said of this Wall-street favorite of the Common Council.

abstract: In the Senate yesterday, the Committee on Pensions was instructed to inquire whether any further legislation was necessary to provide relief for the families of colored soldiers who were...
lead_paragraph: In the Senate yesterday, the Committee on Pensions was instructed to inquire whether any further legislation was necessary to provide relief for the families of colored soldiers who were massacred at Fort Pillow. The Committee on Foreign Relations was directed to inquire and report whether if the Reciprocity Treaty with Great Britain continued in force, it would be desirable to include the Pacific Coast in its operations. The bill to expedite the settlement of land titles in California was passed. A bill was brought up for the relief of naval contractors, which went over under the rules. The Tax Bill was then brought up, and several amendments were adopted. At the evening session the bill to stipulate for the release of United States property from attachment, or other process, was passed. The bill to relieve the Professors of the West Point Academy from liability to military orders, was passed. The joint resolution tendering the thanks of Congress to Lieut.-Col. BAILEY, Acting Engineer of the Nineteenth Army Corps, was passed after the adoption of an amendment offered by Mr. GRIMES, striking out the clause authorizing a gold medal to be struck. The consideration of the Internal Revenue Bill was resumed, and the reading of the bill as in Committee of the Whole, was completed.

abstract: -- The guerrillas on the Mississippi River have been having a rather good time for the last month or two. The reason was that the guardian spirits of the Mississippi -- those low, black, mailed giants of Admiral PORTER -- were away up the Red River on extra duty, and, by various accidents, have been there unduly delayed. They are now all out again on the Mississippi in full feather. They are scouring up and down for rebels, and chastising them wherever found. A magnificent sweep for operating over have these gunboats -- one thousand miles of the Mississippi River. Three years ago the existence of an armed vessel in these waters was not even contemplated; now, we have a hundred of these armed vessels, mounting 462 guns, and manned by crews which number in all about 5,500 men. Not only the Mississippi they watch, but its tributaries, and the whole extent of the line over which their control is exercised, exceeds 3,000 miles. Sleeplessly they move to and fro. By day and by night they are on the scent. The retributive justice they administer upon the rebels keeps them in awe and in order. During their absence, these rebellious guerrillas broke loose, but they will soon now be driven to their holes and kept there.

abstract: THE LATE FATAL ACCIDENT IN BROADWAY  THE DRIVER COMMITTED To PRISON. The name of the woman who was run over and almost instantly killed on Tuesday night, at the corner of Broadway and Grand streets, has been ascertained. Deceased was Mrs. ELIZA DUBOIS, of No. 401 Hudson-avenue,
lead_paragraph: THE LATE FATAL ACCIDENT IN BROADWAY THE DRIVER COMMITTED To PRISON. The name of the woman who was run over and almost instantly killed on Tuesday night, at the corner of Broadway and Grand streets, has been ascertained. Deceased was Mrs. ELIZA DUBOIS, of No. 401 Hudson-avenue, Brooklyn. Coroner RANNEY, yesterday, held an inquest on the body at the New-York Hospital. Several persons who witnessed the occurrence testified that the driver, whose name is Owen Lynch, was driving at a reckless rate, and that when called upon to check his horses, he paid no attention to the warning. Lynch alleged that his horses were hard-bitted and he could not control them. All the witnesses testified, however, that he had his team entirely at his command and might have stopped it if he had been so disposed.

abstract: -- It is not possible to conceal the feeling of impatience which has taken hold of the most intelligently loyal portion of the English people, in their attempt to reconcile their reverence for the person of their Sovereign, with their further endurance of the impenetrable gloom in which the court surrounds itself. The subject is neither inviting to those whom it most immediately concerns, not specially tempting to friendly onlookers in the outside world. But it is daily forcing itself in such a manner upon public notice, that it cannot well avoid rising into the importance of a grave political issue.
lead_paragraph: -- It is not possible to conceal the feeling of impatience which has taken hold of the most intelligently loyal portion of the English people, in their attempt to reconcile their reverence for the person of their Sovereign, with their further endurance of the impenetrable gloom in which the court surrounds itself. The subject is neither inviting to those whom it most immediately concerns, not specially tempting to friendly onlookers in the outside world. But it is daily forcing itself in such a manner upon public notice, that it cannot well avoid rising into the importance of a grave political issue.

abstract: Last evening the Board of Engineers and Foremen held their annual meeting at Firemen's Hall. After the collection of the annual dues, the Treasurer's report was submitted, which, including the evening's collection, showed a balance on hand of $222 03. The company then went into election for officers for the ensuing year, when the old officers were all reelected. It was then decided to nominate candidates for the position of Assistant-Engineer, to fill a vacancy. A ballot being cast, Messrs. THOMAS CORWIN, of Engine No. 13, and BERNARD KENNEY of Hose No. 16, having received the highest number of votes, were declared the candidates. The election will take place on Monday evening, at the "Gotham," No. 298 Bowery. Polls to be open from 7 to 9 o'clock.

abstract: New-York Yacht Club Annual Regatta
snippet: New-York Yacht Club Annual Regatta
lead_paragraph: The day could hardly have been more pleasant, or the wind more favorable, for the Fifteenth Annual Regatta of the New-York Yacht Club, which took place yesterday. At an early hour the pier at the foot of Twentieth-street, North River, was thronged by people anxiously awaiting the arrival of the steamers which were to accompany the yachts "down the river." Before 10 o'clock, the hour designated for the departure of the fleet, the steamer Matteawan was crowded by members of the club, and their lady friends, and shortly after that hour the boat swung into the stream leaving the press to await the arrival of the Meta. This petty manifestation of exclusiveness was fully appreciated by the Reportorial Corps, and considered a special dispensation in their favor -- the society on board the Meta being quite as agreeable, and possibly as select as those on board the Matteawan.

abstract: The trial of EDWARD HUNTER for the murder of his wife, before Recorder HOFFMAN at the Court of General Sessions, resulted yesterday in a verdict of murder in the second degree. The trial has occupied ten days, and excited unusual interest.
lead_paragraph: The trial of EDWARD HUNTER for the murder of his wife, before Recorder HOFFMAN at the Court of General Sessions, resulted yesterday in a verdict of murder in the second degree. The trial has occupied ten days, and excited unusual interest. The prosecution was conducted by O.L. STEWART, Assistant District Attorney. The counsel for the prisoner were J.F. WALTON and H.L. CLINTON. There was no question raised as to the prisoner's having committed the homicide. The general management of the case and the summing up devolved upon Mr. CLINTON, whose indefatigable exertions in behalf of the prisoner are worthy of special mention. The jury were out forty-eight hours endeavoring to arrive at a verdict. It is understood that about half of the jury were at first in favor of a conviction of the capital crime. The prisoner had previously borne a good character, and was attended during the trial by many faithful friends.

lead_paragraph: The doctors and lawyers are every year adding new and curious chapters to the treatises on medical jurisprudence. The number of cases in which insanity is put forward as a justification for crime is increasing so rapidly, both here and in England, that the moral as well as legal responsibility of individuals for their acts, and above all, for their criminal acts, bids fair to disappear altogether. abstract: -- The plaintiff in this case brings an action against the editor and proprietor of the New-York Leader for an alleged libelous and defamatory article published in that paper against his good name and character. The article was headed "Count, No-account," and insinuated that the world-renowned author, poet and actor, George, the Count Joannes, is only a Count by the courtesy of those who have a mind to call him so. The eminent nobleman appears in person in this action and claims the sum of $20,000, as the exact amount of damages to his wounded honor.

abstract: THE LAWRENCE MASSACRE. Our readers will doubtless remember the accounts we gave at the time of the horrible atrocities committed by QUANTRELL and his bloody band on the defenceless and unsuspecting inhabitants of Lawrence, on the morning of the 21st of last August.
lead_paragraph: THE LAWRENCE MASSACRE. -- Our readers will doubtless remember the accounts we gave at the time of the horrible atrocities committed by QUANTRELL and his bloody band on the defenceless and unsuspecting inhabitants of Lawrence, on the morning of the 21st of last August. They will also doubtless be interested to hear an account of it by an eye-witness of the tragic scenes. Rev. Mr. PADDOCK, President of Baker University, Kansas, and Pastor of the Methodist Church in Lawrence, who was himself on QUANTRELL's death-roll, and was shot at by the ruffians, will give an account of what he saw on that eventful morning, to-morrow (Sabbath,) the 5th inst. He will speak at the Hanson-place M.E. Church, Brooklyn, (Rev. Mr. WOODRUFF's,) at 10 1/2 A.M., and at Fleet-street M.E. Church, Brooklyn, (Rev. Mr. HATFIELD's,) at 7 3/4 P.M. Those who have heard him tell us that he is an interesting, thrilling and eloquent speaker.

abstract: FUNERAL OF A CLERGYMAN. The funeral of Rev. FREDERICK S. WILEY took place from St. Ann's Church, yesterday. The deceased was formerly assistant pastor of this congregation.
lead_paragraph: FUNERAL OF A CLERGYMAN. -- The funeral of Rev. FREDERICK S. WILEY took place from St. Ann's Church, yesterday. The deceased was formerly assistant pastor of this congregation. Subsequently he went to Philadelphia, and thence returned to New-York, where he was one of the ministers of Grace Church for a number of years. Failing health necessitated a voyage to Europe. He died in Florence, Italy, on the 20th of January last, and his remains were brought home for interment. The funeral services at the church were conducted by the pastor, Rev. Dr. MILLS, Rev. Dr. DYER, Rev. Dr. CANFIELD and Rev. Dr. COAD. The remains were conveyed to Greenwood Cemetery, accompanied by a large concourse of sympathizing friends and relatives. The pall-bearers were Rev. Dr. Price, Rev. Dr. Partridge, Rev. Mr. Tracy, Rev. Mr. Dunn, Rev. Mr. Smith, Rev. Mr. Eigenbrodt and Rev. Samuel Clark.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, a memorial was received from the New-York Chamber, of Commerce, in favor of establiabing a Navy-yard at New-London, Conn. Three thousand extra copies of the National Bank Bill were ordered  printed. A bill to incorporate the Potomac Ferry Company was introduced and referred to the Committee on the District of Columbia.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, a memorial was received from the New-York Chamber, of Commerce, in favor of establiabing a Navy-yard at New-London, Conn. Three thousand extra copies of the National Bank Bill were ordered printed. A bill to incorporate the Potomac Ferry Company was introduced and referred to the Committee on the District of Columbia. A petition was presented, setting forth that many, disasters in our army were caused by the use of intoxicating drink, and asking Congress for some remedy. The petition was laid on the table. The bill for the relief of Wisconsin was discussed until the expiration of the morning hour. The bill to facilitate commerce between the Atlantic and Pacific States was reported back with an amendment. In the evening, the bill to punish counterfeiting United States coin was passed, and the Tax Bill was considered until the hour of adjournment.

lead_paragraph: The long anticipated trot in which this year's champion of the trotting turf. Dexter, was to meet opponents, who were determined to thoroughly test his merits, or deprive him of the laurels he had previously achieved, came off at the Fashion Course, on Friday, the trot having been postponed from the previous day for which it was originally fixed on account of the unpropitious state of the weather.

abstract: The People ex rel. Ambrose O'Niel vs. John Brannigan. -- This was the return to a writ of habeas corpus by means of which the relator sought to regain the custody of Mary O'Niel, his infant daughter, a little girl of eleven years. The respondent in his return produced the child and set forth that her mother was dead; that he being her uncle had taken her when she was five years old and had kept her and had provided for her ever since; that the child's father had since remarried, and the girl did not wish to go to her step-mother's; that he was willing to keep her and provide for her, as one of his own children; and that he and his wife were much attached to her. Although it did not appear that the child was detained against her will. His Honor said that unless something was shown against the character of the father, or that he was unable to provide for his children, he was entitled to the custody of his daughter, and it must be ordered accordingly.
lead_paragraph: The People ex rel. Ambrose O'Niel vs. John Brannigan. -- This was the return to a writ of habeas corpus by means of which the relator sought to regain the custody of Mary O'Niel, his infant daughter, a little girl of eleven years. The respondent in his return produced the child and set forth that her mother was dead; that he being her uncle had taken her when she was five years old and had kept her and had provided for her ever since; that the child's father had since remarried, and the girl did not wish to go to her step-mother's; that he was willing to keep her and provide for her, as one of his own children; and that he and his wife were much attached to her. Although it did not appear that the child was detained against her will. His Honor said that unless something was shown against the character of the father, or that he was unable to provide for his children, he was entitled to the custody of his daughter, and it must be ordered accordingly.

abstract: The indecorous haste and carelessness usually observable in England on the disposal of the effects of celebrated, and particularly of literary men, immediately after their decease, was never more strongly exemplified than in the recent sale of THACKERAY'S library and papers.
lead_paragraph: -- The indecorous haste and carelessness usually observable in England on the disposal of the effects of celebrated, and particularly of literary men, immediately after their decease, was never more strongly exemplified than in the recent sale of THACKERAY'S library and papers. From the accounts of the auction it is evident that the most valuable materials for his biography were sacrificed and dispersed without a thought of their intrinsic value, or the purpose to which they might be properly applied. As a sample, among the lots were "four large drawers, like those of a kitchen dresser," full of books, not very inviting in outward aspect, but the more valuable because they had been actually "used up" by the late owner, and were crowded with his memoranda, sketches, notes, &c. These are all now being catalogued and invitingly set forth to the public, at high prices by the booksellers, who made a fortunate speculative purchase of these and other similar lots. Among them we notice one article worth mentioning -- "Sketch Book of Mr. THACKERAY during a tour in France in 1842 and 1843 with upward of forty colored pen-and-ink and pencil drawings of shipping, old buildings, churches, characteristic figures, landscape groups, &c., including 'Rouen,' 'Honfleur,' 'The Banks of the Seine,' &c., very spirited, full of character, and ready for publication." This valuable relic is priced, not immoderately, at six guineas. In one of his "Roundabout Papers," THACKERAY mentions that the two favorite books he was accustomed to take to bed with him was Montaigne's Essays and Howell's Letters. The relic-hunter may secure, no doubt, the identical copy of old Howell for the small sum of five shillings sterling. An American book -- MILLMAN's Rifle, Axe and Saddlebags, "with the autograph THACKERAY in fancy letters," is now highly priced at one pound. The catalogue before us contains one hundred and twenty-six lots of a similar character, including presentation copies from authors to THACKERAY, books belonging to his father, others given to his daughters, &c., the sale of which seems to show a sad want of feeling, when there could be no pecuniary necessity to excuse it, as the property left by the novelist was estimated for the legacy duties at twenty thousand pounds.

abstract: We publish in our advertising columns this morning the prospectus of the new line of steamers which is soon to commence running between this port and Havre. The Washington, the pioneer vessel of the line, will leave Havre on June 15, and sail from this port on her return trip July 6. Her burden is 3,400 tons, (old builders' measurement.) She is 350 English feet in length, 45 feet beam, 33 feet in depth, and on her trial-trip in the Clyde she made 13 1/2 knots per hour. The Washington and her consorts will all be under the command of able and experienced seamen, and the managers of the line design to take special pains to promote the comfort and safety of their passengers, as will be seen by reference to the advertisement. Notwithstanding the number of steamers plying between this City and the different European ports, their united capacity is insufficient to accommodate the immense number of immigrants now rushing hither. This fact alone insures the success of the new line, and the favorable auspices under which it starts makes it certain that it will soon become an established institution.
lead_paragraph: We publish in our advertising columns this morning the prospectus of the new line of steamers which is soon to commence running between this port and Havre. abstract: Tuckerman, H. T. America and Her Commentators
snippet: Tuckerman, H. T. America and Her Commentators
lead_paragraph: In the existing plethora of literacy matter, when it is almost impossible to keep up with the current of publication on any given subject in America, England, France and Germany -- much less to carry investigations backward into times past -- any book about books that furnishes the student with the results of reading and inquiry on a special branch of research is sure of a favorable reception. In this view Mr. TUCKERMAN's work will be extremely acceptable to many -- containing, as it does, an elegant and spirited survey of a class of books that some representation of is felt to be indispensable in every American library, while none but a large public collection would like to be burdened by the whole number, supposing such a thing to be obtainable. The value of a critical guide like that before us is at once obvious as affording the basis for a judicious selection, independently of its intrinsic interest as a curious chapter in literary history. Wonderful, indeed, is the consecrating and ennobling power of Time -- the trashiest libel -- the feeblest or most ferocious utterance hiding itself in neglected print -- of to-day -- when once a portion of the pitiless and inexorable past becomes a thing for historians to study, for philosophers to discuss. The colossus of history is a composite structure, built up principally by the aggregation of materials from which nothing is rejected as too small or trifling in the eye of the master-workman, like MACAULAY, who is able to penetrate to and lay bare the springs of human action, from the slight indications afforded by the outward form and pressure of things apparently the most trivial, but pregnant with suggestion when rightly considered. Of this class was originally a large portion of the materials on which the early history of the United States of America must rest. State papers and documents may supply the bony skeleton, the framework of the narrative, but the mind desiderates something more succulent. In the country itself the struggle for life was too engrossing to allow much time for the jotting down of facts that might illustrate its social progress. The great present was too earnestly felt, was too exacting in its claims on all to be written about in the dilettanti spirit that only comes with ease and reflection; consequently, we are dependent on the reports of those whom chance brought to our shores for the lights and shadows that give animation and expression to the story of the past. Thus the most curious account of Boston and its inhabitants in the early part of the last century that remains to us, is given by a bookseller, the famous JOHN DUNTON, who brought over a cargo of literary ware as a speculation, and opened a store in Boston to dispose of it. His "Life and Errors" narrates his experience in New-England, but has not apparently fallen in Mr. TUCKERMAN's way. We may say indeed, once for all, that a work of this kind being founded on bibliography, a more exact acquaintance with that study would have cleared it of many errors of names and dates, corrected numberless misprints which are now very offensive to the eyes of those who discern them, and have supplied many omissions that would have added to the interest and completeness of the undertaking. One obvious defect, only, will we mention, that is, the want of a methodical or chronological catalogue raisonne of the authors, analyzed or referred to in the text; others it might seem invidious to dwell upon, as they do not largely detract from the value of the book for general readers. Mr. TUCKERMAN's object is (as he himself declares) "two-fold -- to present a general view of the traits and transitions of our country, as recorded at different periods, and by writers of various nationalities; and to afford those desirous of authentic information in regard to the United States, a guide to the sources thereof" -- the latter incidentally involving the discussion of the comparative value and interest of the principal critics of our civilization. Starting with the discovery of the continent, a rapid introductory view is taken of the early voyagers and explorers who have left memorials of their expeditions, often the records of enterprise and endurance worthy of the most heroic ages of the world, that most always remain precious in the estimation of those to whose ancestors the goodly land they possess was by them laid open and made accessible. They fall into two great divisions as far as the present United States are concerned. The founders of Virginia and of New-England, of whom Capt. JOHN SMITH and Gov. WINTHROP may be taken as the respective types. Brief notice is made of the Northern navigators and their half-mythical Vinland, but the work only fairly commences with the next chapter, dedicated to the French missionary explorers of New-York, Canada and the Great West, HENNEPIN, MENARD, ALLOUEZ, MARQUETTE, CHARLEVOIX, &c. The memory of these enlightened men, devoted to their self-imposed task -- not to be swerved from it by any considerations of personal safety, but often sacrificing their lives to the maintenance of the principles that inspired them -- still lingers fragantly over many a sunny cove and inlet in the great lakes -- many a haunted isle in the blue waters of the St. Lawrence. There is no purer page in history than that devoted to the unadorned recital of their labors. As related by themselves, the simplicity of the tone adopted shows that they were following in the straight-forward path of duty, unconscious that future generations would look up to them admiringly as the true pioneers of civilization, in regions more weird and remote from the ordinary associations, than we can now well realized. Continuing the treatment of his subject by nationalities, Mr. TUCKERMAN next proceeds to the later group of French travelers and writers whose connection with the War of the Revolution caused their testimony to be eagerly sought for in Europe, and still furnishes us with many of the most interesting details that we possess relative to that event. Prominent among them is the lively and satirical Marquis DE CHASTELLUX, whose travels are well analyzed; the Abbe ROBIN, Chaplain to Gen. ROCHAMBEAU, and the unfortunate BRISSOT DE WARVILLE, who visited America fatally to his future lot in his native country, where he died a victim to the vain attempt of naturalizing in an uncongenial soil the ideas he had imbibed abroad. Great names of statesmen thrown on these shores by the storms of the French Revolution follow quickly. CHATEAUBRIAND, TALLEYRAND, SEGUR, LA ROCHEFOUCAULD, VOLNEY and others, have all left memorials of their impressions more or less satisfactory, and at the present day French travel culminates in the height of mental culture, that yields the clear philosophic vision and the power of generalization from scattered and imperfect data characterizing the works of DE TOCQUEVILLE, CHEVALIER, DE BEAUMONT, POUSSIN, AMPERE, DE GASPARIN, &c. The English travelers come next in order. Foremost among them stands the apostolical figure of BERKELEY. The personal history of this self-denying prolate has been a favorite study of Mr. TUCKERMAN's, and it is accordingly treated con amore in this chapter. The names that follow are of a very miscellaneous character, and there are none to equal in attraction those that the record of French travel has to show. Even the Revolution itself was little productive of book making in England, compared with what now follows any striking event; probably the unfortunate issue of the conflict may have rendered it a subject that afforded little gratification to the Georgian era of readers. The idyllic pictures of rural life in New-York, by Mrs. GRANT, of Laggan, are the chief domestic English memorials of the ante-revolutionary period in our Northern States. A few participants in the war and its results have left personal narrations, as CAPT. ANBUREY, a captive with BURGOYNE's army, and WILLIAM EDDIS, the royalist collector of the customs at Baltimore, and others; but the total amount of information so preserved is not important. It was in the next generation -- when the economic advantages of America as a home and refuge for the multitudes struggling for mere existence in Europe first attracted attention -- that the shoal of English travelers properly begins, and continues to the present day in scarcely abated numbers. Too numerous to be all characterized, Mr. TUCKERMAN gives a fair account of the more prominent among them, doing justice to the descriptive powers and vivacity of Mrs. TROLLOPE, the conscientious dullness of Capt. BASIL HALL, the glowing admiration for nature of FANNY KEMBLE, the scientific accuracy of Sir CHARLES LYELL, while he justly animadverts on the unfairness that generally marks their strictures on the social condition and aspects of life in the country they describe. The name of this class is legion, but nearly all of any pretension will be found alluded to in Mr. TUCKERMAN's book. The northern European writers, mostly from Germany, afford materials for the next chapter, and the following one completes the European travelers and commentators by an enumeration of those of Italy, several of whom are curious, and little known. In conclusion some space is allotted to the home travelers who have extended the knowledge of the continent of their birth or adoption, in the interests of science and commerce, and to the general works descriptive of the United States, as an aggregate, destined for the information of foreigners or our own countrymen. The work cannot fail to be generally useful, and fills a place in our libraries as yet unoccupied.

abstract: A visit to the iron-clad shipyards in the neighborhood of New-York, in which the last batch of light-dratt vessels are building, shows that the Naubuc, Modoc and Cohoes would be ready for launching within five or six weeks.
lead_paragraph: A visit to the iron-clad shipyards in the neighborhood of New-York, in which the last batch of light-dratt vessels are building, shows that the Naubuc, Modoc and Cohoes would be ready for launching within five or six weeks. These vessels, although having an immense armor, will draw only six feet of water. They were contracted for at the rate of $365,000 each if built in six months, and $395,000 if built in nine months. They had hardly been commenced, however, when new and valuable improvements, suggested by the experience of our other vessels at Charleston, were introduced; and these necessarily threw the work backward a great deal, so that some ten or twelve of the ships, which would now have been afloat and preparing rapidly for active service, are only on the verge of completion. Fourteen are all planked, so that if their services were immediately required, night and day work could finish them in exceedingly short space of time. There is hardly a river or a lagoon of the South in which these vessels cannot move with ease and safety, while they can take these guns of a heavier calibre than were ever seen on rivers before. Their motive power is screw of sufficient magnitude to propel them at the rate of seven or eight miles an hour. Not being intended for ocean service their motions on the coast will necessarily have to be well considered and few. They are essentially harbor batteries. If the nineteen vessels of this class, which are now building, could at this time be transported to the Mississippi there would be an end of the rebel gunboats. They possess nearly all the defensive power of the original monitor, and as much offensive power, their only weak point being below water-mark, and the rebels have proved recently that they can reach our ships in that region very effectively.

abstract: Gladstone's, Mr., Speech--Liberalism in England
snippet: Gladstone's, Mr., Speech--Liberalism in England
lead_paragraph: It is now generally acknowledged in England that Mr. GLADSTONE'S late speech on the extension of the franchise, indicates pretty clearly his political future. It marks him out, beyond question, for the leadership of the Liberal party which, it is acknowledged, will step into power after the Tories have had one more turn in office. The present Ministry is already in a very shaky condition, and nothing except the want of a decided, well-marked policy on the part of the Opposition has prevented its overthrow ere now. The Tories have been very successful in finding fault with its conduct in this or that matter, but when an occasion arose for a trial of strength, they have never been able to trace any broad lines of difference that would distinguish their general course, if placed in power, from that of the present Cabinet; and without this there was, of course, little use in leading their followers to the attack, with the positive design of ousting the Ministry. On the great question which has, ever since the revolution of 1688, divided Whig and Tory -- the mode of distributing the governing power among the different classes of the nation -- both PALMERSTON and DISRAELI have been as one for the last four years. Their conflicts have, under these circumstances, lost all interest and excitement.

abstract: Inaugural Message
snippet: Inaugural Message
lead_paragraph: Gov. GILMORE, who was recently reelected Governor of New-Hampshire, was inaugurated on Thursday last. In his message, the state debt was represented to be $1,274,058 99 -- adding aid paid to families of volunteers it will be $600,000 more. The Governor said this debt was not so large in proportion to the number and resources of the people as that incurred by the revolutionary fathers in their great struggle for liberty, nor by it was there any risk of the State becoming bankrupt. No extravagance had led to its accumulation, and comparison with the outlays of other States would prove the degree of economy studied by the Government. The funding of this debt is urged at the present time, when money is plenty, and the issue of six per cent. bonds covering the amount, and payable in fifteen or twenty years, is recommended, as also the assumption by the State of a portion at least of the war debt incurred by cities and towns.

abstract: Sergant SLATER, of the Eigth Precinct, accompanied by Roundsman CROLIUS, and Officers Egan, Miller, Fenton, Adams, Traver and Spurbeck, were yesterday commissioned to search certain houses in Mercer-street, for deserters.
lead_paragraph: Sergant SLATER, of the Eigth Precinct, accompanied by Roundsman CROLIUS, and Officers Egan, Miller, Fenton, Adams, Traver and Spurbeck, were yesterday commissioned to search certain houses in Mercer-street, for deserters. In the course of their travels they entered the premises No. 81 Mercer-street. They there found gambling going on very extensively, and as was their duty to do, they look into custody, all whom they found engaged in the unlawful business. Seventeen well dressed and many of them intelligent looking men, were conveyed before Justice DODGE, at the Jefferson Market Police Court, by the officials above named. They gave their names as follows: Andrew Clacker, dealer; Francis Schoharie, cue keeper; John Whaley, looker-out; Patrick Egan, Henry Vancott, John Moore, Andrew Andrews, Thomas Johnson, Harry Howard, Jeremiah O'Bride, James Joyce, Thomas Orr, Thomas Smith, James Lawrence, Joseph Myers, James Nelson and James McCarty -- all of whom, it is alleged, were engaged in gambling at the time of the arrest. They were committed to answer. A large number of checks, cue boxes, and other gambling implements were taken possession of by the police.

abstract: The two great armies now confront each other definitely in the strip of country, some ten miles wide, that lies between the Pamunky and the upper waters of the Chickahominy. GRANT'S line, from Cold Harbor to Atlee's, on the Central Railroad, is fully seven miles in length; while LEE'S we judge to be somewhat more contracted.
lead_paragraph: The two great armies now confront each other definitely in the strip of country, some ten miles wide, that lies between the Pamunky and the upper waters of the Chickahominy. GRANT'S line, from Cold Harbor to Atlee's, on the Central Railroad, is fully seven miles in length; while LEE'S we judge to be somewhat more contracted. GRANT thus directly faces the rebel capital as well as the rebel army. LEE has planted himself firmly on the north bank of the Chickahominy; and the attacks that have lately been made upon his lines, as well as the assaults that he in turn has made, would seem to indicate that he is prepared either to accept or offer general battle upon his present position.

abstract: Green, Lt.-Col. of 173d N Y. V.
snippet: Green, Lt.-Col. of 173d N Y. V.
lead_paragraph: -The last arrival from New-Orleans brings intelligence of the death, on the 13th inst., of Lieut.-Col. WILLIAM N. GREEN, Jr., of the One Hundred and Seventy-third New-York Volunteers, from wounds received at the battle of Pleasant Hill, La., at the age of twenty-one. Entering the army as a private at the outbreak of the war, Col. GREEN was promoted for the brave conduct at the battle of Roanoke Island. He passed through various battles and skirmishes -- among others that of Cedar Mountain, at which he was captured, and taken to the Libby Prison at Richmond. After his exchange he continued in the service, and received especial mention for his courageous conduct in capturing, with his own hand, the sword of a Georgia Captain and the battle-flag of the regiment. The sword was presented to Col. GREEN, by the Commanding General, and he was promoted to a Lieutenant-Colency. About a year since he left for the Department of the Gulf, passed with his regiment through the whole Louisiana campaign and that of the Red River, up to the time of the battle in which he received his death-wound. He was unusually well read in military law, and had been intrusted with the presidency of courts-martial for the trial of offences punishable with death. He was brave, manly and honorable, and his assiduous attention to the comfort of the men under his command gave him a high place in their affections, and insured a cheerful alacrity in obedience.
