abstract: In 1851, in  Zanesville, O., one JOHN W. SOALES, butcher, was arrested and lodged in jail on a charge of larceny, the larceny alleged consisting in an unlawful appropriation of certain pigs.
lead_paragraph: In 1851, in Zanesville, O., one JOHN W. SOALES, butcher, was arrested and lodged in jail on a charge of larceny, the larceny alleged consisting in an unlawful appropriation of certain pigs. Shortly after his release from jail on this charge, fearing another arrest for some offence not known, SCALES left Zanesville early one morning and made his way to Cincinnati. He left in Zanesville his wife, CATHERINE, and children, without provision for their support. The wife heard from him, by letter, once after he left her, and that about a month after he had run away. Some two years or more after, having had an offer of marriage again, she sought a divorce on the ground of desertion, but suspended proceedings, by advice of her lawyer, on learning that SCALES was dead, and so informed her intended new husband. A short time after, in the Spring of 1855, she was married to her present husband, Mr. WM.S. JONES, with whom she has lived since that time -- the last three or four years in St. Paul. Her husband has held a respectable position in society, and her deportment has been such as to commend her to those with whom she became acquainted. Recently, her former husband, SCALES, made his appearance in this city, had interviews with Mr. JONES and with Mrs. JONES, and finally made complaint of adultery against JONES, before Justice MCELRATH of the Police Court. An examination was had on the complaint, yesterday, before Justice MCELRATH, and the complaint was dismissed and JONES discharged from arrest. On announcement of the decision, there was a word or two of emphatic approval from one or two of the persons present who had listened to the evidence in the case, while the looks of all showed their sympathy with the defendant. Mrs. JONES was present during the examination, sitting by the side of Mr. JONES, and at its close walked away with him. Mr. SCALES, the complaining witness, fell asleep during the argument of the lawyers, and so remained at the close of the Justice's decision. His appearance would be apt to make an impression against him with a jury. -- St. Paul Press, May 26.

abstract: Popular Delusion; Falsehoods on the War
snippet: Popular Delusion; Falsehoods on the War
lead_paragraph: We publish this morning, upon our supplementary leaf, a letter from the interior of Texas, depicting with great vividness the Confederate system of imposition. The North, in judging the conduct of the Southern people, has always failed to make just account of the extent to which they have been deluded. Surprise is expressed that they should have ever been drawn into the rebellion at all, and that, having been drawn into it, they should so generally cling to it with such fierceness. The wonder rather should be that their revolutionary passion has not been more intense. Such infernal falsehood could not have unrestricted play upon human nature anywhere without inflaming it to madness.
headline: {'main': 'Popular Delusion in the South A Letter from Interior Texas.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Popular Delusion in the South A Letter from Interior Texas.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: -We are not an advocate of stimulants of an alcoholic character; indeed, we deprecate this "daily tonic" idea -- this "morning toddy" which we see offered in all sorts of shapes as a recuperator, invigorator, revitalizer, &c. As a rule, all artificial stimulants are dangerous remedies, and must be taken into the system as you would mercury or arsenic, in very small doses. But we have had an opportunity to try the now well-advertised article known as HUBBEL's Golden Bitters, and are frank to say where the system needs building up, where a stimulant is required to aid nature in restoring a lost appetite and infusing a vigorous action to the debilitated functions, we can recommend these bitters. HUBBEL's Golden Bitters are evidently intended to improve the debilitated human system rather than to tickle the palate, and are therefore a harmless and safe remedy to keep in the house. -- New-York Weekly Day Book.

abstract: -- The card addressed to the public, on behalf of Capt. C.F. HALL, which we publish to-day, will elicit attention alike in consideration of the importance of the subject, the fame which the courage and endurance of the explorer has won for him, and the unquestioned standing and influence of the gentlemen who have undertaken to speak to the public in behalf of his enterprise. The narrative of Capt. HALL's previous explorations (shortly to be issued by the Messrs. HARPER) has engaged his time and energy for many months. But he is now free to renew his labors as an explorer in the Arctic seas, so soon as the cooperation of those interested in the enterprise shall insure the proper outfit of the expedition.

abstract: Dr. RAPHAEL, Professor of surgery in the Thirteenth-street Medical College, delivered an exceedingly interesting lecture last evening before the Ladies National Relief Association, No. 1 Clinton Hall. The principal object of these lectures, which are given by distinguished Surgeons every Tuesday and Friday evenings, is the instruction of army nurses in some of the duties of their calling. The Relief Association hire those nurses, provide homes for them while in the City, and send them to the field, the camps, and the hospitals. The subject of the lecture last evening was "Gunshot Wounds," and it was treated by the learned author in a practical, common-sense manner, well adapted to an audience that had little knowledge of the technicalities of surgery. In the course of his lecture the Professor said that the different kinds of improved fire-arms now in use rendered gunshot wounds received during the present war much more fatal and destructive than formerly. The remarks of Dr. RAPHAEL were listened to with great attention, and the corps of nurses present cannot fall to appreciate the benefits of these lectures when they enter the Army Hospitals, and undertake the care of wounded soldiers.

abstract: "Cinderella" is still the card par excellence, and Miss SALLIE HOLMAN the chief charm of the performance at the Broadway Academy of Music. In this young prima donna there is no abatement of the many claims which last season gained for her throughout the States so warm a recognition as Cinderella. Her conception and rendering of the role is very pleasing, and she has acquired a thorough mastery of the sources of expression. She has also the gift of protraying passion, and of so deep a kind that it imparts delicacy to her transports and much naturalness to her anguish. If her age is as much as eighteen, her appearance does not suggest more than fifteen, owing to her petite and delicate person, and radiant comptexion. To-night is the last of "Cinderella," and there is a matinee at 3 o'clock P.M.

abstract: -- We talked yesterday with CHARLES DYER, a private in Company E, One Hundred and Fifteenth New-York Volunteers, who was captured by the rebels at the battle of Olustee, Florida, on the 20th of February. He was carried by his captors to the arsenal in the town of Chattahooche, from which he made his escape, and arrived within the Union lines at Larkinvile, on the Tennessee and Alabama Railroad, after a painful and hazardous journey through the woods for more than 250 miles. He was chased once, and overtaken by a squad of rebel cavalry, accompanied by a pack of seven bloodhounds, who would have torn him to pieces but for the admonition of the Captain, who shouted to him to climb a tree. He did climb in a hurry, and just as he was mounting with accelerated velocity, one of the hounds snapped at him and left the print of his teeth quite visible on Mr. DYER's heel. The country through which Mr. DYER passed was almost uninhabited. Scarcely an able-bodied man was visible; a few aged or decrepit men, and the white women and little children who were working in the fields, were the only persons visible. Most of the time he lived on green peas and other vegetables, but occasionally hunger would drive him to the cabins, in which the inmates had nothing whatever, save a little corn bread. No stock was to be seen except a few mules and a few poor wild hogs.

Scarcely an able-bodied man was visible; a few aged or decrepit men, and the white women and little children who were working in the fields, were the only persons visible. Most of the time he lived on green peas and other vegetables, but occasionally hunger would drive him to the cabins, in which the inmates had nothing whatever, save a little corn bread. No stock was to be seen except a few mules and a few poor wild hogs.

abstract: The death of Col. PETER A. PORTER, of the Eighth New-York Volunteer Heavy Artillery, is announced in dispatches from the Army of the Potomac. Col. PORTER was a resident of Niagara County in this State, and we believe a lawyer by profession, in the prime of life, talented and wealthy, he goes to swell the long list of public men of this State who have offered their lives to their country, and have been sacrificed to the demon of war. Col. PORTER came prominently before the public in the early part of 1862 as Member of Assembly from his district. In the Assembly Chamber he was distinguished for the urbanity of his manners, by his power as a speaker and readiness in debate. During the summer of 1862 he was instrumental in raising a regiment of heavy artillery, since known as the Eighth, and received from Gov. MORGAN a commission as its Colonel. The regiment le[???]t for the seat of war in the Fall of that year, and was for a long time thereafter stationed at Baltimore. In September, 1863, Col. PETER A. PORTER was unanimously nominated by the Union State Convention as their candidate for the office of Secretary of State. He was at that time at Baltimore, in command of his regiment, and being notified by letter of his nomination, he promptly answered it, declining the high honor conferred upon him. His letter of declination to the Chairman of the Central Committee must have rendered eim forever beloved by his soldiers. He declined because he wished to serve the country in the field, and for other and equually honorable reasons. He had recruited his regiment by holding out to the men the prospect that he would be their commander; he had promised to lead them, and he would neither deceive nor desert them.

abstract: The United States steam revenue cutter Wayanda, from Washington, D.C., on the 28th, via Newport, R.I., 2d instant at 6 A.M. arrived at this port yesterday A.M. She is the first of the six new vessels contracted for by the Hon. Secretary of the Treasury, a year ago, delivered. She was built in Baltimore by J.T. FARDY & BROTHER. The following is a list of her officers: Captain, J.A. WHITE; First Lieutenant, D.D. Tompkins; Second Lieutenant, D.B. Hodgden; Third Lieutenant, Thomas Say; Chief Engineer, A.M. Cumming; First Assistant, Frank Pulsifer; Second Assistants, Thos. Mulholland and J.E. Jeffers.

abstract: Johnson's Island, Attempted Escape
snippet: Johnson's Island, Attempted Escape
lead_paragraph: The Cleveland Leader of the 2d has the following: -- A gentleman just from Johnson's Island furnishes us with the following valuable information in regard to a recent attempt to escape from the Island. He says that on Sunday last, at half after nine A.M., a plot of the prisoners to escape was discovered, which had nearly been carried into effect. It seems that a plank in one of the cook-houses, in the middle of one of the barracks, had been removed, and that a tunnel had been excavated, with an outlet beyond the wall of the prison-yard. In this hole, which was large enough to admit the passage of one man, were found three ladders, roughly constructed, three knives, notched into saws, a let of bed-ticking from beds, tarred so as to be waterproof, a revolver, a dark lantern made out of an old fruit-can, with a hole and slide in one end, and three life-preservers, made of tightly-corked canteens, four to each life-preserver, fastened to a canvas belt.

abstract: The Dano-German Conference
snippet: The Dano-German Conference
lead_paragraph: The month of truce has almost expired, and yet the Conference has effected nothing. "The divergence of opinion," says the London News, "not only between the belligerents, but between Austria, Prussia and the neutral Powers, is so wide that they have not been able even to agree on any common basis of discussion." The Danish plenipotentiaries have taken their stand on the Treaty of London, and insist that the provisions of that instrument are binding on all the parties who assented to it. The German diplomats, on the contrary, abjure that treaty altogether, and maintain that the war has freed them from its trammels; while the representatives of the neutral States, though inclining to the Danish view of the question, feel themselves paralyzed from inability to reconcile the jarring pretensions of the litigants. The pacificators are in fact in a dead lock, and cannot advance a single step as long as this London Treaty is suffered to remain as a stumbling block in their way. Whatever might be its obligations under other circumstances, it is now impracticable. The solution of the problem touching the future relations of the Duchies to Denmark, will prove amply sufficient to test the tact of the opposing plenipos, without superadding the unprofitable task of attempting to attain unanimity as to the meaning of this instrument, to which Europe owes both the war and the Conference. Let the Treaty of London then be at once shelved by the general consent of all parties, and let the diplomats apply themselves to determine what is to be the future status of the Danish Duchies.

abstract: Grant's and Sherman's Campaigns
snippet: Grant's and Sherman's Campaigns
lead_paragraph: The bygone month of May will assuredly be one of the most memorable in the annals of the war. With its opening days, our two great armies in Virginia and in Georgia simultaneously advanced -- the advance quickly followed, in the one field, with the deliverance of battle by LEE, his repulse and retreat; and in the other field, the advance speedily progressing, with the driving of JOHNSTON from one and another, and still others, of the heights and ridges of the mountains of upper Georgia. As the days wore on, the battle of the Wilderness was succeeded by the battles at Spottsylvania; the flanking movement on the lines of Mine Run was followed by the flanking movement on the line of the Po; this again followed by forcing the passage of the North Anna, the recrossing of that stream and the flanking of LEE's lines on the South Anna; this followed, by the passage of the Pamunky, the march direct toward the objective of Richmond, and the contest at the Chickahominy. In all of which movements Lieut.-Gen. GRANT took the initiative, while LEE was compelled, in each successive instance, to wait upon the will, and adapt himself as best he might, to the movements of his adversary. When the month opened our army was something less than a hundred miles from Richmond; at its close we were within ten miles of it; and although, in some circumstances, this might form no criterion whatever by which to judge of our gains, we think that viewing the incidents and reviewing the history of the advance, we can be guided by it somewhat in measuring how we stand as compared with how we stood.
headline: {'main': 'The May Campaigns.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The May Campaigns.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: New-Orleans, Eight Steamboats Burned, Supposed by Incendiary
snippet: New-Orleans, Eight Steamboats Burned, Supposed by Incendiary
lead_paragraph: The steamship Morning Star, Capt. H.L. HEPBURN, from New-Orleans May 28, via Havana May 31, arrived at the port yesterday afternoon, with 220 passengers and 1,000 bales of cotton. Purser FULLER reports that on the night of the 27th ult. a fire broke out among the steamers at the levee, near the foot of Canal-street, destroying eight river steamers and several sail craft -- among which was the steamer Empire Parrish, belonging to SPOFFORD, TILESTON & CO.; the balance were river steamers, most of which have been in the Government service. Great injury was also done to the adjacent levee and wharf buildings. The Morning Star was compelled to get up steam, owing to her close proximity to the fire.

abstract: A story is current of a shocking occurrence at Litchfield. It is stated that a citizen of that town who was lying quite sick, was left on Monday night to the care of a single watcher -- a man of the neighborhood. During the night the watcher was seized with an attack of delirium tremens, and in his frenzy assaulted the helpless invalid and beat him to death! When the sick chamber was entered at an early hour in the morning, the madman was found dragging the corpse of his victim about the floor, kicking and stamping upon it. The head of the dead man was shockingly cut and mangled. The maniac murderer was with difficulty secured, manifesting a savage determination to continue his work of violence, and shouting frantically his intention to "get the devil out of him." -- New Haven Palladium, June 1.

abstract: parochial, industrial and Sunday Schools connected with St. John's Chapel celebrated their customary St. Barnabas festival yesterday morning in St. John's Park, where the children, numbering about 2,000, received refreshments and amused themselves in moral sports. The feature of the morning was the drill of the Dix Cadets, a juvenile military company, composed of the boys of the parish school, and named in honor of Gen. DIX. Among those present were Rector DIX, of St. Paul's Church; Rev. Mr. WESTON, of St. John's and Chaplain of the Seventh Regiment, and other clergy of Trinity parish.

abstract: New-York, Fulton-street, No. 58,$80,000
snippet: New-York, Fulton-street, No. 58,$80,000
lead_paragraph: Shortly before three o'clock, yesterday morning, a fire broke out on the fourth floor of the six-story building, (brown-stone front,) No. 58 Fulton-street, in the premises occupied by J.H. HOLLINGSHEAD, electrotyper. The flames spread with great rapidily, and in a short time the iron doors of No. 60 Fulton-street were burned through. Owing to the height of the buildings, great difficulty was experienced by the firemen in getting the water on the flames at the right time and place. Four upper floors of Nos. 58 and 60 were entirely destroyed. From Fire Marshal BAKER, who was engaged yesterday, in investigating the matter, we learn that the fire originated in the electrotyping establishment, and is supposed to have been accidental.

abstract: The Boston Advertiser of Friday says: "That unexpected orders, caused probably by the increasing complication of affairs among the European Powers, were received on Thursday by Admiral LISSOFSKY, directing him to return to Cronstadt immediately with his fleet. He will probably sail from Boston direct on Thursday or Friday of this week. Capt. KRAEMER sailed for New-York on Friday with the Peresveit."

abstract: Advices from the front are that the enemy have recrossed the North Anna, and are again on the move in the direction, it is supposed, of our right. The enemy are said to have made an effort this morning to burn the bridge over the North Anna, on the telegraph road, but were foiled. There was some skirmishing this this morning, and also some between 10 and 12 o'clock last night.

abstract: -If this ill-fated vessel has ceased to be the subject of newspaper paragraphs, she continues to be a matter of interest to the wrecking company, who are still actively at work on her remains. As we understand from conversation with a gentleman who has spent some time near the scene of operations, the divers have recovered most of the goods which were scattered in the vicinity of the vessel, and are now at work getting package goods from the forward hold. The work is very difficult, as the goods have to be moved some distance before they can be taken to the hoisting tackle. Access to the hold can be had only at a particular stage of the tide, hence but little progress is made daily. -- Portland Advertiser, June 3.
lead_paragraph: -If this ill-fated vessel has ceased to be the subject of newspaper paragraphs, she continues to be a matter of interest to the wrecking company, who are still actively at work on her remains. abstract: most powerful hail-storm that has visited this section for years passed over the country a few miles north and east of this city yesterday afternoon. Hall-stones as large as a "small hen's egg" fell in large numbers. In East Windsor, taking the country for about three miles in width, north and south, in a direct line, the storm was furious. Huge drifts, reaching to the hub of a carriage wheel, were piled up with the frozen particles in different places. Grass, rye, tobacco and strawberry plants were totally destroyed, being crushed to the earth, great damage being done thereby to the crops. Window glasses were broken at an extensive rate. A pail full of the stones was picked up at 2:30 o'clock in the door-yard of JASON ELLSWORTH, and at 9 o'clock last evening they were brought into our office, and though decreased in size to a considerable extent, owing to the long time they had been kept, they were many of them larger than walnuts. At Vernon Center and Rockville the storm lasted for about two hours, doing a great deal of injury to property and crops. In the latter place, a correspondent says, "the damage done in immense. The window lights on the west and southwest side of the mills are almost all broken. The skylight on the Brooklyn block is completely demolished, as is the one on the old tavern of R.H. BILLS. One stone was found which measured seven inches in circumference! Numerous others, ranging from four to six inches in circumference, were found. The roads, which have been recently repaired, are gullied in some places to the depth of twelve inches." The extent of the storm is not known, though it reached seven miles south of here, and at Meriden large hall-stones fell for about half an hour. It has damaged property to the value of many thousand dollars, and the loss will be severely felt by farmers. -- Hartford Courant, June 2.

abstract: Army >amp; Navy Journal on Grant's Campaign
snippet: Army >amp; Navy Journal on Grant's Campaign
lead_paragraph: Two years and a few days ago the battles of Hanover Court-house and Fair Oaks were fought, the one a few miles in advance of the right flank of the present position of the Army of the Potomac, the other across the Chickahominy, not far from its present left front. Practically, the Army of the Potomac occupies to-day the same position that it did just previous to these two engagements. If any proof were at this late day needed of the inviolability of those general laws of military strategy which it was so much the fashion in the early periods of this war to [???]ry, it would be found in the fact that every campaign occurring within the comparatively limited [???]here of operations contended over by the Armies of the Potomac and of Northern Virginia, has of necessity taken routes nearly, if not precisely, similar and tending toward the same objective points.

lead_paragraph: The latest news from Gen. GRANT is up to three o'clock on Friday. In a dispatch dated at that time he gives the particulars of an assault made upon the enemy's lines on Friday morning, at 4:30 o'clock. The enemy were driven within their intrenchments at all points, and though the advantage gained was not decisive, yet our troops held all the ground they had gained. About three hundred prisoners were taken, mostly from BRECKINRIDGE's corps. Gen. GRANT says his loss was not severe, and he does not suppose the enemy to have lost heavily. Another official report, not from Gen. GRANT, estimates our loss in the battle at three thousand. Col. HASKELL, Thirty-sixth Wisconsin, Col. PORTER, Eighth New-York Heavy Artillery, and Col. MORRIS, Sixty-sixth New-York, were killed. Gen. R.O. TYLER was severely, and Col. BYRNES, of the Twenty-eighth Massachusetts, mortally wounded. Col. MCMAHON, of the One Hundred and Sixty-fourth New-York, and the heroic Col. BROOKE, of the Fifty-third Pennsylvania, were also wounded.

abstract: Our latest intelligence from New-Zealand is of considerable importance. The capture, by Gen. CAMERON, of the native strongholds on the Waipa has broken the backbone of Maorian power, if it has not quite crushed the revolt.
lead_paragraph: Our latest intelligence from New-Zealand is of considerable importance. The capture, by Gen. CAMERON, of the native strongholds on the Waipa has broken the backbone of Maorian power, if it has not quite crushed the revolt. These strongholds were of the most elaborate construction, and so formidable that they could not have been carried by assault without great sacrifice of life. Instead of attempting to storm them, therefore, the British commander determined to turn them, and on the evening of the 20th of February he set forth, at the head of about a thousand troops, to gain the rear of the Maori position. Unperceived and unopposed the detachment passed round the intrenchments, and when the natives saw the enemy in their rear they were filled with consternation, and decided to evacuate their strongholds, while evacuation was possible. This resolve was promptly executed, and on the following morning not a single human being was found in either. The Maories retired to a point only a few miles distant, where they defended themselves obstinately for a brief space, but ultimately abandoned that position also, and sought refuge in the hill country. Since then 150 of them, regarding their cause as hopeless, have laid down their arms, and returned to their allegiance. It is despair in fact, not any anticipation of triumph, that urges the Maories to prolong the conflict. Vanquished though they have been, and expect to be, they nevertheless prefer death on the battle-field to that unconditional submission, without which they cannot obtain peace. They have heard the cry of the colonists for confiscation, they have heard that 20,000 adventurers are to be settled on the lands of which they are to be stripped, and they dread to place themselves in the power of a merciless and unscrupulous enemy, lest their only source of subsistence should be wrung from them.
headline: {'main': 'The Anglo-Maorian War.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Anglo-Maorian War.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: People New-York vs. Allen et al.; New Tax Commissioners Confirmed
snippet: People New-York vs. Allen et al.; New Tax Commissioners Confirmed
lead_paragraph: The United States vs. Antonio James, J.R. Caseras, Rynear Moses, Edward H. Vickey, and J.D. Sheldon. -- The parties in this case were brought up for examination on the charge of obstructing the Enrolling Officers of the Seventh District in the discharge of their duties. The Enrolling Officer, it appears, called at a boarding-house, Nos. 106 and 108 East Fourteenth-street, and asked the lady of the house for the names of the inmates liable to do military duty. She replied that she did not know the full names of any of her boarders, but gave him their surnames. The officer left a blank to be filled up with the full names. On the next day he called again, and was informed that some of the gentlemen had not written their names on the paper; that some of them were absent; and that their christian names were unknown to her.

lead_paragraph: Last evening the citizens of New-York assembled in mass at Union-square, to raise their united voices in testimony of the nation's gratitude to Lieut.-Gen. GRANT, add to the armies of the Republic now under his command. Since the memorable April day when Sumter's fall aroused this City, no more unanimous or enthusiastic meeting has been held than the gathering last night. Long before the hour when speaking might be expected, the vicinity of the stands was occupied by a dense crowd of citizens who recreated themselves by cheering GRANT, President LINCOLN, Gen. MEADE, and the other gallant officers whose portraits or names appeared upon the banners and shields used as decorations.

abstract: World N. Y. and Tribune on Rebel Advances North
snippet: World N. Y. and Tribune on Rebel Advances North
lead_paragraph: The World has, for several months, kept its readers excited and hopeful, by a succession of announcements from a Southern correspondent, that large "columns" of Confederate troops were preparing for an invasion of the North on a grand scale. One "column" was to cross the Potomac into Pennsylvania, and another was to cross the Ohio into Ohio, and both were to lay waste and destroy in every direction. A correspondent of the Tribune has lately taken up the same tune, and menaces us with a sudden dash up the Shenandoah on the part of LEE, who is to invade the North and assail Washington with his whole force, leaving GRANT to twirl his thumbs in front of Richmond, and take it if he can or will. And there is very little doubt that a secret fear that something of this kind might happen, has haunted a good many people down to the commencement of the campaign, and still flits now and then across their excited fancy.

abstract: Plate Presentation by Hud-River Railroad
snippet: Plate Presentation by Hud-River Railroad
lead_paragraph: The Directors of the Hudson River Railroad, in January last, appointed Messrs, M.H. GRINNELL, WILLIAM KELLEY and LEONARD W. JEROME, a committee to prepare a service of plate for presentation to SAMUEL SLOAN, Esq., the President of the road, and appropriated the sum of $7,500 for the purpose. On the 25th of May the committee fulfilled its duty by presenting Mr. SLOAN the service of plate, accompanied by a letter expressing the high appreciation in which his valuable and important services to the road are held by the board, and adding that in their unanimous judgment it was mainly to his energy and fidelity and his judgment and ability that the improved condition and flattering prospects of the road are mainly due. In acknowledgment of this very handsome testimonial, Mr. SLOAN, a few evenings since, entertained the gentlemen of the board at a private dinner, at which the silver plate for the first time performed its appropriate part. It is very massive and very elegant, having been prepared by Messrs. TIFFANY & Co. expressly for the purpose. This compliment is eminently just and deserved. Mr. SLOAN has been indefatigable in his efforts to advance the interests and promote the prosperity of the Hudson River Road, and his endeavors have been crowned with conspicuous and remarkable success. He has decided practical ability, great tenacity of purpose, and complete devotion to whatever business he has on hand. These qualities, with a large experience, have made him one of the ablest and most successful railroad managers in the country.

abstract: Grant's Campaign
snippet: Grant's Campaign
lead_paragraph: We have two official dispatches concerning the operations of Friday last. At dawn on that day, GRANT assaulted the enemy's lines, drove them within their intrenchments at all points, but gained no decisive advantage. About dusk on the same day, the enemy returned the blow of the morning, by suddenly assaulting one of our brigades, which brought on a fight that lasted with great fury for half an hour, but the attack was unwaveringly repulsed. On the same evening our cavalry thwarted a scheme of the enemy, by driving a brigade of them from their rifle-pits in confusion, after a short but sharp conflict. During the night after these operations, the enemy drew in his left wing. The fighting in these various affairs must have been more severe than might appear to some readers of the dispatches; for the Adjutant-General reports the loss in killed, wounded and missing, during the three days' operations around Cold Harbor, at as high a number as seven thousand five hundred.

abstract: Texas Letter; On Necessity of Reelection; Texas Letter on Necessity of Reelecting President Lincoln
snippet: Texas Letter; On Necessity of Reelection; Texas Letter on Necessity of Reelecting President Lincoln
lead_paragraph: We publish this morning a brief letter, (which we know to be genuine,) from the interior of Texas, relative to the necessity of reelecting President LINCOLN. The writer declares that nothing would give the loyal men of the South so much satisfaction; and that nothing would more discourage rebels. This testimony from the very bosom of rebeldom, is but a corroboration of our argument, that the Union cause cannot have its complete vindication short of compelling the South to submit to the national authority, as exercised by the very man against whose constitutional election by the people they rebelled.

abstract: MORE RAISING OF SALARIES. -- The Common Council, of Brooklyn, having heretofore increased the salaries of all the City officials, at the special meeting on Friday night also added to the expenses of the Water Department, by raising the salaries of clerks and other employes from $100 to $500 each, per year. The appropriation in 1862, for this department was, $66,941 18, and the amount asked for the coming year was $215,000, a very long step in advance, but which is accounted for by a proposed expenditure of $100,000 for water meters. This item was stricken out, and the report of the Committee was adopted, leaving the amount actually appropriated $115,000, being an increase of $48,000.

abstract: THEY ARE CRUSHED BENEATH A FALLING SMOKESTACK, A most distressing accident occurred on Saturday afternoon on board the schooner Maria, lying alongside the revenue cutter Kankakee, at the foot of Horatio-street, North River.
lead_paragraph: THEY ARE CRUSHED BENEATH A FALLING SMOKESTACK, A most distressing accident occurred on Saturday afternoon on board the schooner Maria, lying alongside the revenue cutter Kankakee, at the foot of Horatio-street, North River. It appears that the cutter was receiving her machinery on board, and that the smokestack was being hoisted in, when the supports gave way and precipitated it over the side of the vessel on to the deck of the schooner. Capt. ZENO C. BAKER and a deck hand, named JOHN DUNN, were crushed beneath the smokestack and instantly killed. Some other parties were more or less injured. An inquest was held on the bodies of deceased yesterday by Coroner RANNEY, from which it appears that while the smokestack was being put in place, the steamer Mary Powell passed, the waves from her making such a commotion as to cause the supports to give way. The evidence of two witnesses only were taken. These were Mr. JOHN GREY, the contractor for furnishing the machinery to the Kankakee, and Mr. LUTHER C. BAKER, brother to one of the deceased. Their evidence showed the occurrence to be accidental, and the jury rendered a verdict "that deceased came to his death from injuries received from the accidental falling of a smokestack on board the revenue cutter Kankakee, June 1, 1864, at the foot of Horatio-street, North River; further, we recommend that six guys be used in all cases of this kind, in lieu of four, as has been common heretofore."

abstract: By the arrival of the Ocean Queen, yesterday, we have interesting advices from Panama to the 27th ult. The Spanish agents had begun to show alarm at the warlike attitude of the South American States, and the proposed fillibustering attempt upon the Chincha Islands has received a decided check. In the southern department  of the Republic a large volunteer force
lead_paragraph: By the arrival of the Ocean Queen, yesterday, we have interesting advices from Panama to the 27th ult. The Spanish agents had begun to show alarm at the warlike attitude of the South American States, and the proposed fillibustering attempt upon the Chincha Islands has received a decided check. In the southern department of the Republic a large volunteer force is being rapidly organized. At Panama Senor SALAZAR Y MAZARREDO, who was returning in disgust from his mission to Peru, was mobbed, but by the assistance of the French Consul, managed to make his escape on board the steamer Tamar, bound for Southampton. Demonstrations were also made against the Consul. On the passage out a mutiny occurred on board the Ocean Queen. The sailors on board, for the relief of the flagship Lancaster's crew, showed signs of disorder and an intention to take possession of the ship. Capt. AMMEN, who was in charge of the men, fired upon them, killing two; five of the ringleaders were put in irons and order restored. The men in irons were afterward put on board the gunboat Neptune.

abstract: Roman Catholic Hierarchy and Emigration; on Emigration and the War
snippet: Roman Catholic Hierarchy and Emigration; on Emigration and the War
lead_paragraph: The rush of Irish emigration to the United States has begun to alarm the Hierarchy, and an admonitory appeal has been addressed to the Catholic Bishops in Ireland by a right reverend prelate who has long resided on this side of the Atlantic. The prelate in question, Bishop LYNCH, now of Toronto, was formerly the incumbent of a Roman Catholic Church in Buffalo, and has enjoyed rare opportunities for ascertaining the fate which awaits his emigrant countrymen and countrywomen on their arrival in the United States. His testimony, therefore, ought to be of no inconsiderable value.

abstract: In the Senate, Saturday, the House bill to provide for the payment of the Second Regiment, Third Brigade, Ohio Volunteer Militia, for the time they were actually in the service, without regard to irregularity in the muster, was passed.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, Saturday, the House bill to provide for the payment of the Second Regiment, Third Brigade, Ohio Volunteer Militia, for the time they were actually in the service, without regard to irregularity in the muster, was passed. The bill to extend, for five years, the time for the reversion to the United States of lands granted by Congress to aid in the construction of a railroad from Per Marquette to Flint, &c., was passed. The bill to pay Wisconsin her five per cent. on the reserved public lands in her borders, coming up as unfinished business, was dismissed. The consideration of the Tax Bill was then resumed, and continued until the House adjoured.

abstract: The latest intelligence from Gen. GRANT comes down to 8:30 o'clock on Saturday night, and furnishes a consecutive narrative up to that time of the main events of the struggle from the hour of his previous report (3 o'clock on Friday.)
lead_paragraph: The latest intelligence from Gen. GRANT comes down to 8:30 o'clock on Saturday night, and furnishes a consecutive narrative up to that time of the main events of the struggle from the hour of his previous report (3 o'clock on Friday.) There appears to have been a lull in the conflict from 3 o'clock on Friday up to nightfall of the same day. At 7 o'clock P.M., the rebels made a dash at SMITH's brigade, GIBBON's division, and the battle raged for an hour with the utmost fury. The attack was gallantly repulsed. A force of our cavalry, under WILSON, the same evening, (Friday,) fell upon a rebel brigade, which LEE had thrown round to his left, for the evident purpose of enveloping BURNSIDE. WILSON drove them from their rifle-pits, but at some considerable sacrifice, Col. PRESTON, of the First Vermont Cavalry, being killed, and Col. BENJAMIN, of the Eighth New-York Cavalry, having been wounded. The dispatch also mentions the wounding of Gen. STANNARD, of the Eighteenth Corps. Gen. GRANT estimates his losses since he crossed the Pamunky at 7,500. On Saturday morning the enemy was found to have drawn in his left wing, which is in front of BURNSIDE. Gen. GRANT had received a reinforcement of 5,000 men, by way of Port Royal, on the Rappahannock, on Saturday. The telegraphic communications with the army, by way of Cherrystone and Fortress Monroe, are uninterrupted.

abstract: The House yesterday passed the Tariff Bill, after making numerous minor amendments. There was a decided disposition manifested to hurry it through. Many members wishing to go to Baltimore to-mor- row, but little business will be transacted in the House till after the convention, which is absorbing all interest now.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Sunday, June 5.

abstract: HUDSON COUNTY COURT -- SENTENCE OF PRISONERS. - - In the Hudson County Court, Judge OGDEN pronounced the following sentences on Saturday: James Elliott, convicted on two indictments for prize-fighting, was sentenced to two years in State Prison on each indictment, the terms to run together -- and he was also fined in the sum of $200; Thomas Lee, for grand larceny, was sent to the State Prison one year; John Schomaden, for assault and battery, was fined $5 and costs; Wm. McMullen, Thomas Morton and James Rodgers, convicted of burglary, were sent to State Prison three years each; Ann Sullivan, grand larceny, County Jail thirty days; Wm. Irving, highway robbery, State Prison two years; Jacob Ritgers, petty larceny, $5 and costs; Mary Delaney, sixty days; Peter Welden, thirty days; Thos. W. Johnson, twenty days; Patrick McGown, fifteen days; Francis Narriott, ten days each to the County Jail, for petty larceny; Martin Fennell, fornication, fined $14 and costs; John Short, bigamy, State Prison three years.

abstract: The steamer Missouri, from New-Orleans 30th, has arrived. She was fired into at Columbia by a baiteey. Sixty shots were fired at her, eight of which struck. One shell exploded in the nursery cabin, wounding a lady in the foot. No other person was wounded.

abstract: Malakoff, The Duke of
snippet: Malakoff, The Duke of
lead_paragraph: By the European arrivals yesterday, we have intelligence of the death of the Duke of Malakoff, more widely known as General and Marshai PELLISSIER, the Commander-in-Chief of the French army in the siege of Sebastopol. Marshal PELISSIER was in his 70th year at the time of his death, having been born near Rouen, in 1794. After completing his military studies at St. Cyr, he was gazetted a Sal-Lieutenant in 1815. Subsequently he saw service in Spain in 1823, achieved the rank of Captain in 1828, served in Greece and afterward in Algeria up to 1832, when he returned to France for the recruitment of his health. In 1839 he returned to Algeria, where he remained in active service for a period of 16 years, and it was during this period of his career that his name was first given to the world, and in a character which was long regarded as infamous. A viciously hostile tribe of Arabs made themselves conspicuous in their resistance to French authority during the insurrection of 1845. Occupying mountain fastnesses almost impenetrable to the foreign soldier, these tribes were enabled for a long time to harrass the French troops, and to openly defy effective chastisement in return. An expedient -- of which it is not known whether PILLISSIER was the actual author -- was devised to smoke the Arabs out of their caves, or burn them alive in their retreats if they refused to surrender. Defiance was the only answer of the mountain chiefs to the threat of the French commanding officer, although it is said a large portion of the mountain warriors were willing to surrender. Be this as it may, their delay in listening to the summons determined their fate. PELLESSIER ordered the faggots to be applied to the mouths of the Cauerus, and 600 of the wretched Arabs were thus consigned to a horrible and barbarous death. Various have been the palliations offered for the act, and it may be hoped there were reasons for it sufficient to relieve the perpetrators, at least, of the charge of wanton murder. The act was condemned by the French Minister of War. PELISSIER, however, was not removed from his post in Algeria, but remained there till after the outbreak of the Crimean war, when he was appointed second in command to Gen. CANROBERT. On the 19th of May, 1855, he became Commander-in-Chief of the French force in the Crimea, and his successful storming of the Malakoff, led to the evacuation of the main Sebastopol forts be the Russians, and ultimately to negotiations which ended in peace. Gen. PELESSIER became a Marshal of France and Duke of Malakoff, with a high pension, as the reward of his services, by his own government. At the hands of her Britanic Majesty he received the decoration of a Knight's Grand Cross; and was subsequently for a short time Minister to England in 1858.

abstract: The news from Gen. GRANT is up to yesterday. There was only skirmishing on Saturday, and no fighting on Sunday. Gen. GRANT says everything was going on well. Our forces still occupy their position within a few yards of the rebel lines, which were taken and retaken an rapidly on Friday morning. At Bottom's Bridge the...
lead_paragraph: The news from Gen. GRANT is up to yesterday. There was only skirmishing on Saturday, and no fighting on Sunday. Gen. GRANT says everything was going on well. Our forces still occupy their position within a few yards of the rebel lines, which were taken and retaken an rapidly on Friday morning. At Bottom's Bridge the rebels appeared to be fortifying on both sides of the river. We give from our special correspondent, this morning, full and thrilling details of the severe battle of Friday.

abstract: Of all diseases there is none more prevalent, deleterions, and yet more neglected than Catarrh. It is truly surprising that of a disease so prevalent, and exercising such perbicious effects on the system, so ...
lead_paragraph: Of all diseases there is none more prevalent, deleterions, and yet more neglected than Catarrh. New realize the fatal consequences of neglecting it, and consequently are not cognizant of how many diseases to which it is inducive. It is truly surprising that of a disease so prevalent, and exercising such perbicious effects on the system, so little should be known by both professional and d non-professional. It is much to be regretted that the Medical Faculty should have paid so little attention to it, or otherwise much suffering, and undoubtedly many might have been saved from a premature grave. But, nevertheless, it is a fact that cannot be denied, hundreds, yes, thousand being living witnesses to this fact, and how many that are [???]e none can tell. In consequence of their total ignorance of it, and exerting themselves, in no way to gain more information on the subject, hundreds of n[???]s[???]rums, in the shape of s[???]uffs, have sprung up like mushrooms, as the [???]anaced for the disease in all its stages; and worse than this these every snuffs have been recommended by physicians. Not willing to admit their ignorance of the disease the patient is dismissed when applying for aid with the answer that "Catarrh can never be cured." Try a little snuff, says one: a little tine salt and sugar, says another; snuff up a little cold water, says a third. If these remedies are not prescribed, it is either neuralgia or the effects of a cold, which will soon wear away. Ala[???] how many there are that wear away before the cold do[???]. Being a regular Physician myself, and at one time a general practitioner, nothing disrespectful is intended to the general practitioner, as feeling that their services are but too little appreciated, it would be foreign to my object to wish to make the slightest imputation; but in a work like this, where the health, comfort and even lives of thousands are at stake, it is not only impossible to avoid, but absolutely necessary to criticise, even though it be harshly. It will be seen from this that really nothing that could be beneficial has been done. Consequently there are many that believe that the disease can never be cured; added to which, their having been told by those in whom they naturally placed confidence, that "Catarrh can never be cured," has tended to make them more positive in their opinions. It must be remembered by such that this is a progressive age. Science has made, and is making, gigantic strides. Many things that could not be done when they were boys, and which, had one hinted of being ultimately done, would have brought down the ridicule of these before whom he should have been so foolhardy as to venture the assertion, have been accomplished. The sciences of both medicine and surgery have not been behind hand, but have kept pace with the other branches of science. How many operations in by-gone times, now performed with facility and success, were then looked on as not only impracticable, but absolutely impossible. Why, then, may I not ask, should not more have been learned of Catarrh, and an effectual method of treating it.

abstract: On the 27th of May the Discount market exhibited symptoms of increasing ease, the applications at the Bank being few and unimportant. The Confederate Loan recovered 1 cent. on the receipt of the Scotia's advices.

abstract: The Board of Aldermen met yesterday. A resolution providing for a celebration of the ensuing 6th of July, with an appropriation in blank, was introduced and laid over. The Comptroller reported a balance of $1,950,932 49 in the city Treasury on last Saturday. The Board concurred to give a stand of colors to the Ninety-third Regiment, N.Y.S.N.G. Beyond this the proceedings were uninteresting. The Board adjourned to 12 M. on next Monday.
lead_paragraph: The Board of Aldermen met yesterday. A resolution providing for a celebration of the ensuing 6th of July, with an appropriation in blank, was introduced and laid over. The Comptroller reported a balance of $1,950,932 49 in the city Treasury on last Saturday. The Board concurred to give a stand of colors to the Ninety-third Regiment, N.Y.S.N.G. Beyond this the proceedings were uninteresting. The Board adjourned to 12 M. on next Monday.

abstract: By three arrivals we have English and European news one week later. The steamship Virginia, which sailed from Liverpool on the 24th of May and Queenstown on the 25th, and the Etna, (of the Inman line,) which left Liverpool on the 25th and Queenstown on the 26th, arrived at this port yesterday. The China, (of the Cunard line,) ...
lead_paragraph: By three arrivals we have English and European news one week later. The steamship Virginia, which sailed from Liverpool on the 24th of May and Queenstown on the 25th, and the Etna, (of the Inman line,) which left Liverpool on the 25th and Queenstown on the 26th, arrived at this port yesterday. The China, (of the Cunard line,) which appears to have taken the place of the Europa, reached Halifax late on Sunday night, one week out from Queenstown, thus bringing the news down to the 29th of May. The news of the great battles of the Wilderness and Spottsylvania had created a most profound sensation, especially in England, as will be seen from the comments of the London Times, which we publish elsewhere. The qualities of Gen. GRANT as a commander are the subject of high eulogium even in the Anglo-rebel papers. The privateer Georgia is announced for sale at Liverpool by private treaty. The pirates of the J.G. Gerity were before the Court of Queen's Bench on a writ of habeas corpus, and were discharged -- the Chief Justice, however, dissenting from the majority of the Court. The news which was carried to Europe by the City of Washington respecting the progress of the campaign, was generally regarded as exceedingly disastrous to the rebel cause, and the rebel cotton loan had declined, thereupon, from 5 to 6 cent. The British ministry have taken a practical way of getting at the bottom of the difficulty respecting LAIRD's rebel rams: they have been purchased on Government account. It is not stated whether the executors of the late Pasha of Egypt or LAIRD himself gets the purchase money. The Derby was won by Blair Athole, Gen. Peel, second, and Scottish Chief, third. The Dano-German Conference had been holding intermittent sessions, but had come to no definite decision on the question. Various unofficial reports are given. Among others, that the British Government had agreed to a plebiscite in Schleswig. This is improbable. Lord RUSSELL had made the important announcement in the House of Lords that the Queen was no wise an obstacle in the way of giving effect to the Government policy, but cheerfully followed the advice of her responsible ministers. The Emperor and Empress of the French were about to pay a visit to the King of Prussia. The Pope continues seriously ill. The death of the Duke of Malakoff is announced. We publish an obituary notice of the late Marshal in another column.

abstract: Grant's Campaign. Battle of the Chickahominy
snippet: Grant's Campaign. Battle of the Chickahominy
lead_paragraph: The battle of Friday last was a much more serious affair, both in its original conception, its actual character, and its final consequences, than we had been led to believe from the brief dispatches heretofore given to the public. The intention really was that it should be the decisive battle of the campaign. The movements of the preceding days, culminating in the possession of Cold Harbor -- an important strategic point -- had drawn our lines close in front of the Chickahominy, and reduced the military problem to the forcing of the passage of that river -- a problem which, if solved in our favor, would decide whether Richmond could be carried by a coup de main, if a decisive victory should attend our arms, or, whether operations would settle down to a siege in form. The great struggle did not result in a success; and though the enemy's lines were carried and temporarily held at two important points, our assaulting columns were finally compelled to abandon them. Probably no action so important in its character was ever crowded into so brief a space of time -- ten terrible minutes in the early dawn developed on the part of the enemy such strength both of position and force as to carry conviction that any victory that could here be achieved would be purchased at too great a cost.
headline: {'main': "Friday's Battle.", 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': "Friday's Battle.", 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: His Acceptance of the Nomination for President
snippet: His Acceptance of the Nomination for President
lead_paragraph: Of course FREMONT accepts. He laid the plot on purpose to accept. His griefs would run to seed if he did not accept. His "whole charge of ancients, corporals, lieutenants, gentlemen of companies, discarded unjust serving men, revolted tapsters," would all go to the dogs if he didn't accept. It is plainly enough now but an ill venture; yet, being in so far, there was no alternative but to stand to it.

abstract: Danish War Losses
snippet: Danish War Losses
lead_paragraph: It is doubtful whether the losses suffered by the Danish army since the outbreak of the war with Germany, have ever been paralleled -- looking at the strength of the army when it accepted the gauge thrown down to it. The estimates are various as to the numbers of the Danish force, including the volunteers that have taken up arms in defence of the independence of the country. But the regularly disciplined force of the Kingdom -- the army proper -- does not appear to have exceeded 35,000 at the commencement of hostilities. The official reports, then, show that half this force has disappeared in the bloody conflicts, from Flensburg to Duppel and Viele. In short, the Danes have lost 16,473 men, including 300 officers, besides 467 guns. The continuance of the unequal war at such a sacrifice can not surely be permitted by the intervening Powers.

abstract: -A grand complimentary benefit was given last evening at Stuyvesant Institute, to Mr. J.W. WHITNEY, a gentleman well and favorably known in the sporting circles of this City. At an early hour the hall was filled. After some good singing, and a jig dance, by MICKEY WARREN, Mr. HARRY HILL displayed his remarkable proficiences in the use of the Indian Clubs. Mr. GEORGE C. DOBSON, the celebrated banjoist, then gave an exhibition of his skill in the use of that instrument, his performance was very excellent and was heartily applauded. Mr. MCMAHON, of Brooklyn, and several other professors of the manly art of self-defence, then put on the gloves and engaged in a friendly set-to. In the final one between Mr. J.W. WHITNEY and Mr. THOMAS CORNELL, both gentlemen showed such a perfect knowledge of the art and such command of themselves as to deserve and bring forth the strong and hearty plaudits of the audience. The affair was a perfect success.

abstract: The old but still youthful romantic and spectacular drama of "Aladdin, or the Wonderful Lamp," was revived here last night; not the burlesque, be it understood, but the genuine Arabian story, with all its bathos and beautiful visions of fairy land as of old -- a spectacle recalling youth and the rosy paths of juvenile reading. The piece is intended, we suppose, to run through the Summer season. No other justification can be offered for the lavish way in which it has been placed upon the stage. The dialogue is not interesting; the situations are not what they might be under the new sensation dispensation; but the story is preserved in a familiar way, and the gladness of boyhood comes back to us in hearing it told anew. We have no recollection of ever having seen "Aladdin" more beautifully put on the stage. From the first scene to the last (which did not work) it was a charming vision of Eastern land. The costumes were rich, appropriate and correct. When we have said this we have exhausted the subject. The acting was of course all that could be desired, Mrs. JOHN WOOD and her company being infinitely superior to any requirements that may be made upon them in such a work. It must be noticed, however, that at least one of the leading artists was not perfect in her text, and, in fact, incurred the ridicule of the gallery by seeming to need the vociferous hints of the prompter. The stage carpenters, too, were dilatory in their business, and caused delays, which were resented in the usual way. Owing to these untoward circumstances -- which will undoubtedly be remedied to-night -- we are unable to record the verdict of the house, but we are disposed to regard "Aladdin" as a work which will gain steadily in favor, and on the positive merits of its scenery and dresses, become the rage.
lead_paragraph: The old but still youthful romantic and spectacular drama of "Aladdin, or the Wonderful Lamp," was revived here last night; not the burlesque, be it understood, but the genuine Arabian story, with all its bathos and beautiful visions of fairy land as of old -- a spectacle recalling youth and the rosy paths of juvenile reading. The piece is intended, we suppose, to run through the Summer season. No other justification can be offered for the lavish way in which it has been placed upon the stage. The dialogue is not interesting; the situations are not what they might be under the new sensation dispensation; but the story is preserved in a familiar way, and the gladness of boyhood comes back to us in hearing it told anew. We have no recollection of ever having seen "Aladdin" more beautifully put on the stage. From the first scene to the last (which did not work) it was a charming vision of Eastern land. The costumes were rich, appropriate and correct. When we have said this we have exhausted the subject. The acting was of course all that could be desired, Mrs. JOHN WOOD and her company being infinitely superior to any requirements that may be made upon them in such a work. It must be noticed, however, that at least one of the leading artists was not perfect in her text, and, in fact, incurred the ridicule of the gallery by seeming to need the vociferous hints of the prompter. The stage carpenters, too, were dilatory in their business, and caused delays, which were resented in the usual way. Owing to these untoward circumstances -- which will undoubtedly be remedied to-night -- we are unable to record the verdict of the house, but we are disposed to regard "Aladdin" as a work which will gain steadily in favor, and on the positive merits of its scenery and dresses, become the rage.

abstract: on Reconstruction and the Negro
snippet: on Reconstruction and the Negro
lead_paragraph: One of the strongest arguments against Slavery, and that of which the Anti-Slavery party in this country made most use, was the degradation into which it plunged the colored race at the South. Under it the negro was as like a beast of the field as it was in the power of law and usage to make him. There was in every Southern State a code of regulations ingeniously framed for the express and avowed purpose of extinguishing in him, as far as possible, all the hopes, wants, aspirations and anxieties of a human being. Education of every kind was carefully withheld from him; all sense of self-respect was beaten out of him by the cowhide, and in order to remove all trace of connection between the slave and the rest of the human family, he was not allowed to contract a binding marriage. Of the efficiency of these measures we are unhappily not permitted to doubt. It is proved by the testimony of everybody who has examined the condition of the Southern slaves, and this testimony derives the strongest kind of corroboration from the attributes of the negroes themselves. Their marvellous quiescence for so many generations under the most horrible wrongs that man could inflict on his fellow, is, in itself, proof enough that Slavery had corrupted the soul as well as degraded the body. And even if we had been disposed to overlook these facts, the Abolitionists took good care not to let us. They kept them before us. They proved the wickedness of Slavery, in short, mainly by its consequences. Their strongest appeal to the national justice and pity was based on the success of the slave code in accomplishing the objects of its framers.

abstract: It is semi-officially announced that Secretary WELLES will, next week, leave the National Capital on his annual tour of the different navy-yards. He will first visit New-York, then Philadelphia, Boston, Portsmouth, N.H., and perhaps New-London, which is pretty generally believed to be the site for the new navy-yard.
lead_paragraph: It is semi-officially announced that Secretary WELLES will, next week, leave the National Capital on his annual tour of the different navy-yards. He will first visit New-York, then Philadelphia, Boston, Portsmouth, N.H., and perhaps New-London, which is pretty generally believed to be the site for the new navy-yard. It is hinted that Admiral PAULDING is about to suggest to him a considerable enlargement of the anchorage at the New-York Yard.

abstract: -- We have lost a very large number of most valuable officers of all grades in the present campaign. We refer not only to general officers, but to colonels, lieutenant-colonels, majors, captains. The proportion of officers who have fallen to the entire loss has been greater than in any previous campaign. The principal reason of this has been the nature of the actions. They have been, to a great extent, of the character of assaults upon the enemy's fortified positions; and in these assaults and charges the officers dismount and lead their men forward, and are, of course, special and prominent targets for the enemy.

abstract: The National Union Convention met at Baltimore yesterday, and effected a speedy organization by appointing Dr. R.J. BRECKINRIDGE of Kentucky, temporary President, who was succeeded by Ex Gov. DENNISON, of Ohio, as permanent President. The permanent organization was perfected last evening, but the Committees on Credentials and Resolutions not being ready to report, the convention adjourned until 9 o'clock this morning. During the sittings yesterday, highly patriotic speeches were made by Dr. BRECKINRIDGE, Senator MORGAN, Gov. DENNISON and Parson BROWNLOW.

abstract: New-York Grand Lodge, Annual Meeting
snippet: New-York Grand Lodge, Annual Meeting
lead_paragraph: The eightieth annual communication of the Grand Lodge of Free and Accepted Masons of the State of New-York, commenced its session, yesterday afternoon at 2 o'clock, in the City Assembly Rooms. The attendance was unusually large, the vast hall being densely crowded. The jewels, implements and emblems of the Grand Lodge were covered with crape, in honor to the memory of the Deputy Grand Master, who died in November last. M.W.G.M. CLINTON F. PAIGE presided in the East, the remaining grand officers occupying their respective positions. The lodge was called to order at 2 o'clock precisely, and after prayer by R.W. Bro. C.W. SCHOONMAKER, Grand Chaplain, the Grand Lodge was opened in ample form. The Grand Master then delivered a very able address, in which he congratulated the craft on the vast masonic improvement made during the past year. He paid a fervent tribute to the memories of the officers of the Grand Lodge who had died since their last gathering, and submitted a number of decisions made by him on questions of masonic jurisprudence. On motion the report was referred to a committee of three, consisting of R.W. JOSEPH B. CHAFFEE, STEPHEN H. JOHNSON and W.N. IRISH for apportionment to appropriate committees.

abstract: An exhibition of the works of art contributed to the Metropolitan Fair by foreign artists, which failed to arrive in season, will be opened to the public to-day at the Dusseldorf Gallery, No. 548 Broadway. The exhibition will continue one week, when the paintings and other works of art will be sold at auction on Wednesday and Thursday evenings, June 15 and 16. The collection consists of oil paintings (some of which are of American and patriotic subjects, painted expressly for the purpose,) elaborate water-color drawings; sketches in oil, water-color, crayon and pencil; also, numerous fine photographs, from pictures and drawings, with the autographs of the artists; fine engravings, and various albums, filled with drawings, engravings, portraits and autographs, all contributed by celebrated artists, among whose names may be mentioned those of Carl Hubner, O. Achenbach, C. Becker, L. Knaus, Hildebrandt, J.W. Pr[???]yer, C. Sohn, R. Jordan, Kindler, Lachenwitz, Hiddemann, Schlessinger, Hoff, Meyer, of Bremen; Ed. Frere, Duverger, Salentin, Seigert, Geselchap, Herzog, Schmitz, Taft, Sondermann, Bellange, Cretins, Schrader, Meverheim, Mintrop, Hamman, &c.

abstract: The annual session of the American Medical Association was commenced yesterday, in Irving Hall. There were present a large number of prominent physicians from this and other States. The convention was called to order by Dr. ALLEN MARSH. Prayer was offered by Rev. Dr. DE WITT, after which the report of the committee of arrangements was read by the chairman, Dr. ANDERSON. The report explained the objects of the Association, and referred to the recent establishment of St. Luke's Hospital, on Fifth-avenue, and other similar institutions. On the conclusion of the reading the report was unanimously adopted. A very able address was delivered by Dr. MARSH, the out-going President. An election of officers took place in the afternoon. A report on the practical working of the United States Drug Law was read by Dr. E.R. SQUIBB, and a report on American Medical Necrology, by Dr. C.C. COX. The following papers will be read:

abstract: The latest intelligence from the Army of the Potomac is up to Tuesday morning, at 9 o'clock. There had been considerable fighting on Saturday and Sunday, especially at night. The rebels had made three assaults on our lines -- one on Saturday, one on Sunday, and one on Monday -- all at night, but in each case met with a bloody repulse. On Sunday evening they took advantage of a prevailing mist, and assaulted our left, under HANCOCK. They were met at close range by our troops, and literally slaughtered. On Monday a hundred picked men made a rush upon a working party in HANCOCK's siege lines, of whom nine were captured, and nearly all the rest were killed or wounded. At midnight of Monday the rebels made an assault on BURNSIDE, and were severely repulsed. Letters had passed between Gen. GRANT and Gen. LEE with reference to the dead and wounded lying between the lines of the two armies. They were collected, the dead buried, and the wounded taken care of by the respective armies. Gen. GRANT is evidently laying siege to LEE's lines in his present position.

abstract: In the Senate yesterday, Mr. SUMNER presented numerous petitions from different States, asking for the abolishment of Slavery by Congress. They were referred to the Committee on Slavery and Freedmen. Mr. GRIMES reported back the bill outhorizing the Levy Court of the County of Washington, D.C., to levy a direct tax upon the people of the county for their portion or the Government tax under the Act of Congress of July, 1861, without amendment. The Committee on Foreign Relations reported favorably on the bill respecting Consular jurisdiction over crews of vessels of foreign nations in waters and ports of the United States. The bills granting lands to Montana and Dacotah were postponed until next December. The bill relative to increase of duties on imports was postponed. The bill to pay for the publication of the debates of Congress was made the special order for Tuesday. The bill to establish a Bureau of Freedman's Affairs was called up, but without considering it, the Senate went into Executive session and afterward adjourned.

abstract: WELLACK's THEATRE. -- To-morrow evening will be performed, for the benefit of Mr. THEODORE MOSS, the very obliging and efficient Treasurer of this theatre, "ERNESTINE," for the first time this season, and "A Pretty Piece of Business," never before acted here. Mr. Moss is so well and favorably known to all the theatre-goers of this City, this nothing can be said to add to his popularity, and the simple announcement that he is to have a benefit, will doubtless fill the house to its utmost. The services he rendered in systematizing and superintending the sale of tickets at the great Metropolitan Fair were almost invaluable, and the public will, doubtless, take this occasion to manifest their appreciation of them.

abstract: We overtook the rebels in force on the afternoon of the 25th, four miles south of Pumpkin-vine Creek. They were in heavy force, and occupied strong positions on the western spur of Allatoona hills. Gen. HOOKER led the attack against the rebels, driving them over two miles into their log breastworks, himself suffering considerably.

abstract: The, its Deeds and Honors
snippet: The, its Deeds and Honors
lead_paragraph: No words can fully express the gratitude which the people owe to the Army of the Potomac. For nearly forty days and nights, now, it has either been fighting every day or performing difficult and hurried marches, or countermarching to execute some required manoeuvre. Its nights have often been spent in battle, or in making some sudden movement to circumvent the enemy. It has borne heat, and dust, and wet, sleeping on the ground and without change of garments, enduring the most incessant fatigues ever borne by any army. The armies of other nations, as the London Times well remarks, become exhausted after one or two days' battle, but this army has fought and marched for over a month without overpowering weariness, or despondency, or exhaustion. No murmur or complaint has arisen from them; on the contrary, a trustworthy correspondent describes them as more cheerful and more determined now than at the outset. During this fearful month they have sent home thirty thousand of their number with honorable wounds -- five thousand have been buried in the soil over which they have marched. Their most favorite corps commander, the experienced SEDGWICK, has been killed, with the heroic WADSWORTH and RICE, and hundreds of other brave officers, well known and long tried in the history of this army. Such fighting as they have done, as the English journals confess, has not been seen in the history of the world. Their courage, their endurance and their fortitude have shed a new lustre on the American name. For, as the rebel journals have rightly divined, the Army of the Potomac is made up to a large degree of native Americans. The very best young men of the community, representing all possible grades and ranks and professions of society, some the heirs of old families, some scholars and graduates of the professions, others mechanics and laborers and artisans; still others, the larger number in the army, coming from the most vigorous class of the whole country, the intelligent farming population. They are men who do not fight for the mere love of fighting, who have not joined the army for the paltry wages they could earn, but they are those who understand the tremendous issues at stake. They know that this is a life and death struggle for a contitinent between Freedom and Slavery. They understand how momentous every battle is, and they struggle and endure as men do who contend for a great cause, affecting distant times. They and their great leader represent the two best qualities of the American character -- its tenacity and its hopefulness.

abstract: Competitive Examinations
snippet: Competitive Examinations
lead_paragraph: The importance of admitting cadets to the Military Academy only by open competitive examinations, is clearly proved by the history of the present graduating class. It entered with ninety-six members, and now numbers only twenty-seven. It is not usual for more than fifty per cent. to graduate. Favoritism and patronage have crowded many into the Academy who were utterly wanting in all aptitude for military studies or duties. With proper care in the selection of candidates, the per centage of graduates would be ninety. Competitive examination has long been the mode of admission in all the great military schools of Europe. "Reward and encourage merit," was a favorite maxim of NAPOLEON. This year an unusual number of members of Congress have adopted this plan, and invited all candidates from their several districts to appear before a competent and impartial committee, and the result is the selection of young men of a higher order of talent and culture. Cadet LYDECKER, who is at the head of the graduating class, was appointed in this way by Gen. SICKLES. The examination of this class closed on Monday last. The class oration was given by B.G. NORTHRUP, Esq., agent of the Massachusetts Board of Education. The examination of the other classes continues through this week, with very attractive military drills every afternoon, consisting of squadron and troopers' drills, target practice with light and heavy ordnance, flying artillery, mortar practice, use of howitzers, &c. The Board of Visitors consists of thirteen gentlemen, including one representative each from Oregon, Minnesota, Tennessee, Kentucky and Missouri.

lead_paragraph: The news from Gen. GRANT is up to Tuesday afternoon, at 3 o'clock. No further fighting is reported. Considerable changes in our lines had occurred, but they are not proper for immediate Publication. The wounded had nearly all been sent so the rear. Communication between Gen. GRANT and Gen. BUTLER had been effected by way of the James and Chickahominy Rivers, and thence overland to Cold Harbor. A report from Washington, to the effect that LEE had retired to the south side of the Chickahominy on Tuesday, is hardly creditable.

lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, the bill to enable the trustees to perfect the title to the lands of the Blue Mound College was passed. The Committee on Naval Affairs reported frvorably on the bill for the sale of the Chicago Marine Hospital. Mr. DAVIS read a letter from Gen. BUTLER in reply to a resolution offered by him some time before. Mr. DAVIS said the letter was in such terms as a man conscious of his innocence would use. Action in the matter was, however posponed. The bill to amend the act concerning certain private land claims in New Mexico, was passed. The bill respecting Consular jurisdiction over the crews of foreign vessels in American waters, was passed. A motion was made to take up the bill prohibiting military interference in elections, but the motion was disagreed to. The House Bill to establish a Bureau of Freedmens' Affairs, and after some remarks by Mr. SUMNER and Mr. RICHARDSON, the further consideration of the bill was postponed until Thursday. The bill for the repeal of the Commutation clause was called up and argued at length, but without taking action in the matter the Senate adjourned.
