abstract: The settlement of the controversy about Mr. LAIRD's steam-rams, by their purchase by the British Government, seems to have been a source of great satisfaction in England, and will be such in this country as well. It is practically a defeat of the rebels, not only in ...
lead_paragraph: The settlement of the controversy about Mr. LAIRD's steam-rams, by their purchase by the British Government, seems to have been a source of great satisfaction in England, and will be such in this country as well. It is practically a defeat of the rebels, not only in depriving them of a chance of having on the sea vessels with which they might, perhaps, even venture to attack our blockading fleets, but in preventing what they have striven most assiduously to bring about, viz.: a collision between our country and England. There can be no doubt that the wisest men in both countries felt that there was possible danger that such a collision might spring out of some such cause. We, therefore, are very ready to rejoice over the result of this "unpleasant and complicated affair." It is an indication to us that the English Government is really desirous of performing the obligations of that neutral position which they assumed. It seems also to indicate a feeling among the sympathizers with the rebellion in England, that their hopes for its success are vain. If they had sufficient confidence in being able to get the rams to sea in time to be of any material service to the rebels, they would hardly have consented to abandon their undertaking at this stage. But possibly the news of GRANT's onward march, and the fall of the rebel loan, were sufficient to convince them that they might as well make such a settlement as would be pecuniarily profitable to them, rather than to undergo the expense and toil of a trial which, if successful, could hardly give them the fruits of success in time to be of any advantage to the failing cause which they would be only too glad to prop up.
headline: {'main': 'The Rebel Rams in England.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Rebel Rams in England.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Nominations, the
snippet: Nominations, the
lead_paragraph: The National Union Convention has unanimously declared ABRAHAM LINCOLN to be the candidate of the great Union party for the next Presidency of the United States. This proceeding is not so much a substantive act as a formal expression. The making of the nomination was already virtually accomplished by the people; the convention simply gave form to it. With a single exception, it is the only instance for a generation in which a political National Convention has named its candidate without competition. That exception was the renomination of HENRY CLAY by the Baltimore Whig Convention of 1844. In every other national convention there has been an ardent, and in many cases a very bitter, strife between the supporters of different favorites. This strife sometimes proceeded from a difference in shades of party sentiment, sometimes from sectional or local influences, sometimes from purely personal preferences. If, in the case of Mr. CLAY, there was from the first an absolute unanimity, it came almost entirely from personal considerations. Mr. CLAY had been for very many years the head and front of the Whig party. He had again and again been urged for the regular Presidential nomination of the party, but his preeminent merits were as often set aside in favor of some more "available" candidate, so styled. The betrayal of the party by JOHN TYLER brought the party to a universal sense that HENRY CLAY had been unworthily treated, and the convention of 1844 was thus fired with the single purpose of doing justice to its great party champion. It was a personal sentiment that wrought that unanimity. Vast numbers gave themselves up to it, who seriously doubted whether the renomination would not insure the defeat of the party, or whether even if it prevailed, the interests of the party would not suffer under the strong will and stern rule to which it would be subjected. Concern for the party almost entirely disappeared in a concern for HENRY CLAY.

abstract: BURTON DRAMATIC ASSOCIATION. -- This association gave a performance of "Hamlet" at the Stadt Theatre on Tuesday evening. We are compelled to state that the locality is not the best that might be chosen for the purpose; but such a really excellent performance from amateurs as that given, is but deserving of praise. To particularize on such an occasion would, perhaps, seem to be out of place; but it may be said that the Polonius was something of quite a different cast from what we have been accustomed to witness from novices who essay the sock and buskin; with a very small degree of attention, Mr. MERVILLE would not only merit but gain the applause of those whom "Hamlet" describes as the "judicious," for he would certainly never bring them to grief. Mr. MERVILLE is a rare exception to the would-be amateurs who almost invariably make failures. The fair Ophelia deserves mention in commendatory terms. She assumed the part at very short notice, and considering that it was necessary for her not only to commit the text to memory and familiarize herself with the business, but also to learn the music, it can be said she did well. Hamlet was a careful and remarkably correct bit of acting. Horatio was particularly excellent in what was most important -- the scenes in the first act. We suspect that this gentleman is more familiar with the drama than he has chosen to make known. As a whole, the "Burton" may be congratulated on their performance. It was an earnest of something even better to come.

abstract: A lad aged 15 years, named MAX. ROTH, was taken into custody yesterday afternoon, by Officers GILMORE, of the Post-office, and HAYS, of the Bank Police, on the charges of theft and forgery. The firm of BOODY  Co., Bankers, at No. 8 Wall-street, are the complainants in the case, and they allege that on the 31st ultimo, they sent a boy in their office, with $76,000 to ...
lead_paragraph: A lad aged 15 years, named MAX. ROTH, was taken into custody yesterday afternoon, by Officers GILMORE, of the Post-office, and HAYS, of the Bank Police, on the charges of theft and forgery. The firm of BOODY Co., Bankers, at No. 8 Wall-street, are the complainants in the case, and they allege that on the 31st ultimo, they sent a boy in their office, with $76,000 to deposit in the Marine Bank. On his way thither he met young ROTH, who a few days previously had been discharged by Messrs. BOODY & CO., for cause, and thus the accused learned the amount of money to be deposited. After the book and money had been left at the bank by the office boy, ROTH entered, said there was a mistake and asked the paying teller to return the same for correction. The latter well knowing ROTH, and being unaware of his discharge by the firm, gave him the funds. When outside he abstracted the sum of $6,088 and returned the balance to the Bank. About $5,000 of the stolen money have been recovered. ROTH was committed to the Tombs.

abstract: Every day for the last five or six weeks a naval court-martial has been in session in this City, for the purpose of investigating certain charges made against contractors for the Navy Department. For many days the case of Mr. SCOFIELD has been before the court. The publication of its proceedings is not permitted. The court, it is rumored, has thus far failed to establish direct fraud to any considerable extent. Enormous profits are alleged to have been exacted, but an important witness informed our reporter yesterday that larger profits are every day made in "honest trade" with the public. A complete record of the proceedings of the court is in course of preparation for print, but the precise channel of its publicity has not yet been designated.

abstract: the Lesson of the War
snippet: the Lesson of the War
lead_paragraph: Our correspondent with the Ninth Army Corps remarked, in a recent letter, that the rebel sharpshooters were superior to ours, and did more injury. He attributed their superiority to the greater familiarity with the rifle of the Southern population, and their more thorough acquaintance with woodcraft. The great number of officers killed on our side, and many of them of high rank, makes this view of Southern superiority with the rifle the more probable. And yet, if it be the fact, there is no excuse for any Northern inferiority at this stage of the war. It is well understood that good rifle shooting is as much a matter of science and training as good artillery firing. A thoroughly expert rifleman can be manufactured almost as surely as the rifle itself. He can learn to shoot with remarkable accuracy by rigidly following certain rules, almost without firing a shot. Regiments of men from our cities, who had never seen a rifle, could be trained so as to shoot with the precision of the most practiced Kentucky hunter.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, a bill was reported to facilitate telegraphic communication between the eastern and western continents. The bill to establish certain new military and post roads in Michigan, was passed as amended.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, a bill was reported to facilitate telegraphic communication between the eastern and western continents. The bill to establish certain new military and post roads in Michigan, was passed as amended. Mr. DAVIS offered a joint resolution to restore peace among the people of the United States. Objection being made to its reception, the Chair decided that it was not in order. Another Committee of Conference was appointed to meet that of the House on the Consular and Diplomatic Appropriation Bill. The bill relative to commercial intercourse between the loyal and disloyal States, was then taken up for consideration. The bill to prohibit the exemption of persons from military duty by reason of the payment of money, was then taken up. An amendment was offered that all calls for drafts hereafter may be for a term not exceeding one year; that the act shall not, however, extend to any district or sub-district where the quota on previous calls has not been filled. That no person drafted on further calls shall be liable to be again drafted until the present enrollment shall be exhausted, and that when men are furnished by any district in excess of the quota on calls previously made, the term of service of each man shall be considered and allowed to said district in calls hereafter made. Alter a lengthy argument the first branch of the amendment was adopted by a vote of 23 against 17, the remaining sections of the amendment were adopted. An amendment was offered by Mr. WILSON, but before discussing it the House adjourned.

abstract: The Phoenix, of Brooklyn, commenced in 1853, with a capital of $200,000. Since then it has steadily progressed, till its receipts for a single year are stated at $300,000 -- an amount of income larger than that of any American company with the same amount of capital. It has paid dividends to the amount of $304,000 to stockholders, being an average of 15 per cent. annually. During its first five years it did almost entirely a local business. It is said to have been as successful, in the management of its agency business, as any other company in the State. The Phoenix has now added $300,000 to its capital, thus coming up to the standard of enterprise in these times, and making its capital half a million. To this is added its surplus of $222,210 20, and its assets reach a total of $722,219 20. With this increase of capital the Phoenix will, of course, increase its business. It has opened a new office at No, 139 Broadway, adapted in all respects to the wants of a first-class corporation. -- Journal of Commerce.

abstract: An invalid officer who has just arrived here from Bermuda Hundreds has furnished me with some very interesting news from that quarter. He says that the indications in Gen. BUTLER'S camp are very numerous of another forward movement, but in what direction is known, of course, only to the high officials. Conjectural points, however, are freely canvassed in camp, and among there Petersburgh is the oftenest mentioned.

abstract: A NINETEENTH WARD ROWDY SHOT BY A POLICEMAN. A report was made to Inspector CARPENTER, yesterday, by Capt. HAETT, of the Ninteenth Precinct, that on Wednesday night number of rowdies assaulted and knocked down a stranger in the First
lead_paragraph: A NINETEENTH WARD ROWDY SHOT BY A POLICEMAN. -- A report was made to Inspector CARPENTER, yesterday, by Capt. HAETT, of the Ninteenth Precinct, that on Wednesday night number of rowdies assaulted and knocked down a stranger in the First-avenue, near Sixty-eighth-street, for the purpose of robbing him. Officer CLARK, of that precinct, hearing the screams for help, proceeded to the spot through a dark avenue, (none of the lamps in the vicinity being lighted,) and ordered the desperadoes to desist, or he would shoot them. The violence continued, and the policeman discharged one barrel of his revolver, the ball from which took effect in the right side of one of the assailants, whose name is ISAAC ALLEN. The wound is a very severe one. He was conveyed to the station-house and thence to St. Luke's Hospital. ALLEN's confederates made their escape, and have not yet been arrested.

abstract: An immense audience assembled at the Hippotheatron to witness the match between WM. GOLDTHWAIT and DUDLEY KAVANAGH for the championship of America. It proved one of the best contested games ever played. GOLDTHWAIT took the lead, and at one time was over 300 points ahead; but KAVANAGH's unrivaled skill made him again a winner in 86 innings, with 75 points to spare. Highest runs, KAVANAGH, 156, 126, 120 and 118; GOLDTHWAIT, 117, 113, 96 and 96. Winner's average, 17.38. Time, 4 hours 30 minutes. A large amount was staked on the result, most of it at $100 to $50, although there were some pets at $100 to $30.

abstract: Platform, the
snippet: Platform, the
lead_paragraph: The Union party, now for the first time meeting in National Convention, for the first time gives its combined sanction, and an authoritative form, to its tenets. Its series of resolutions embrace nothing novel; they are but the reassertion of principles which have already shaped the character and policy of the Administration; and yet their clear and systematic statement, accredited by the unanimous assent of the party in convention assembled, is an important act, which will pass into history.

abstract: Morgan's Kentucky Raid
snippet: Morgan's Kentucky Raid
lead_paragraph: -- It would seem that JOHN MORGAN is again in Kentucky, and has gotten as far up as Paris, Bourbon County, and even farther. We heard of MORGAN a short time since as commanding a division of infantry in JOHNSTON's army, but he must have got tired of that very quickly, if this really be him in Kentucky. We do not know by what route he got into the State, nor exactly where he came from, but he must have passed through some one of the gaps of the Cumberland Mountains.

abstract: The new and handsome steamer Berkshire, of the New-York and Hudson line, left Hudson night before last at her usual hour, with a heavy freight and an unusual number of passengers. When a few miles below Rondout fire broke out on the main deck, which was stowed with bales of hay, and increased with such amazing rapidity, enveloping so large a surface at once, that its cause was difficult to trace. It was too distant from the fire-room to have caught therefrom. One account is that it came from the lamp-room, and another supposes it was occasioned by the careless smoking of a cigar.
lead_paragraph: The new and handsome steamer Berkshire, of the New-York and Hudson line, left Hudson night before last at her usual hour, with a heavy freight and an unusual number of passengers. abstract: The news from the Army of the Potomac presents no new feature to-day. The flag of truce has been arranged satisfactorily, and the dead and wounded were being removed from the field. The railroad from the White House to the army is in process of repair, and the mails for the army are now regularly received.

snippet: Steuben, Baron Von, 52d N. Y. S. V.; Perry, Lt.-Col. E., 139th N. Y. S. V.; Drake, Col. 112th N. Y. S. V.
lead_paragraph: Among the killed at the battle near Cold Harbor, Va., was Lieut.-Col. EDGAR PERRY, of the One Hundred and Thirty-ninth N.Y.S.V., Brooklyn. He went out with his regiment as Captain of Company F. In July last he was promoted to the position he held at the time of his death. Lieut.-Col. PERRY was the son of the late ELY PERRY, of Orange County, of this State, and nephew of Hon. WILLIAM E. HASBROOK, of Newburgh, and of Col. JAMES H. PERRY, of the Forty-eighth Brooklyn, who was killed at Fort Pulaski, Georgia. At the time of Lieut.-Col. PERRY's death, he was in command of his regiment, the Colonel being absent therefrom in consequence of sickness. A brave and promising young officer and patriot has fallen while nobly fighting in the cause of a country he dearly loved. And although in the prime of life, hope and usefulness, he fell as a brave soldier delights to fall, with his face to the foe fighting in defence of a holy cause and of his native land. C.H.M.

abstract: -The County Volunteer Committee of the Board of Supervisors are understood to have bounty funds on hand to the amount of $600,000 or more. In view of the message of the President, yesterday, laid before Congress, recommending the repeal of the three hundred dollar exemption clause, is it not time to consider how this unexpended sum can be turned to practical account? The committee, it is true, have already done no common service to the State; but the exigences of the hour demand even a further tax on their time and their energies. The public, while acknowledging the debt they owe the committee, feel satisfied that the members are not weary in well-doing, and that they may reckon on the business of recruiting being commenced anew with the same judicious energy and the same successful results as marked the admirable arrangements under which the last quota of New-York was filled.

abstract: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of all military movements in the different departments from the pens of our special correspondents. Also, all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news, European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, giving the tone of public feeling abroad, made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports; items of agricultural and domestic interest, compiled from sources many of which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader; and marriages and deaths of the week.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, a joint resolution was offered to the effect that Arkansas had now in operation a State Government organized upon a true basis and Republican in form, gained by a full and untrammeled vote of the people, declaring that, such laws of Congress as stated the people of Arkansas in rebellion should he declared inoperative and void, and ordering that the present organized government in Arkansas be recognized, on the condition that, except as punishment, Slavery, or involuntary servitude, shall not exist in the State. A resolution was also offered for the protection of overland emigration. The bill for the settlement of California private land claims was brought up; the consideration of the bill ceased on the expiration of the morning hour. The Indian Appropriation Bill was brought up and several amendments acted upon, after which a report from the Committee of Conference on the Army Appropriation Bill was heard. The Senate adjourned, however, without taking action in the matter.

A resolution was also offered for the protection of overland emigration. The bill for the settlement of California private land claims was brought up; the consideration of the bill ceased on the expiration of the morning hour. The Indian Appropriation Bill was brought up and several amendments acted upon, after which a report from the Committee of Conference on the Army Appropriation Bill was heard. The Senate adjourned, however, without taking action in the matter.

abstract: An unfortunate error in the caption of a telegram in yesterday's issue made it appear that Col. MCLEOD MURPHY had been dismissed from the army by Gen. MEADE. The text of Gen. MEADE's order showed that it was not the officer just mentioned, but Lieut.-Col. M.C. MURPHY, of the One Hundred and Seventieth New-York Volunteers, who was dishonorably dismissed from the military service, for presuming to send a flag of truce to the enemy's lines without authority. Col. MCLEOD MURPHY, who is deservedly known as one of the most gallant and meritorious officers in the service, has not been in the army at all for a great length of time, but has been engaged in the naval service, and for months past has been stationed in this City, supervising naval recruiting operations at the State-street depot. The error in question arose from the approximate similarity of the two names, and we are as glad to make the correction as we are grieved that it should be required.
lead_paragraph: An unfortunate error in the caption of a telegram in yesterday's issue made it appear that Col. MCLEOD MURPHY had been dismissed from the army by Gen. MEADE. The text of Gen. abstract: -- This convention adjourned on Thursday afternoon sine die, after tendering a vote of thanks to Mayor GUNTHER and the head of the public institutions, for the kindness and attention paid by them to the members of the convention. The prize essay for the present year was written by Dr. S. FLEET SPEIR, of Brooklyn, who received a gold medal valued at $100. Yesterday morning the members of the convention visited the various public institutions of the City, in company with the Commissioners of Public Charities.

abstract: The Masonic Convention concluded its labors yesterday. The main business was the installation of officers, which took place during the morning session. The Finance Committee passed several appropriations, among which was an appropriation of $5,000 from the Treasury of the Grand Lodge toward the Hall and Asylum Fund, and $2,000 to the New-York Board of Masonic Relief. A committee of twenty-five was appointed to solicit subscriptions from lodges and others, to the Hall and Asylum Fund, and to report the result of their labors at the next communication. The Grand Master made the following appointments: G. Marshal, Orrin Welsh; G. Standard-bearer. E.L. Judson; G. Sword-bearer, Ed. M. Banks; G. Stewards, F.W. Herring, R.G. Cornell, Josh. H. Toone; Geo. H. Raymond, Senior Grand Deacon; Theophilus Pratt, Junior Grand Deacon. At 10 1/2 o'clock the convention adjourned.
lead_paragraph: The Masonic Convention concluded its labors yesterday. The main business was the installation of officers, which took place during the morning session. The Finance Committee passed several appropriations, among which was an appropriation of $5,000 from the Treasury of the Grand Lodge toward the Hall and Asylum Fund, and $2,000 to the New-York Board of Masonic Relief. A committee of twenty-five was appointed to solicit subscriptions from lodges and others, to the Hall and Asylum Fund, and to report the result of their labors at the next communication. The Grand Master made the following appointments: G. Marshal, Orrin Welsh; G. Standard-bearer. E.L. Judson; G. Sword-bearer, Ed. M. Banks; G. Stewards, F.W. Herring, R.G. Cornell, Josh. H. Toone; Geo. H. Raymond, Senior Grand Deacon; Theophilus Pratt, Junior Grand Deacon. At 10 1/2 o'clock the convention adjourned.

abstract: We have a brief but gratifying dispatch concerning the victory of Gen. HUNTER over the rebels near staunton. The enemy was severely defeated, with a heavy loss of prisoners, six...
lead_paragraph: We have a brief but gratifying dispatch concerning the victory of Gen. HUNTER over the rebels near staunton. The enemy was severely defeated, with a heavy loss of prisoners, six guns, and a large amount of stores. The rebels appear to have made no stand at Staunton, though the place was strongly fortified, and all the male inhabitants, young and old, had been ordered out to assist in its defence. Our correspondent significantly adds that our army is about to move upon another point of importance.

abstract: Consular Pupils, Approp. Bill
snippet: Consular Pupils, Approp. Bill
lead_paragraph: The Diplomatic Appropriation Bill, about which the House and Senate have just disagreed, but which will, no doubt, be eventually passed, creating consular clerks or pupils, to be attached to the leading Consuls' offices abroad, at salaries of $1,000 a year, introduces an innovation into our civil service, likely to prove so highly important as a precedent, that it cannot be too strongly commended to public attention. The persons who are to be appointed under it are not to be removable, except "for cause," and the cause is to be laid before Congress. This, we trust, will prove the narrow end of the wedge, and be the means of introducing a similar reform into all other branches of the Administration. We shall, under this rule, secure the services of a far better class of men than we have ever had before, because its permanency will tempt them, and an honester class, because they will not be seduced into "making hay while the sun shines," from the knowledge that they are pretty sure to be ousted at the end of four years. Moreover, it will secure us what we have never had before in our diplomacy, a class of trained public servants, familiar with the duties of their office, with its usages and proprieties, and with foreign languages and manners.

abstract: Platform and Reconstruction
snippet: Platform and Reconstruction
lead_paragraph: The Copperheads, who are nothing if not querulous, complain of the Union platform for not touching upon the question of reconstruction. They say that the supporters of the Administration have different opinions on this cardinal point, and that it was pusillanimously avoided in order to escape discord. They try to make it appear that the seeming unanimity of the Convention was secured only by concealment and evasion.

abstract: CHARLES E. KNOX, formerly of Utica, and more recently in temporary charge of the Presbyterian Church in Morristown, was, on Wednesday evening last, ordained and installed as Pastor of the Presbyterian Church in Bloomfield. Rev. Mr. MILLARD, of Montclair, conducted the exercises, and proposed the constitutional questions to the candidate for ordination. The sermon was delivered by Rev. THOMAS S. HASTINGS, of this city. Rev. Mr. HOYT, of Orange, made the ordaining prayer. Rev. WM.E. KNOX, of Rome, gave the charge to the Pastor, and Rev. Dr. PARKER, formerly of this city, but now of Newark, that to the people. The exercises were throughout of a highly interesting character.

abstract: The members of the seventy-ninth Regiment (Highlanders) who yet owe service to the Government, numbering about 150 of the 325 came home, have recently been ordered to assemble on Hart's Island, and have been organized as the "Seventy-ninth Battalion." Under this name they have been ordered to take the field, under command of Capt. ANDREW BAIRD. The name of the Seventy-ninth is thus it is understood, to be preserved in the field. The Seventy-ninth Regiment, however, as one of our militia organizations, will soon resume its position in the division of Gen. SANDFORD.

abstract: FATAL ACCIDENT AT HOBOKEN.--A man named JOHN KINNEY, a boat-keeper at the Cove in Hoboken, on Thursday evening attempted to pass in front of a locomotive on the Morris and Essex road at Hoboken, when his foot tripped and he fell directly across the...
lead_paragraph: FATAL ACCIDENT AT HOBOKEN.--A man named JOHN KINNEY, a boat-keeper at the Cove in Hoboken, on Thursday evening attempted to pass in front of a locomotive on the Morris and Essex road at Hoboken, when his foot tripped and he fell directly across the track. The wheels of the locomotive passed over and severed both legs above the knees, causing death a few minutes thereafter. KINNEY was warned by the flag-man not to attempt to cross, but he paid no attention to the caution given him.

abstract: Prince Couza and his Parliament
snippet: Prince Couza and his Parliament
lead_paragraph: Perhaps, since the establishment of the present Moldo-Wallachian Constitution Prince COUZA and his Parliament have agreed about no one thing, save the confiscation of the "conventual possessions." Though the creature of the elective assembly, he has been almost always at variance with it. That body is chiefly composed of boyards, or great landed proprietors, who have an instinctive aversion to both reform and absolutism; and who have generally delighted in thwarting the philanthropic schemes of their Hospodar, especially if those schemes were calculated to undermine their own influence. At length the patience of the Prince became exhausted and he determined to bring matters to a crisis. For this purpose he caused a measure to be submitted to the consideration of the assembly, which he knew very well they would reject. The measure in question was a bill to facilitate the acquisition of land by the Moldo-Wallachian peasantry, and, as COUZA had anticipated, the House refused to sanction it. Such was precisely what that wily individual wanted. He had now his enemies completely in his power. They had given him the whip hand of them. They had placed him in the position of a patriot who was laboring for the public good, and themselves in that of obstructives and adversaries of the Commonwealth. The desired crisis was therefore arrived, and while he had so excellent pretext for appealing to the people, COUZA made up his mind to dissolve the chambers and call on the nation to arbitrate between him and his opponents. The decree of dissolution was accordingly issued, and with it appeared an address from the Hospodar himself to the Roumanians, in which his own services to the State and the delinquencies of the assembly, are carefully set forth. "Having been raised to the throne," says he, "by the unanimous votes of the Elective Assembly, I had a right to expect the cooperation of those who had imposed on me the glorious but difficult task of reorganizing the country." The princely philanthropist, however, was grievously disappointed, and thus pathetically portrays his wrongs. "For his devotion to the National cause;" exclaims he, "your elected chief, Roumanians has been rewarded with outrage and calumny, and a factious oligarchy has unceasingly obstructed his efforts for the public good." This is in the "Cambyses vein," and if we knew nothing of the antecedents of COUZA, we might infer the refrom that a modern Alfred had arrived on the banks of the Danube to bless the people of the principalities with his rule. But though the Moldo-Wallachian Hospodar is neither an Alfred nor a Saint Louis, he has nevertheless made out a very plausible case against the Assembly, and will probably succeed in vanquishing the oligarchs at the elections. COUZA's appeal to the people is not properly speaking a coup d'etat, in the French sense of that phrase. It rather resembles that expedient which is occasionally resorted to in England when parties get into a dead lock, and the Government can't move on. On such occasions the minister appeals from parliamentary factions to their constituents, and the result determines whether the men in office are to continue in place, or to resign the administration to the Opposition. The dissolution of the Moldo-Wallachian Chamber is not its annihilation. The composition of the Assembly may be changed by the action of the people, but the Assembly itself will meet again when the arbitraments are past. The fact is, that the constitution conferred on the Moldo-Wallachians by the great Powers in 1858 was extremely defective, and left the royards far too much influence in the Lower Chamber. This undue influence has been invariably used to prevent all attempt at reform and to perpetuate injustice, and if COUZA's coup should lead to the overthrow of the oligarchs, and the infusion of a larger democratic element into the Assembly, the people and the nation will have no reason to regret the result.

abstract: Swearing and Profanity
snippet: Swearing and Profanity
lead_paragraph: -- The habit of vulgar swearing, so shocking to good taste and to every sense of propriety, is we fear as prevalent in the community as in the most licentious of by-gone times. One hardly expects to pass the open doors of a class of rum establishments without hearing repeated volleys of the most blasphemous oaths -- oaths employed as often to form a pleasant garnish for the conversation, as for the more intelligible purpose of giving an outlet to passion. But these rum shops have no monopoly of the custom. It pervades society of an order much less outwardly debased; and fast young men of a quasi respectable bearing who affect sports in themselves harmless, render their company altogether revolting by promiscuous and incessant swearing. The evil stares us in the face, and those who would seek to check it can at best but administer a silent reproof by presenting the contrast of a quiet demeanor, and a rigid abstinence from needless expletives or the use of even seemingly inoffensive oaths.

lead_paragraph: If some friendly Asmodeus would take off the roofs of Richmond for us during these days, it would be very interesting to see what feelings and thoughts occupy the souls of the inhabitants of that guilty city, as they hear for the second time the thundering guns of a Union army approaching. But such a spiriting could hardly be expected, even in these days of spirit manifestations, for what foul spirit could there be who was not upon the rebels' side? We can imagine something of it without such aid.

abstract: Peace Party; The Davis-Vance Correspondence; The Vance Correspondence and Peace Party in North Carolina
snippet: Peace Party; The Davis-Vance Correspondence; The Vance Correspondence and Peace Party in North Carolina
lead_paragraph: The correspondence between JEFFERSON DAVIS and Gov. VANCE, of North Carolina, on the subject of peace, which we published on Monday, reveals a very curious state of mind on the part of both these functionaries. Gov. VANCE says that " after a careful consideration of the causes of the discontent" which he acknowledges to exist in his State, he has come to the conclusion "that it will be impossible to remove it, except by making some effort at negotiation with the enemy." To this DAVIS replies that it is of no use offering to negotiate with the enemy, that he has three times endeavored to do so, and has in every instance failed to secure even a hearing for his messenger. They both agree that the only terms they can offer to the North now, are those which they have always offered, to let the North alone, if it lets them alone; or, in other words, acknowledges their independence. Gov. VANCE professes to believe that if this were offered again and refused, it would close the mouths of the North Carolina malcontents, and not only this, but strengthen and intensify the war feeling. But it is hardly possible to believe that there is a single man in North Carolina intelligent enough to oppose the war at all, who does not know perfectly well that this proposal to negotiate on the basis of Southern independence has been before the United States Government ever since the war began. There is no white man in the State, we are quite satisfied, so grossly ignorant of the origin and history of the struggle as to flatter himself that the North is fighting for any other reason than its unwillingness to let the South alone; or that, if it changed its mind on this subject, the offer of peace would not first come from it. There is none who does not know what the "Commissioners" came to Washington for in the Spring of 1861; what DAVIS sent his "military officer" and his Vice-President for, and why these gentlemen were all sent back to Richmond without any response. What can anybody in the South possibly suppose the North keeps 600,000 men in the field for, and submits to terrible bloodshed every week, if it is willing to let the Confederacy alone? Newspapers may rant as much as they please, but there is no class of the Southern people so stupid as to suppose that we carry on a great war, and overwhelm ourselves with debt, as they fancy we are doing, for the mere purpose of plunder and slaughter.

While taking his prisoner to the Station-house, the friends of the latter
lead_paragraph: ANOTHER MURDEROUS ATTACK ON A POLICE OFFICER. At a late hour on Friday, night, while Officer SULLIVAN was patrolling his beat, he had occasion to arrest a young man named DENNIS J. 0'CARROLL for disorderly conduct in the streets. While taking his prisoner to the Station-house, the friends of the latter made a deperate assault on the officer. They forcibly took his club from him, and then placed a loaded revolver to his head and attempted to discharge it, but fortunately the weapon missed fire. The men then made their escape after having rescued O'CARROLL. The policeman immediately reported the circumstances to the station-house, and Sergeant POLLEY, with a number of men, went in pursuit of the fugitives. On the northwest corner of Third-avenue and Forty-second street, in O'CARROLL's porter-house, they were found, but they all succeeded in making their escape except O'CARROLL and DENNIS COONAN. O'CARROLL had Officer SULLIVAN's club in his possession when arrested. The prisoners were taken before Justice KELLY, fined $10 each and required to find bail to keep the peace.

abstract: Memorial Diplomatique on United States Prize Courts. The Springbok
snippet: Memorial Diplomatique on United States Prize Courts. The Springbok
lead_paragraph: The second point made by the writer in the Memorial Diplomatique, in his attack upon our prize courts, of which we spoke some days since, is, that contraband cargo does not carry with it the forfeiture of the rest of the cargo, though belonging to the same owner. His argument is, briefly, that while a belligerent has the right to hinder succor from reaching his enemy, he has no right to punish the one who is endeavoring to send that succor, and the confiscation of the cargo which is not contraband, is punishment. "But," he says, "the transgressor being a neutral, the belligerent possesses no right of jurisdiction over him. He has no right to impose any penalty whatever on a neutral in neutral territory." The writer does not pretend to cite any authority on this point, except a sentence from HAUTEFEUILLE, which says that "neutral vessels laden in whole or in part with contraband of war, destined for the enemy, are liable to seizure, but not in an absolute manner," -- a remark, be it noted, which does not refer in the least to the other cargo or its ownership. And he disposes of the opposite authorities simply by saying: "We are aware that some authors have questioned this doctrine, but their arguments are easily refuted." Among these authors thus summarily disposed of, we may name BYNKERSHOEK, VALIN, KENT, WHEATON, STORY, Lord STOWELL, PHILLIMORE, PRATT, HAZLITT and ROCHE, HALLECK, MOSELEY and WILDMAN. If there is any point of prize law well settled on authority, it is that, as PRATT says, "the taint of contraband extends to all property on board belonging to the owners of the contraband articles." We find, on a cursory examination, no less than thirteen cases in Robinson's Reports in which Lord STOWELL acted upon it.

lead_paragraph: The St. Louis Union says that a company of federal troops recently came upon a gang of guerrillas secreted in a cave in Marias county, and six of their number were shot down by the concealed foe. The soldiers thereupon stationed themselves at the mouth of the cave and established a blockade. The guerrillas offered to surrender if they could be treated as prisoners of war, but the soldiers sent back word that every rebel in the cave had got to die. Thus the affair stood at last accounts.

abstract: The news from the army around Richmond would be without much interest but for the official dispatch announcing an advance by Gen. KAUTZ against Petersburgh, on Friday. What force Gen. KAUTZ had at his disposal is not stated;...
lead_paragraph: The news from the army around Richmond would be without much interest but for the official dispatch announcing an advance by Gen. KAUTZ against Petersburgh, on Friday. What force Gen. KAUTZ had at his disposal is not stated; but he had sufficient to carry the enemy's works, although too small a force to hold them. The dispatch seems to insinuate that Gen. GILMORE was ordered, to support the advance on Petersburgh and failed to do so. In the circumstances, Gen. KAUTZ had no resource but to withdraw. He succeeded in capturing forty prisoners and one piece of artillery.

abstract: In the Senate yesterday, Mr. FOSTER, from the Committee on Claims, introduced a bill to amend the act granting pensions. Mr. TURNBULL introduced a bill relating to United States Circuit Courts. Mr. LANE, of Kansas, added a new section to his resolutions relating to the recognition of the new State Government of Arkansas, to the effect that the resolutions shall be in force from and after the acceptance by the people of the State and the President's proclamation of the same. The California Land Claims Bill was discussed during the morning, and the Indian Appropriation Bill  was passed as amended, and goes back to the House. The report of the Army Appropriation Bill was agreed to. The Senate adjourned at half-past 4 o'clock.

abstract: As we are again about to have some change in the Conscription Law, and there is talk of drafting men for one year only, it would be well to consider the propriety of
lead_paragraph: As we are again about to have some change in the Conscription Law, and there is talk of drafting men for one year only, it would be well to consider the propriety of adopting some rule that would insure to the United States a year's service of trained men, and not of raw recruits. If the draft is made for the purpose of filling up the ranks of regiments now in the field, and the conscripts are at once sent forward to the army, they will, of course, learn their work more rapidly than in camp at home; but under the best of circumstances this is a wasteful process. The battle-field is not the place to learn drill on; it is not the place to take undrilled men to. The presence of large bodies of raw recruits in a regiment is always a source of danger and embarrassment, let them be ever so brave naturally. In fact, the bravery of novices is apt to render them only an easier prey to a wary and seasoned enemy. And yet if the time during which they are to learn to manoeuvre and handle their arms is to be taken out of twelve months, it will seriously curtail their term of actual service, and leave most regiments in a state of chronic disorganization.

abstract: Our Democratic brethren seem to be a good deal bewildered. They don't know whom it is best to nominate for the Presidency, and they are not quite sure it is best to nominate anybody just now. They are afraid to select a candidate as the representative of their principles, partly because they
lead_paragraph: Our Democratic brethren seem to be a good deal bewildered. They don't know whom it is best to nominate for the Presidency, and they are not quite sure it is best to nominate anybody just now. They are afraid to select a candidate as the representative of their principles, partly because they have no principles to speak of, and partly because they can't agree in regard to the few they have. So they have about come to the conclusion that they will be under the necessity of nominating a military candidate. But here also various difficulties confront them. Their favorite hitherto has been MCCLELLAN, rather on the score of what he might have done if things had gone differently than by reason of anything which he actually accomplished. But as time passes, public attention is turned rather to the men who do things than to those who might, could, would or should have done them: and there is some danger, that if nominated now Gen. MCCLELLAN might be forgotten before election day, -- or his reputation utterly eclipsed by the exploits of some of his successors. So, on the whole, the Democrats are rather inclined to postpone their convention, and to wait for the very latest intelligence from the seat of war.

abstract: Among the most gratifying developments of the Baltimore Convention was the unanimity exhibited in favor of a Constitutional amendment making a universal and perpetual end of Slavery. There was a time when such
lead_paragraph: Among the most gratifying developments of the Baltimore Convention was the unanimity exhibited in favor of a Constitutional amendment making a universal and perpetual end of Slavery. There was a time when such a proposition could not have been pressed without a great risk of making serious, if not fatal, discord in the Union party. We ourselves deprecated its premature agitation. Always recognizing that the unity of the Union party is the prime necessity, we have always been disposed to keep in the background all questions of minor concern calculated to breed strife. The progress of events was far more potent to settle them than any controversy could be. Experience has long since demonstrated that public opinion is shaped mainly by the inaudible and invisible teachings of the war, rather than by any appeals, however urgent, or by any arguments, however forcible.

abstract: The news this morning from the army East and West, without being of a startling character, is interesting. A dispatch from Gen. GRANT, dated on Saturday afternoon, reports considerable cavalry skirmishing--the rebels making the attack on Gen. WILSON'S lines near the Jenny House. BEAUREGARD'S army is reported to be between Bottom's Bridge and the James River. In the
lead_paragraph: The news this morning from the army East and West, without being of a startling character, is interesting. A dispatch from Gen. GRANT, dated on Saturday afternoon, reports considerable cavalry skirmishing--the rebels making the attack on Gen. WILSON'S lines near the Jenny House. BEAUREGARD'S army is reported to be between Bottom's Bridge and the James River. In the vicinity of Sumner's and Bottom's Bridges the rebels are busily at work throwing up fortifications. Contrary to an understanding agreed upon, picket-firing is steadily kept up by the rebels, and the casualties are numerous.

abstract: -- Shortly after 11 o'clock on Saturday night a fire was discovered in a large two-story brick building, corner of Union-avenue and Tenth-street, Eastern District, owned by ARCHIBALD ANDREW, and occupied by T.A. CUTTER, extensively engaged in the manufacture of hoop skirts. The alarm was given and the firemen were soon at work, but the flames were not extinguished until the inside was pretty thoroughly burned out. Mr. CUTTER had about $12,000 in machinery and stock in the building, and his loss will probably reach $6,000. He was insured for $5,000 in the Montauk and Excelsior Insurance Companies. The building was damaged about $1,500, upon which Mr. ANDREW had an insurance of $1,200 in the Fulton Insurance Company. The origin of the fire is not known

abstract: There was a large attendance of the trotting fraternity on Friday to witness the match for $2,000, mile heats, best three in five, in harness, between the mare Baby Belle, who received forfeit from Empress about a fortnight since, and the gelding Port Royal, but it turned out a thoroughly one-sided affair. The betting opened at 4 to 1 on the Baby, 10 to 1 being freely offered on her after the first heat, without finding takers.

The betting opened at 4 to 1 on the Baby, 10 to 1 being freely offered on her after the first heat, without finding takers.

abstract: Coroner RANNEY held an inquest yesterday at the corner of Ninth-avenue and Sixty-fourth-street, on the body of Miss JULIA O'SULLIVAN, who was drowned by jumping overboard from the steamboat Berkshire, at the times she was burned on the North River. Deceased was a passenger on the boat, and had been on an expedition of search for the body of her brother, who was drowned a day or two before by falling overboard from the steamer Hendrick Hudson. She was 28 years of age and a native of Ireland.

abstract: There was quite an excitement on the Battery grounds yesterday, occasioned by the queer antics of two mysterious individuals, who were at first thought to be insane. Attention was attracted to the parties by their suddenly doffing their coats, and apparently, as if by magic, putting them on again. It was evident their performances were for their own amusement, as, upon a near approach, they quietly seated themselves upon the grass and began to converse in a foreign language. Quite a crowd assembled about the men, who, upon being made aware that their feats were objects of attraction, renewed their "manipulations." The gratuitous entertainment consisted of mysterious contortions, instantaneous removal of portions of their wardrobe, and particularly of their coats, which they took off and put on without the slightest apparent muscular action. Everything was done in the most mysterious manner possible, and the whole affair ended, much to the mystification of about one hundred people, in less than ten minutes. One of the men said his name was ZAN-ZAN, and that his companion was his mate.
lead_paragraph: There was quite an excitement on the Battery grounds yesterday, occasioned by the queer antics of two mysterious individuals, who were at first thought to be insane. abstract: PIC-NIC IN AID OF THE GERMAN HOSPITAL FUND. -- A mammoth pic-nic, gotten up by the Germans of the Eastern District, in aid of the German Hospital Fund, will take place this morning at SCHACK's Myrtle-avenue Park. Twenty-three societies, including six military companies, will join in the procession, which will start at half-past eight o'clock, from the corner of Montrose-avenue and Leonard-street, and, after marching through several streets, will proceed to the grounds to spend the day. A concert will be given by several singing societies. The Turner's Society will also perform gymnastic feats, and MYERS' brass band will furnish the music. The ladies of the Williamsburgh Hospital Association will have charge of the refreshment stands. The committee having the matter in charge will use every effort to make this a grand and successful affair.

abstract: Mr. and Mrs. FLORENCE bring their Winter Garden engagement to an end this week. It has been and continues to be an extremely profitable one. A single fact will illustrate this more forcibly than any mere statement. During a period of seven
lead_paragraph: Mr. and Mrs. FLORENCE bring their Winter Garden engagement to an end this week. It has been and continues to be an extremely profitable one. A single fact will illustrate this more forcibly than any mere statement. During a period of seven months the "bill" has only been changed twice. The great attractions were the "Ticket-of-Leave Man" and "Fra Diavolo." The latter is still in the first [???]lush of its popularity. It is to be withdrawn after the present week, simply on account of Mr. FLORENCE, who is troubled with a throat complaint that compels him to seek absolute rest "Fra Diavolo" will be preceded by the farce of "Thrice Married."

abstract: We have  received a bundle of papers from Houston and Galveston, Texas the Galveston News, weekly and tri-weekly, and the Houston daily Telegraph. The News comes down as late as May 6, but there is no news in it. One of its day's issues is printed on a sort of dingy white paper; another on paper the color of red clay; and a third is a kind of blue clay color.
lead_paragraph: We have received a bundle of papers from Houston and Galveston, Texas the Galveston News, weekly and tri-weekly, and the Houston daily Telegraph. The News comes down as late as May 6, but there is no news in it. One of its day's issues is printed on a sort of dingy white paper; another on paper the color of red clay; and a third is a kind of blue clay color. In regard to size and shape they are no more particular than as regards color. One number of the News is about 18 inches long by 12 wide, another about a foot long by 10 inches wide. None of them is more than a single leaf, or two pages. In one of the red-leaf issues, they put a blank space in the middle of the six columns, and thus provide for folding it as a quarto; but this makes it a foot and a half long and only half a foot wide, like an old-fashioned ledger.

abstract: A gentleman in conversation remarked to President LINCOLN on Friday that nothing could defeat him but GRANT's capture of Richmond, to be followed by his nomination at Chicago and acceptance. "Well," said the President, "I feel very much like the man who said he didn't want to die particularly, but if he had got to die, that was precisely the disease he would like to die of."

abstract: About 10 o'clock on Saturday night, a United States marine, while walking along the railroad between Prospect and Warren streets, Jersey City, was struck on the head by a passing train of cars and seriously injured. He was observed by the engineer, who blew the whistle and applied the brakes, but the fellow seemed to take no heed of the warning. The injured man was conveyed to the Almshouse Hospital in an insensible condition, and was attended by a physician. His injuries are probably not of a fatal character.

abstract: -- It is some ten days now since GRANT's army had a serious collision with the rebels; and though in the interval there has been more or less of brisk fighting almost every day, there has been no gain apparent from it. The public are, of course, perfectly well assured that GRANT is by no means idle. There have been rumors enough that he was steadily carrying on some work which would soon be productive, and we are satisfied that its character and aim will now very soon be seen by the whole country.

abstract: One fact strikes the public mind as in great contrast to nearly all former experience of the Army of the Potomac, and that is, the cessation of those remarkable "surprises," or those attacks in "overwhelming numbers," which used continually to afflict us.
lead_paragraph: One fact strikes the public mind as in great contrast to nearly all former experience of the Army of the Potomac, and that is, the cessation of those remarkable "surprises," or those attacks in "overwhelming numbers," which used continually to afflict us. Under MCCLELLAN there was first the turning back of the retreating enemy, and of his falling upon our front corps near Williamsburgh, before the other portion of the line could be got forward in support -- a battle which, with any decent generalship, ought to have been a decided victory for us with comparatively little loss. Then followed the surprise of Fair Oaks, where a corps thrown out in the air is overwhelmed, and our army, cut in two by a river, is attacked in detail; then the bold raid of STUART, and finally the flank attack by JACKSON, and the greater part of LEE's army on one wing of ours -- the other wing remaining comparatively idle. And still further on, the bold rear assault by JACKSON on POPE's army, and the cutting up of portions of our forces again in detail. Then came the rebel escape from Antietam, which was equal almost to a defeat of our army; still later the surprise of the Eleventh Corps, badly placed in an exposed position at Chancellorsville, and HOOKER's retreat. And yet again, the escape of LEE from Gettysburgh.

abstract: The action of the Government of China in ordering that the Alabama and all other vessels which would prey upon American commerce, shall be excluded from all Chinese
lead_paragraph: The action of the Government of China in ordering that the Alabama and all other vessels which would prey upon American commerce, shall be excluded from all Chinese ports, is a matter of no small importance to us. Those Eastern seas are so far away that if these pirates were allowed to have as much assistance there as they have received in English ports, our vessels there would be almost at their mercy. Our readers will recollect the accounts which came from that quarter when the Alabama made her flying trip thither some months since, how all our vessels were immediately shut up as closely and with as much trepidation as chickens, when a hawk is in the air. But these rovers have never been able to keep the sea long without going into some port to refit, and this closing of the ports of China against them will make them chary of their visits to that part of the world.

abstract: Complimentary letter to, on retirement
snippet: Complimentary letter to, on retirement
lead_paragraph: The Board of Aldermen had no quorum yesterday, and now stand adjourned without day. The Board of Councilmen adopted resolutions complimentary and of thanks to FRANCIS MAHEDY, THOMAS MCGRATH and THOMAS TYLER, members of Enginne Company No. 31, for gallant conduct in saving life at a recent fire in Division-street. A resolution was adopted requesting the Comptroller to reserve $5,000 of the City Contingent Fund, to be expended in welcoming home the three years' regiments belonging to this City, who have returned, and those yet return this Summer. The Comptroller was requested to report what regulations exist for running the Eighty-sixth-street ferry to Astoria. Two veto messages were received from the Mayor, one on the resolution to procure official badges for the Police Justices, and the other on the resolution directing the Corporation Council to take proceedings to open certain up-town streets on the West side of the City. The first, he says, involves a needless expense, and the second he regards as untimely and unnecessary, and says besides, that several remonstrances to it of property owners interested have been presented to him. The board adjourned to Thursday, 2 P.M.

lead_paragraph: The latest intelligence from Gen. GRANT'S army is up to Monday morning, at which time an important movement was reported to be in successful progress. A report comes by way of Washington and Philadelphia, though not confirmed from other sources, that Gen. HANCOCK captured Bottom's Bridge on Sunday, by a bayonet charge, and that our whole army was safely across. There is probably no truth in the report.

abstract: The great Strawberry, Ice Cream and Floral Festival in Aid of the Freedmen and the Southern Loyal Refugees commenced yesterday afternoon at the City Assembly Rooms, No. 446 Broadway. The large room was very beautifully decorated; from the balconies were suspended banners bearing the portraits of Gens. GRANT, THOMAS, HOOKER, BUTLER and MCPHERSON. In the centre of the room was placed a large table, filled with bouquets and baskets of the most rare and exquisite flowers, the grateful perfume of which filled the entire room. About the sides of the room a large number of small tables were neatly arranged, which were surrounded with merry couples, about whom flitted numbers of little fairies, who kept the hungry mortals well supplied with the most delicious cream, the freshest strawberries and the best cake imaginable. Around the flower table and about the room many couples were promenading, and the whole affair was enlivened by some excellent selections from the various operas performed by DODWORTH's celebrated band. Mrs. WOOLSEY G. STERLING, the directress of the festival, and Rev. C.C. LEIGH, are entitled to great credit for the truly admirable manner in which all the arrangements have been made.

abstract: REV. SELLA MARTIN AT COOPER INSTITUTE.  Quite a large audience assembled last evening at the Cooper Institute, to listen to an address from Rev. SELLA MARTIN, who was but a few years since a slave in Georgia, on the state of public opinion in England with regard to the American war.
lead_paragraph: REV. SELLA MARTIN AT COOPER INSTITUTE. Quite a large audience assembled last evening at the Cooper Institute, to listen to an address from Rev. SELLA MARTIN, who was but a few years since a slave in Georgia, on the state of public opinion in England with regard to the American war. The meeting was opened by PETER COOPER Esq., who then introduced Rev. Dr. MCCLINTOCK. After a brief prayer, the reverend gentleman read a resolution of the London Emancipation Society laudatory of Mr. SELLA MARTIN, and made a short address, at the conclusion of which he introduced the lecturer of the evening to the audience. After the hearty applause which greeted his appearance had subsided, Mr. MARTIN proceeded to give a very clear and interesting summary of his observations on the feeling of the English toward America, and the reasons which induced a majority of the aristocratic and commercial classes to sympathize with the South, while the laboring classes are all but unanimous in favor of the North. Mr. MARTIN concluded his address, which was listened to with the utmost attention, with a brief account of his own life, and an eloquent appeal for sympathy and aid for the suffering, struggling people of his own race.

abstract: their Power; London Spectator on the farming Class
snippet: their Power; London Spectator on the farming Class
lead_paragraph: The London Spectator has lately remarked, with an intelligence in regard to foreign countries unusual to an English journal, that the really governing class in America were not the inhabitants of cities but the small freeholders cultivating the soil. It is to these that observers must look if they would see what is to be the popular decision on political questions or the continuance of the war. And according to the Spectator this class is distinguished by a certain Scotch quality called dourness, which inclines them to thorough radical measures. There is much shrewd observation in this view of our agricultural masses.

abstract: Sheffield, Miss M. E., of Norwich, Conn.; Hornblower, Chief Justice, of New-Jersey
snippet: Sheffield, Miss M. E., of Norwich, Conn.; Hornblower, Chief Justice, of New-Jersey
lead_paragraph: New-Jersey, in the death of the late JOSEPH C. HORNBLOWER, has lost one of her most eminent citizens. He was born at Belleville in 1777, educated chiefly at Orange, and after spending some time in the commercial house of JAMES KIP, of this City, entered, in 1798, the law office of DAVID B. OGDEN, of Newark. He became a member of the bar in 1803, and at once secured a lucrative and honorable practice; and his integrity and ability made him prominent in the legal profession. In 1832 he was appointed Chief Justice of the Supreme Court of New-Jersey, and held the office fourteen years, retiring in 1846. His decisions during this period are marked by learning, legal acumen and high moral principle, and occupy several volumes of the New-Jersey Law Reports. The Newark Advertiser says of the Chief Justice:

abstract: Dirt???or, Iron-clad; Description of
snippet: Dirt???or, Iron-clad; Description of
lead_paragraph: It having leaked out in naval circles that the immense engines of the great ocean iron-clad Dictator would be moved for the first time yesterday, no little interest was felt in a large portion of the community, and about 9 or 10 o'clock groups of foreign and American naval officers and of professional men generally might have been seen in the neighborhood of the Delamater Iron Works. Although the fact that steam was to be applied to the machinery had not been communicated to the reporters, the press was not entirely without representation, Before noon it was announced, by the arrival of a gentleman from Mr. ERICSSON, that the raising of steam was to be postponed entirely -- the contractor having determined not to delay the progress of the vessel by any mere formal test, as the Government is known to have expressed a desire to have the vessel completed for active duty as soon as circumstances will permit. No sooner had this information been vouchsafed than our reporter determined to make some inquiries as to the progress of the ship, and he immediately discovered that a still more important operation had been completed and might be inspected. This was nothing less than the successful arming of the ship with the immense new Ericsson guns, of which so much has been surmised that a brief description will not be out of place. It is known that the first and second batches of monitors are armed with three kinds of ordnance -- the 11-inch, the 15-inch and the 100-lb. rifle-gun. The first two are of the Dahlgren, and the latter of the Parrott type. The Ericsson 9-inch differs from all these as widely as the imagination can conceive. It is, in fact, so novel and revolutionary in its character that its success will, in Europe at least, be looked upon as a national matter. Capt. ERICSSON is said to have entered into a contract with the Government to guarantee that his gun will burn over fifty pounds of powder, while the 15-inch Dahlgren, when throwing a 450-pound shot during DUPONT's attack upon Charleston, only burned thirty-five pounds. The British 68-pounder (of 12,500 lbs.,) said by His Royal Highness the Duke of Cambridge to be the most powerful gun in the service, with sixteen pounds of powder, near one-fourth of fifty pounds, has an initial velocity of 1,800 feet per second, and therefore a punching power against iron plates of 27,000 pounds. The rifled gun, with charges of one-tenth to one-twelfth of the shot, and the 15-inch gun with a charge of 35 pounds to its shot of 425 pounds, have velocities varying from 1,100 to 1,400 feet per second. The 300-pound Parrott has, therefore, a punching power of 49,000 pounds, and the 15-inch gun of 55,000 pounds. The new gun, with 75 pounds charge, (one-third of the weight,) will have as great velocity as the 68-pounder, and its punching power 55,000, or exactly double that of the English gun. With 100 pounds of powder, its velocity should be raised to 2,000 feet, and its punching power will be 68,000 pounds, or 340 tons. It can be seen at a glance, that if a piece of ordnance of this magnitude can be successfully constructed, naval artillery is years ahead of the science of building war ships, for there is no craft in the world which would not be fairly capsized by a blow from a ball striking her with a force of 300 tons. The importance of the forthcoming experiment to the Dictator may therefore be imagined.

abstract: Newspaper correspondents are reminded that all manuscripts sent to publishers are entitled to be forwarded at the rate of two cents for four ounces, provided that one corner of the envelope is cut and left open, and the word "manuscript" is written on the face of the envelope. abstract: The first grand match of the season was commenced on the new ground of the New-York Club at Bedford, L.I., between the First Eleven of that club and the First Eleven of the Union Club of Newark. A fine display of the game way exhibited by both sides, and was witnessed by a larger assemblage of visitors than has been present on our cricket field for years past.
lead_paragraph: The first grand match of the season was commenced on the new ground of the New-York Club at Bedford, L.I., between the First Eleven of that club and the First Eleven of the Union Club of Newark. A fine display of the game way exhibited by both sides, and was witnessed by a larger assemblage of visitors than has been present on our cricket field for years past. The ground, which is a picturesque retreat, was in good order. To-day the game will be resumed and played out. The following is the score of yesterday's play:

abstract: -- An enormous scale, the largest perhaps in the country, has just been finished at Cleveland for the Fort Pitt Works in this city. They are intended to weigh the monster twenty-inch gun, and are of the following dimensions: Length, 30; breadth, 7 1/2 feet, and 4 feet in height. They will weigh from two pounds and a half up to one hundred tons, and are so nicely and accurately adjusted that the weight of half a pound will turn the beam. A half pound weight on the beam weighs one ton on the scales. They are built entirely of wrought iron, with the exception of the lever heads, which are cast. The pivots are made of wrought Iron steel edges, for the purpose of securing greater strength and durabilty. The cost of these scales, when set up in Pittsburgh will be $2,000. -- Pittsburgh Chronicle, June 10.

abstract: In the Senate yesterday, a bill was passed granting the right and interest of the United States in certain lands of the Grand Prairie Common Field, in Missouri, to that State. A lengthy report was received relative to the seizure of the silver mine of SYLVESTER MOWRY, in Mexico, by order of Gen. CARLETON, which was...
lead_paragraph: In the Senate yesterday, a bill was passed granting the right and interest of the United States in certain lands of the Grand Prairie Common Field, in Missouri, to that State. A lengthy report was received relative to the seizure of the silver mine of SYLVESTER MOWRY, in Mexico, by order of Gen. CARLETON, which was laid upon the table and ordered to be printed. The resolution relative to recognizing the Free State of Arkansas, werebrought up and after a lengthy debate, in which Messrs. SUMNER and LANE took a prominent part, was, with the credentials of Messrs. FISHBACK and BAXTER, who claim seats as Senators from Arkansas, referred to the Judiciary Committee. The Military Committee was discharged from further consideration of the bill relative to increased railroad facilities between New-York and Philadelphia. The Diplomatic Appropriation Bill was agreed to as it came from the House. The bill authorizing the Secretary of the Treasury to extend the Marine Hospital, at Chicago, was passed. Certain amendments to the Enrollment Bill were offered which, without reading, were ordered printed, after which the Senate adjourned.

abstract: The Sixth Annual Convention of the Sportsmen's Clubs of the State of New-York was held last evening at the rooms of the Sportsmen's Club, No. 16 East Fourteenth-street, Mr. CHARLES H. HASWELL presiding. After some preliminary proceedings, a committee was appointed to examine and report on new inventions submitted to the Club. The next business was the selection of judges, which resulted as follows: Of fly throwing and bass line, W.C. Barrett and C.E. Whitehead; pistol shooting, J.W. Green; rifle shooting, Geo. O. Holmes; all vacancies to be filled on the ground. Pigeon-shooting was mentioned, but the names of the judges were not given. The following officers were elected for the ensuing year: President O.R. GERALD, of Niagara Falls; Vice-Presidents, SOLOMON BOWLES and JOHN L. JEWETT; Secretaries, CHAS. E. WHITEHEAD and FRANK SIDWAY. A resolution was passed to hold the next annual meeting at Niagara Falls on the first Tuesday in June, 1865, after which the meeting adjourned to meet again this evening at 8 o'clock.

abstract: A mutiny occurred on board the ship Emily Augusta, Capt. STRICKLAND, while proceeding to sea yesterday afternoon, bound to St. John, N.B. While going down the bay, and when abreast of the Narrows, Capt. STRICKLAND went forward to get the men to go to work, when they told him to go aft again, and immediately rushed upon him, one of them stabling him in the back with a sheath-knife. They also attacked the mate, knocked him down on deck and kicked him, and made a pass with a knife at him, but did not cut him. The ship was immediately turned pack and anchored off Quarantine, and a boat's crew from the revenue cutter Crawford, boarded her and put the crew in irons. The United States Marshal was notified, who sent the Harbor Police boat down to her and had them all brought to the City and locked up in the Toembs. Capt. STRICKLAND, who is dangerously wounded, was brought to the City.
lead_paragraph: A mutiny occurred on board the ship Emily Augusta, Capt. STRICKLAND, while proceeding to sea yesterday afternoon, bound to St. John, N.B. abstract: ROBERT BRADLEY, aged 22 years, died yesterday, at the New-York Hospital, from the effect of injuries received on the 27th ult., by falling with a dummy, in the store of Messrs. HOWARD, SANGER & Co., No. 107 Chambers-street. At the time deceased received his injuries himself and another man were descending on the dummy from one of the upper floors. A chain suddenly broke, and the dummy and deceased went to the bottom. The other man saved himself by clinging to the second floor. Coroner WILDEY was notified, and will hold an inquest on the body to-day. BRADLEY was a native of Connecticut, and had been in the employ of the firm several years.

abstract: Eight millions of dollars is an amount of wealth that somewhat staggers the understanding; yet that amount was received in premiums in 1863, by the Atlantic Marine -- an amount that lacks only $2,000,000 to equal the sum of premiums, received by all the fire insurance companies of this State within the same time. The increase in the premiums of this Company in one year was not less than $3,097,954 06. The profits of the Company for the year was $2,630,000, after paying $3,755,000 in losses. By its last report we see that its assets amounted to $9,265,546 62. It made dividends of 40 per cent., beside paying six per cent. on its outstanding certificates. Its ascertained profits from July 1, 1842, to Jan. 1, 1863, were $16,958,830, being its total profits for twenty-one and and a-half years of successful business. All its certificates issued before 1862, amounting to $11,690,210, have been redeemed in cash, leaving the Company a net earning of $5,258,670. These figures may well startle older insurance companies, of less strength and less scope of action. Too much praise cannot be bestowed upon the capable management of the Atlantic, which has caused these splendid results. -- Commercial Advertiser.

abstract: To-day is the last day of the festival being held at the City Assembly Rooms, No. 446 Broadway, in aid of the White refugees from the South. The object is so very worthy that it ought to be unnecessary to appeal to our citizens to aid it, especially as such a good opportunity is now offered for every one to do a little. The National Freedman's Relief Association have been induced to make this attempt to do something for these refugees, in respone to the earnest appeals of their teachers, who depict the utter destitution and wretchedness of these people as almost too fearful to be believed. Donations of money and edibles, such as cream, strawberries, &c., will be thankfully received at the hall this day and evening.
lead_paragraph: To-day is the last day of the festival being held at the City Assembly Rooms, No. 446 Broadway, in aid of the White refugees from the South. The National Freedman's Relief Association have been induced to make this attempt to do something for these refugees, in respone to the earnest appeals of their teachers, who depict the utter destitution and wretchedness of these people as almost too fearful to be believed. Donations of money and edibles, such as cream, strawberries, &c., will be thankfully received at the hall this day and evening.

abstract: The Board of Supervisors met yesterday, when the Volunteer Committee submitted their final report, and also an ordinance appropriating $2,000,000, to be raised by subscription, in absence of ...
lead_paragraph: The Board of Supervisors met yesterday, when the Volunteer Committee submitted their final report, and also an ordinance appropriating $2,000,000, to be raised by subscription, in absence of authority of legislative enactment, to continue recruiting. The clause to the effect that the committee should not proceed till $500,000 were subscribed was stricken out and then the ordinance was adopted; and also a resolution directing the committee to resume recruiting as soon as they shall obtain official surety that all the men they enlist shall be allowed in the next quota. The committee say another call for 300,000 men is likely to be made by July 1, and that the quota of this City will be between 10,000 and 12,000 men. At present there is an excess of 66 men allowed by the Government over all calls heretofore made; but the committee claim an excess of 1,415. Since the 1st of last August, 32,877 men have been enlisted in the City, of whom 21,133 received the bounty. For bounties, $5,660,746 have been expended; for all expenses incident to the work of the Committee, $175,646 90, leaving a cash balance of $639,577 10 on hand, out of $6,946,700, which is the whole sum raised for their use. The Committee also say that a new enrollment will aid in reducing the expected new quota, and they solicit citizens to help in the work of effecting a thoroughly correct enrollment. The Comptroller reported a balance of only $46,333 68 of the $1,200,000 appropriated for the payment of riot damages, and transmitted an ordinance appropriating the further sum of $700,000 authorized by law to be raised, and it was adopted. The Mayor vetoed a bill for iron work on the large drill room on Fifteenth-street, on the ground of excessive prices. The Board adjourned to the 28th inst., at 8 P.M.

abstract: The arrival of Maximilian, May 28
snippet: The arrival of Maximilian, May 28
lead_paragraph: The 28th of May was signalized by the arrival of MAXIMILIAN, of Austria, in what may now be called his new Mexican dominions. The denoument of the invasion has been reached with notable speed. It is barely two years and nine months since the tripartite treaty of London was signed by France, England and Spain; and, looking back to that apparently harmless instrument, it is almost incredible that it should have turned out to be the actual prelude to so grand a tragedy as the overthrow of an independant Commonwealth of eight millions of people. Such is nevertheless the fact.
