abstract: We think it mad be safely asserted that, since war first became known to mankind, no General ever sacrificed his men so recklessly, so remorselessly, and to so little purpose, as Gen. GRANT. He started from his camp on the north side of the Rappahannoek, little more than a month ago, with 130,- 00 men.
lead_paragraph: We think it mad be safely asserted that, since war first became known to mankind, no General ever sacrificed his men so recklessly, so remorselessly, and to so little purpose, as Gen. GRANT. He started from his camp on the north side of the Rappahannoek, little more than a month ago, with 130,- 00 men. He has been reinforced, according to the statements of his friends, by more than 80,000 since that time, viz.: STANTON says he sent him 25,000 veterans after the battle of the 12th of May; BUTLER has sent him 20,000, and prisoners say he has received 40,000 from Ohio and other sources, making a total of 85,000. Yet his army, at this day, in the opinion of those best qualified to judge, does not greatly exceed 100,000 men, and is, certainly, greatly, inferior in numbers to what it was when he started on his crusade. He lost 75,000 in Spottsylvania, and his losses in Hanover cannot have fallen very far short of 25,000. Thus he has sacrificed 100,000 men, the flower not only of his own troops, but of the whole United States army. In return, he has effected nothing, absolutely nothing. LEE's entire loss since the campaign opened does not amount to 17,000, all told, killed, wounded and missing. He has never once been forced from a position, and has only fallen back when his enemy, despairing of victory, has attempted to slide off to his left, and get in rear, without further fighting. GRANT in the meantime has been brought up before MCCLELLAN's old lines beyond the Chickahominy, and is not able to take a single step in advance. He has thrown away 100,000 men to obtain what he could have had for nothing.

abstract: NIBLO's SALOON. -- An interesting concert will be given et this establishment to-night, in aid of a very meritorious object. It is for the benefit of the widow of Lieut. FRANK B. BOUDINOT -- one of the brave fellows who met his death at the battle of the Wilderness. Lieut. BOUDINOT was formerly connected with the Academy of Music, but became a volunteer in the cause of his adopted country. Mrs. BOUDINOT, too, has done good service in the hospitals of the army, and was acting as nurse when the news of her husband's misfortune came to her. These circumstances are surely worthy of remembrance, and will contribute, we hope, to the attendance to-night. The programme itself is very good, and will be interpreted by Mme. de Lussan, Signorita Morensi, Signor Morelli, Mr. Heller, (piano,) Mr. Yelhoar and Mr. Geo. F. Bristow (conductor.)

abstract: Congress, Adjournment of the
snippet: Congress, Adjournment of the
lead_paragraph: Notwithstanding the remonstrances of the Richmond papers, the rebel Congress has adjourned, after a brief session, without a serious attempt to relieve the financial embarrassments of the Jeff. Davis Government Secretary MEMMINGER has made a public statement that he has not a dollar in the treasury wherewith to pay the soldiers. Nor are there any means of meeting the other current expenditures. The enormous taxes which have been levied have been only partially paid; and these payments, having been made in the almost worthless currency, are of little avail. Certificates of indebtedness are not a practicable resort; based on nothing but an airy promise, they command no confidence. The sale of bonds, for the same reason, makes no progress, except as they are hawked at public auction. We publish in another column an official advertisement for the sale at auction of five millions of six per cent. bonds, of late issue, "secured by a pledge of import and future export duties," with other peculiar inducements. Among these inducements is the generous offer to take payment in "treasury notes of the old issues, of the denomination below one hundred dollars, rated at two-thirds the amount promised on the face." It seems to be assumed that a Government which is willing to sell its promissory paper for other promises of its own, with the deduction of only a third, is a Government that ought to inspire a great deal of gratitude and confidence. Yet Americans, whether loyal or rebel, will cling to their old-fashioned notions that it is not business-like to trust men who don't pretend to honor their engagements in full measure. If MEMMINGER's five millions were actually sold at public auction on the 26th of May, as advertised, they must have gone dog-cheap. It is not singular that directly afterward should come the announcement that the treasury is without a dollar.

abstract: The intelligence from Gen. GRANT is very limited. There is nothing from the Army of the Potomac direct.
lead_paragraph: The intelligence from Gen. GRANT is very limited. There is nothing from the Army of the Potomac direct. An arrival at Fortress Monroe, from Bermuda Hundred, reports heavy firing heard in the direction of Bottom's Bridge Monday morning. A dispatch from Washington announces that no positive information had been received from Gen. SHERIDAN, who started on a great raid on Thursday last. He headed for Charlotteville, and it was understood that after visiting that place he would move upon Lynchburgh. We publish elsewhere a list of wounded officers and men who are still in the rebel hospital in the Wilderness; also, a list of deaths of soldiers at the same place since May 6.

abstract: -- This body met at the Centreville Course, Long Island, yesterday, to compete for the prizes awarded for pistol and rifle shooting. As the only parties present mainly belonged to the New-York Sportsmen's Club, little interest mas manifested. The prizes for rifle shooting was won by Mr. JAMES MEYER, Jr., of New-York, his competitors being Mr. CHARLES BRADFORD, of Detroit, Mr. ROYAL PHELPS, of New-York, and Mr. C.E. WHICKEND, of New-York. The distance was 100 yards, off-hand, open sights, rifle, and ammunition unrestricted. To-day the casting of the fly, and base line, and single trap shooting comes off -- the former at Penny Bridge, Gowanus Bay, and the latter at the Centreville Course.

abstract: -- Capt. LORD, of the Sanitary Squad, yesterday arrested JOHN EISMER, proprietor of a fat-boiling establishment, situated at Nos. 2 and 3 Abattoir-place, West Thirty-ninth-street. That officer, in his affidavit, states that a few days since he went to the place in question, and there found about eight barrels of animal fat in the last stages of decomposition; that the effluvia exhaled therefrom was most offensive and injurious, and that its noisome effects extended for many blocks around. He further stated that in a vat capable of containing seven thousand pounds of fat there were from one to two thousand pounds in the boiling process, and that the gasses thus thrown off were highly impure and injurious to health. EISMER was taken before Justice DOWLING at the Tombs, where he demanded an examination, which will be made to-day. Capt. LORD thinks the health and lives of residents in the vicinity of these fat-boiling establishments is much endangered, and he is of the opinion that the nuisances should be promptly suppressed.
lead_paragraph: -- Capt. LORD, of the Sanitary Squad, yesterday arrested JOHN EISMER, proprietor of a fat-boiling establishment, situated at Nos. 2 and 3 Abattoir-place, West Thirty-ninth-street. abstract: AN ELEGANT BOOK. -- A little manual on the preparation of the "Skeleton Bouquet" has just appeared from the press of Messrs. J.E. TILTON & CO., who are becoming famous for their beautiful books. This is a practical treatise on the gathering, preparing and mounting of leaves, seed vessels and flowers, etc., illustrated in a charming style. The volume also contains directions for preserving natural flowers in all their fresh beauty. The volume itself is a work of art. It is called "Skeleton Leaves and Phantom Flowers." -- Boston Transcript.

abstract: -- A distressing accident occurred yesterday in Madison-avenue, resulting in the death of the youngest son of HIRAM BARNEY, Collector of this port, a youth of exceeding brightness and promise, between nine and ten years of age. He had been for some time a pupil in the school of Professor EMIL CHARLIER and just previous to the accident which caused his death, had been playing in Madison-square, in company with the other scholars, under the care of one of the teachers, during the usual noon recess of the school. On leaving the Square the boys were formed in line and crossed the avenue on their way to the school in Twenty-foarth-street. Two or three of the boys lingered behind to take a drink from the hydrant near the park gate, and among them was little CHARLES BARNEY. Just as they started to cross the avenue, an omnibus passed down, and little BARNEY in attempting to run in front at the horses, was in some way knocked down, and before the driver could come to a stop, the front wheel had gone over his body, inflicting injuries which proved fatal. He survived about twenty minutes. The facts as disclosed at the inquest held in the evening, showed that the driver of the omnibus was not in fault, as he was proceeding at the usual rate of speed, and pulled up as soon as possible. The boy was a great favorite in the school, and his sad and sudden death causes great affliction among his schoolmates and teachers.

abstract: -JOHN MULDOON, the young man who was shot with a pistol in the hands of an unknown person, on Sunday morning last, in Mercer-street, died on Monday night, at the New-York Hospital, from the effects of his wounds. Deceased and his assailant were strangers, and became involved in a quarrel at a public house where they accidentally met. Which of them commenced the affray is not yet known. The man with the pistol went outside the house, and discharged his weapon from the sidewalk. He then ran away, and thus far the police have been unable to effect his arrest. Coroner NAUMANN will hold an inquest on the body to-day.

abstract: A meeting assembles this evening at Cooper Institute, to ratify the nominations of LINCOLN and JOHNSON. The renomination of President LINCOLN was so much a matter of course and so universally anticipated, that there is no room and no occasion for that effervescent enthusiasm which greets the selection of a new name. But the public judgment thoroughly and heartily ratifies the action of the Baltimore Convention, and we doubt not a large audience will assemble to give formal expression to this sentiment. Mr. MAYNARD, of Tennessee, an eloquent and able speaker, will be able to give a full and reliable report of the claims and merits of ANDREW JOHNSON, and Gov. WRIGHT, of Indiana, will probably also be present to speak on the general features of the opening canvass. Besides these, local speakers will also be in attendance.
lead_paragraph: A meeting assembles this evening at Cooper Institute, to ratify the nominations of LINCOLN and JOHNSON. abstract: -- One of the most extensive robberies ever committed in New-Haven occurred in this city yesterday noon. It was no less than the summary appropriation of Â£1,039 in English sovereigns and half-sovereigns, from the residence of Capt. H.J. BOWN. No. 11 Liberty-court. Capt. BOWN arrived in New-York on Wednesday last from Southampton, in the steamship Bremen. On the passage he made the acquaintance of JAMES JOHNSON and JOHN PENNOCK, of London, and WILLIAM GILL, of Bradford, Yorkshire. The acquaintance ripened into friendship, and on Saturday Capt. BOWN invited his English friends to come up to New-Haven and spend the Sabbath, Messrs. GILL and JOHNLON owned this bag of gold, with which they proposed to start some kind of business in this country. PENNOCK was destitute of money, but being a friend, he was brought over at their expense, with the intention also of establishing in business. Previous to coming to New-Haven, Capt. BOWN advised Messrs. GILL and JOHNSON to place their money in the bank for safe keeping. They acted on the suggestion but partially, and brought the balance with them. The gold was in a bag, the bag inclosed in a satchel, and all left under a bed in one of Capt. BOWN's chambers. Yesterday afternoon, BOWN, GILL and JOHNSON started off for a walk. PENNECK complained of headache and remained at the house. Returning after an hour or two, Mr. JOHNSON casually looked for his treasure, and discovered that the bag had been out and the money gone. Mr. PENNOCK was also missing. The police were immediately notified, and the usual precaution taken to secure the thief, but thus far unsuccessfully. A friend of all parties, an Englishman, named JOHN TIFFIN, was arrested in the afternoon as an accomplice, but there being no evidence against him he was discharged. At the present rate of gold, the thief is in upward of $10,000. There is a good opportunity for experienced detectives to show their expertness. -- New-Haven Journal, June 14.

abstract: The Spanish Difficulty with
snippet: The Spanish Difficulty with
lead_paragraph: -The news which we publish this morning from the South, is chiefly of interest as showing not only the unabated vigor with which the Government of Peru is putting itself in an attitude to repel the threatened attack on its independence by Spain, but also the spirit of enthusiasm with which the sister Republics have taken up the cause of Peru. Troops are being raised and drilled all over the country. Peruvian agents have been sent as far as California to procure the materiel of war; an iron-clad is in process of construction at Callao, and at that place important defensive works are in course of construction. The United States of Colombia formally declare that they will make common cause with Peru. In Valparaiso the authorities have forbidden the exportation of provisions, coals, &c., for the Spanish fleet in the Pacific; and the Government had also put an embargo on a vessel with a large quantity of powder on board, supposed to be for Admiral PINZON's fleet. Everywhere, indeed, the excitement and the enthusiasm on behalf of Peru was intense. Everything betokened an early retreat by the Spanish agents from their present dangerous and untenable ground.

abstract: As this question is frequently asked, we will simply say that she is a lady who, for upward of thirty years, has untiringly devoted her time and talents as a female physician and nurse, principally among children. She has especially studied the constitution and wants of this numerous class, and, as a result of this effort, and practical knowledge, obtained in a lifetime spent as nurse and physician, she has compounded a Soothing Syrup for children teething. It operates like magic -- giving rest and health, and is, moreover, sure to regulate the bowels. In consequence of this article Mrs. WINSLOW is becoming world-renowned as a benefactor of her race; children certainty do RISE UP and bless her; especially is this the case in this City. Vast quantities of the SOOTHING SYRUP are daily sold and used here. We think Mrs. WINSLOW has immortalized her name by this invaluable article, and we sincerely believe thousands of children have been saved from an early grave by its timely use, and that millions yet unborn will share its benefits and unite in calling her blessed. No mother has discharged her duty to her suffering little one, in our opinion, until she has given it the benefit of Mrs. WINSLOW's SOOTHING SYRUP. Try it, mothers -- TRY IT NOW. -- Ladies' Visitor, New-York City.

abstract: By the arrival of the Royal Mail steamship Scotia, we have dates from Liverpool to the 4th inst. Mr. DAYTON, the United States Minister at Paris, having made representations to the French Government, which were deemed satisfactory, that the war-vessels being built at Bordeaux and Nantes were intended for the Confederates, it was ordered that they should not be permitted to leave the ports where they are building. Two delegates are said to have been appointed by the French Government to proceed to America, ascertain the real state and prospects of the belligerents, and report the same to the Emperor. It is also reported that overtures have been made by France to the British Government, with a view to stopping the frightful and useless carnage between the Federals and Confederates. The London Times takes a very dismal view of affairs at the North, and is fully prepared to hear of the defeat of GRANT. In the House of Commons it was stated that the telegraph, which is intended to bring the Old and New World in communication by way of Behrings, is actually in course of execution. The Dano-German Conference reassembled in London on 2d of June, and on rising appointed the 6th of June for the next sitting. Notice has been given that the blockade of the ports which were raised on the 12th of May will, unless negotiations are carried on at the London Conference leading at least to some preliminary arrangements, be resumed on the 12th of June.

abstract: Speech at Union Meeting N. Y.
snippet: Speech at Union Meeting N. Y.
lead_paragraph: Last evening one of the largest, most earnest and enthusiastic audiences ever assembled at Cooper Institute, gathered there, filling it to and beyond its capacity, to respond to and ratify the nomination of ABRAHAM LINCOLN and ANDREW JOHNSON for President and Vice-President, for four years from the 4th of March next. All classes of citizens, all parties were represented, and all united in a glad and enthusiastic recognition of the patriotic services, the stern integrity, and the tried ability of President LINCOLN, and in warmest approval of the selection as his coadjutor of the tested and trusty patriot, ANDREW JOHNSON. The opening of the campaign, in this meeting, indicates the Union success. It foreshadowed, the uprising of men, the length and breadth of the country, undirected by party leaders, untrammeled by party feeling and prejudices, devoted solely to the safety of their country, the cause of the Union. Never has there been so unmistakable a demonstration. It was almost impromptu, too, for but brief notice had been given of the meeting to the loyal thousands assembled. A large number of ladies by their presence lent encouraging approval to the objects of the meeting.

abstract: EAST TENNESSEE. -- Our advices from Greene County, in Upper East Tennessee, are most gratifying. A week or so ago, Maj. DAVE FRY, whose name is a terror to all rebels, ascertained that JOHN ARNOLD, JOHN FITZPATRICK, SAM. DAVIS and other rebel thieves were in Greeneville, and immediately determined to capture them or give them a devil of a thrashing. He gathered together a number of our gallant mountain boys, and, with a few regular soldiers, DAVE surrounded the town. The whole affair was managed with such admirable secrecy that they were taken wholly by surprise, and report says that each man looked out for himself, without regard to rank or character for pluck. About twelve were killed in the attack. Some thirty were captured, but all but about twenty died on their way to Knoxville. Lieut. REYNOLDS, a brother of the noted Captain of that name, died suddenly. -- Chattanooga Gazette, June 7.

abstract: Labor Lost
snippet: Labor Lost
lead_paragraph: A revolving squirrel cage is funny enough. But what sensitive nature can regard it without feeling a certain pity for the little animals within? Such ceasless clambering, now here, and now there, and yet nowhere the gaining of so much as one poor inch! You may not care a button for les petites betes dedans; you may indeed reflect that they are classed as vermin, both by men of science and by plain farmers, and yet their fruitless efforts excite a vague commiseration. We confess to something of this feeling -- aversion and diversion, tinged with compassion -- whenever we contemplate the little hopping writers and speakers inside of the Copperhead party. Truly they have a weary time of it -- these scribbling and spouting demagogues -- and all for nothing. The best they can do is to keep the party in a whirl. Not a jot of real progress is made. So it has been from the beginning.

abstract: Grant's Army South of Richmond
snippet: Grant's Army South of Richmond
lead_paragraph: The official intelligence from Gen. GRANT's army which we publish this morning effectually removes the mystery which has hung around its movements since the great battle of the Chickahominy. We are not only put in possession of the general fact of a change of base having been made from the White House to the James, but the details are supplied in so clear and intelligible a form that even those least familiar with the topography of Southeastern Virginia will be at little loss to comprehend the present position of the army.

abstract: Gen. McClellan's Address; Address at Dedication of West Point Battle Monument; Speech at Dedication of West Point Battle Monument
snippet: Gen. McClellan's Address; Address at Dedication of West Point Battle Monument; Speech at Dedication of West Point Battle Monument
lead_paragraph: Yesterday afternoon the site for the proposed Battle Monument at West Point to the memory of the officers and privates of the regular army who have fallen in the war for the Union, was dedicated with appropriate ceremonies. The site selected for the monument is near the northern extremity of the grounds, and west of the hotel. Here a stand had been erected for the orator of the day. It was beautifully decorated with flags and other emblems of Union and nationality. On the stand were Brig.-Gen. ANDERSON, who presided; Maj.-Gen. McClellan, Gov. Seymour, Maj.-Gen. Gordon Granger, Maj.-Gen. Kilpatrick, Brig.-Gen. Meagher, Brig.-Gen. Hays, Col. Bowman, Prof. Davis, and the Board of Visitors.

abstract: It will be seen from the European news by the Scotia, which we publish in other columns, that the conference on the Dano-German question makes no progress whatever. The German delegates demand that Flensburg and Duppel shall be surrendered by Denmark. The neutral Powers go for curtailing the Danish boundary only at the line of the Dannewerke. There are, however, no indications that Denmark will accept even the proposition of the intervening Powers, and taking this view, the London Times makes the declaration -- which we take to be semi-official -- that the Danes are right in believing that even non-intervening England and unsympathetic France can never allow Denmark to be blotted out of the list of nations.

abstract: The news from Gen. GRANT this morning is of great importance. Secretary STANTON announces that the movement to the south side of the James, foreshadowed in previous dispatches, has been successfully accomplished. It began on Sunday night Gen. SMITH'S corps marching to the White House, and embarking on transports for Bermuda Hundred. The main portion of the
lead_paragraph: The news from Gen. GRANT this morning is of great importance. Secretary STANTON announces that the movement to the south side of the James, foreshadowed in previous dispatches, has been successfully accomplished. It began on Sunday night Gen. SMITH'S corps marching to the White House, and embarking on transports for Bermuda Hundred. The main portion of the army took up the line of march toward the James -- BURNSIDE and WRIGHT crossing the Chickahominy at Long Bridge, and the corps of HANCOCK and WARREN at the Jones Bridge -- both bridges only in name, pontoons being used by our forces. BURNSIDE and WRIGHT then moved for Charles City, and struck the James south of that point, HANCOCK and WARREN going to Wilcox's Landing, some distance farther up the river. At 1 o'clock of Tuesday Gen. GRANT was at Bermuda Hundred, and the army was then crossing. Gen. SMITH's corps had already begun to arrive in transports.

abstract: The visitors to the Fashion Course, yesterday, were counted by thousands, as we anticipated would be the case. It was a dense compact throng of swaying humanity. So intense was the excitement in all classes of society, concerning the meeting of the three trotting celebrities -- Fillingham, Morgan, and Butler. It will be seen by the result which was not accomplished until darkness had set in, that the magnates of the trotting turf were all abroad, and the aognoscenti -- so usually well posted -- taken in. The late hour at which the final decision was arrived at, the utter impossibility of our giving space to the full and graphic report of a centest, which is a perfect novelty in trotting annals, compels us to confine ourselves to a summary of the result. Our report will appear in full to-morrow:

lead_paragraph: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of all millitary movements in the different departments from the pens of our special correspondents. Also, all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news, European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, giving the tone of public feeling abroad, made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports; items of agricultural and domestic interest, compiled from sources many of which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader; and marriages and deaths of the week.

abstract: Speech at New-York Early-Closing Meeting; City; Early-Closing Association, Mass Meeting; Speech at N. Y. Early Closing Meeting
snippet: Speech at New-York Early-Closing Meeting; City; Early-Closing Association, Mass Meeting; Speech at N. Y. Early Closing Meeting
lead_paragraph: A mass meeting of the Early Closing Associations was held last evening at Union-square, having for its object the abridgement of hours of labor. Not less than fifteen thousand people were present, and the utmost enthusiasm prevailed throughout the entire proceedings. A stand for speakers had been erected at the lower end of the square, and before 8 o'clock Fourteenth-street, between Broadway and University-place, was thronged. At that hour, several associations coming up Broadway and Fourth-avenue, marched to the front of the speaker's stand, and took their positions in line. Among them -- all bearing transparencies on which were inscribed appropriate mottoes -- were the Salesmen and Cutters, Furniture and Carpet Clerks, Boot and Shoe Clerks and the Dry Goods Clerks Early Closing Associations. The scene was enlivened by pyrotechnic displays, firing of cannon, and music from the Seventh Regiment Band. Shortly after 8 o'clock, Mr. O.M. MOORE called the meeting to order, and nominated for Chairman Ex-Mayor OPDYKE, who was unanimously elected.

abstract: ANOTHER MERCHANT ROBBED BY AN EMPLOYE. -- A young man named EDWARD MATHEWS, residing at No. 33 Allen-street, was arrested yesterday afternoon by Sergeant WALSH and Officer GOLDER, of the Sixth Ward, on the charge of having committed a series of thefts by stealing from his late employer, Mr. C.H. LILIENTHAL, tobacconist, of this City. MATHEWS has been in the employ of LILIENTHAL for several years. During the last eighteen months he has, according to his own confession, been in the habit of purloining tin foil and selling it to ANTHONY CROSSIN, of No. 77 Baxter-street, at the rate of nine cents a pound; its real value being nearly four times that sum. In this way tin foil valued at over $5,000 has been stolen and disposed of by the accused. The quantity in the receiver's hands became so great at length that the latter refused to take any more from MATHEWS in original packages, and it was finally agreed that the foil should be melted before it was delivered to CROSSIN. MATHEWS therefore rented a room in Centre-street, where for some time past he has been in the habit of melting the foil. MATHEWS was committed to the Tombs by Justice DOWLING, and the receiver was required to find bail in the sum of $1,000 to answer.

abstract: Ministerial Crisis in
snippet: Ministerial Crisis in
lead_paragraph: -- There is another crisis in Canada, the result of a vote of the House of Assembly censuring the present Minister of Finance for a mal-appropriation of public moneys five years ago. The money in question was handed to the Grand Trunk Railway by a roundabout process. The facts were developed some time ago in the report of the Financial Commission, and the radical Opposition in Parliament have just found themselves strong enough to pass a sort of non-confidence vote, specially directed against the offending Minister. The practice of singling out a particular Minister for parliamentary censure is not an unusual one in England. The Duke of Newcastle's administration of the War Office during the Crimean campaign is one of the most notable cases in point. So that the Provincials, for once, are backed up in their faction fights by the parliamentary usages of the Imperial Parliament. We believe this is the eighth crisis they have indulged in during the last two years.

abstract: -A few days since a noisy Copperhead was proclaiming the popularity of Gen. MCCLELLAN, in the cars, between Philadelphia and New-York. Discovering a soldier in the car, he approached him and inquired who he went for for next President. The soldier replied, "GEORGE B. MCCLELLAN." The Copperhead made loud proclamation of the fact to the passengers. The veteran soon became a Copperhead lion. Elated at his sudden popularity, he took off his coat and showed two wounds on his arm, received at the battle of Gettysburgh. At this interesting juncture a military detective entered the car, and confronted the McClellan soldier. After a little conversation he left, but soon returned with two soldiers. The wounded warrior of Gettysburgh was unceremoniously arrested and handcuffed. It turned out that he was an escaped prisoner from Fort Delaware, and belonged to the Ninth Georgia Regiment. He had got off in the stolen clothes of a Union soldier. Of course, his new friends loved him all the better for this, but they didn't like to manifest it under the circumstances. -- Treton Gazette.

abstract: Constitutional Amendment, Rejection by the House; Legislature in favor of Slavery Constitutional Amendment
snippet: Constitutional Amendment, Rejection by the House; Legislature in favor of Slavery Constitutional Amendment
lead_paragraph: The Anti-Administration portion of the House, arraying itself against the proposition to submit this amendment to the States, has deprived it of the requisite two-thirds, and an end is thus made of it for the present Congress. The vote stood ninety-four Yeas to sixty-five Nays, only four Democrats -- BAILEY, GRISWOLD, ODELL and WHEELER -- voting in its favor. We deeply regret this. It imposes a needless delay upon the consummation of a great measure, without which the struggle between the South and the North can reach no end. Reconstruction is impossible so long as Slavery exists in the land. The institution, in instigating the rebellion, has committed an inexpiable crime, and the people are fixed in their determination that it shall die the death. Its Northern friends are doing it but a poor service in seeking to prolong its agony. They are doing the country a worse service yet. The public mind, so long harrassed by questions touching Slavery, needs repose. It is high time that a definite and final policy were settled upon -- that the only solid foundation for a reconstruction should be recognized and accepted.

abstract: in Mexico; Gen. Santa Anna in
snippet: in Mexico; Gen. Santa Anna in
lead_paragraph: It would be a strange Mexican revolution in which Gen. SANTA ANNA should not be either one of the chief agents, or the prime victim. The news of his appointment to the post of Grand Marshal of the Empire, the very foremost in the gift of the new Sovereign, is followed this morning by the report that the ex-Dictator is to be brought from his place of exile in the vessel that conveyed MAXIMILIAN to his new dominions, with all the circumstance and pomp that the new Imperial Government can extemporize in his honor. But a few months ago the venerable ex-President was promptly ordered out of Mexico by the French Commanding General -- for what reason, except from a remembrance of the chastisement the Mexican chieftain had inflicted on the French some thirty years ago at Vera Cruz. What else could have made him obnoxious to the Emperor's agent? A master of intrigue; brave but treacherous; chivalrous in action, crafty in council, ready to risk his all in a bold adventure, yet sordid, avaricious and corrupt where plunder was to be had -- what other name in cotemporary history presents half the requisites for the military and political task which must appertain to the Grand Marshal of the Empire of Mexico?
headline: {'main': 'First Grand Marshal Santa Anna.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'First Grand Marshal Santa Anna.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: There is no official dispatch from Washington this morning concerning army operations. The latest intelligence is from our special correspondents up to Wednesday morning, at which time the Army of the Potomac was all on the south side of the James.
lead_paragraph: There is no official dispatch from Washington this morning concerning army operations. The latest intelligence is from our special correspondents up to Wednesday morning, at which time the Army of the Potomac was all on the south side of the James. Generals WARREN and BURNSIDE crossed at Haxall's Landing, which is just above City Point, while HANCOCK and WRIGHT crossed at Fort Powhatan, ten miles below. The entire march and crossing were accomplished without any interruption from the enemy. Gen. SMITH's corps, which went around by water, arrived at Bermuda Hundred on Tuesday evening, and at two o'clock on Wednesday morning moved out with orders to attack Petersburgh. Heavy firing was heard there during the forenoon, but no intelligence of the result has yet been received.

abstract: England is not what you may call a warm country. The ponds have been frozen this present June. Potatoes in Yorkshire are frozen to the ground. Coal fires are among the comforts of life. abstract: -HIS DEPARTURE FOR WEST POINT. -- Gen. SUOTT attained on Monday last his 78th year, and it will be gratifying to his fellow countrymen to know that he enjoys excellent health and spirits. The General has just completed the Memoirs of his Life, and has given them out for publication, contracting that they must be ready for issue early in July. Messrs. SHELDON & GO, are the publishers. The work is anxiously awaited by the public. The General left his apartments at Delmonico's last week, proceeding to Cozzens' Hotel, at West Point, where he proposes spending the Summer months. He continues to take his usual daily drives, and, advanced in years as he is, appears as erect and as soldierly as when he led his triumphant troops to the gates of Mexico.

abstract: In the Senate yesterday a resolution was offered directing the Secretary of the Navy to transmit to the Senate copies of the proceedings of the Naval Court Martial, in the case of C.W. SCOFIELD, Naval Contractor. The bill for the speedy punishment of guerrillas as was called up but no action was taken. The Senate then resumed the consideration of the Tariff Bill. At the evening session a report was received from the committee on the disagreeing votes on the bill to equalize the pay of the soldiers of the army of the United States, which was agreed to, after which the consideration of the Tariff Bill was resumed.

abstract: The friends of this regiment will be glad to learn that they have, as usual, nobly done their part in the grand movement of SHERMAN's army upon Atlanta. They participated in the battles of Rocky-faced Ridge, May 7; Resaca, May 15; and of Dallas, May 25. On the morning of May 15, the One Hundred and Second New-York and One Hundred and Eleventh Pennsylvania Regiments, forming a forlorn hope, were ordered to charge up a hill occupied by the enemy, and capture a battery that was interfering with the movements of our forces. The One Hundred and Second New-York, led by their gallant Colonel, JAMES C. LANE, marched up the hill in line of battle as steadily and in as straight a line as if on a dress parade, although all the war under a severe fire from the enemy, Immediately in front of the battery were rifle pits, occupied by a strong force; but after a severe fight, the enemy were driven out, and the battery, consisting of four guns, captured and sent into our lines. This brilliant operation was considered so hazardous, that officers high in rank who saw it commenced, expected both regiments would be annihilated. After its successful completion, Gen. HOOKER, the Corps Commander, personally complimented Col. LANE and his brave command for the splendid manner in which they had executed the work.
lead_paragraph: The friends of this regiment will be glad to learn that they have, as usual, nobly done their part in the grand movement of SHERMAN's army upon Atlanta. abstract: The annual commencement of this institution took place at the Calvary Baptist Church in Twenty-third-street, near Fifth-avenue, a few evenings since. There was a large audience in attendance. The exercises consisted of the reading of compositions written by the graduates, and vocal and instrumental music. But the most attractive feature of the occasion was the reading of the reports by the several committees on the branches of studies pursued by the young ladies, and read by Prof. OWEN of the Free Academy, and others. These reports illustrated the course of instruction pursued by the pupils in that institution. The compositions written by the young ladies were creditable to their authors and the mental discipline of the school. The highest honors were conferred upon the following young ladies: In French, Miss Nettie M. Bradley. Penmanship, senior department, B. Price; Mid., J. Bradley. Composition, the first honor to Sarah P. Baldwin; second, Vienna Young. In Mathematics, first honor to Sarah P. Baldwin; second, Vienna Young.

abstract: About 2 o'clock yesterday morning a fire broke out in the rear of the second floor of the large six-story building Nos. 7 and 9 Mott-street, near Chatham owned, and occupied principally, by Messrs. POMEROY  SCHENCK, feather-bed manufacturers. Owing to the highly combustible nature of the contents, the flames spread with great rapidity, and the entire structure was soon destroyed.
lead_paragraph: About 2 o'clock yesterday morning a fire broke out in the rear of the second floor of the large six-story building Nos. 7 and 9 Mott-street, near Chatham owned, and occupied principally, by Messrs. POMEROY SCHENCK, feather-bed manufacturers. Owing to the highly combustible nature of the contents, the flames spread with great rapidity, and the entire structure was soon destroyed. The aggregate loss is estimated at over $75,000; partially insured. The origin of the fire is unknown.

abstract: Postage on Manuscripts, regulations for
snippet: Postage on Manuscripts, regulations for
lead_paragraph: The amended Postal Law, which went into effect last July, prescribes (section 24) "that book manuscripts and corrected proofs, passing between authors and publishers, may pass at the rates of printed matter." The intent of this provision is clear: It is that all manuscripts, intended for publication, and containing no private communication, shall pass through the mails at printed rates. The object of the law is evident: It was to secure to the department the profit of carrying these manuscripts, a great proportion of which, if subject to letter postage, would go by express. For months, such manuscripts sent to magazines and newspapers went at this rate; but of late the Post-office Department, as is shown by the following official notice, has taken a different view of this provision:

abstract: The news this morning is of a very definite and satisfactory character. Gen. GRANT's rapid movement to the south side of the James River, has already brought forth very important results. Gen. SMITH, who moved on Wednesday morning, at 2 A.M., attack Pettersburgh met the enemy in their works and after a severe fight, lasting, with interruptions, until dark that evening, he succeeded in carrying the two principal lines of works in front of that city, capturing from three to four hundred prisoners and sixteen cannon. This important success put the city at once under our guns, and compelled the enemy to evacuate it, which they did, moving westward across the Appomattox. The place had been defended by BEAUREGARD and WISE. In the action the colored division of Gen. HINKS took a prominent part, displaying the greatest gallantry. They stormed the strongest portion of the rebel line, took many prisoners and six of the sixteen guns. Gen. SMITH publicly thanked them for their essential service. By dark of Wednesday, Gen. HANCOCK had formed a junction with SMITH, and the whole army was across the James, and rapidly moving forward. The latest information is up to noon of Thursday, at which time a report had reached Bermuda Landing that our troops were in actual occupation of Petersburgh. The same day Gen. BUTLER ascertained that the rebel works in his front were abandoned, and he immediately advanced upon the Richmond and Petersburgh Railroad and commenced its destruction.

abstract: We have published several complimentary notices in our correspondence from Gen. SHERMAN's army of what is known as the Indiana Division of new troops, commanded by Gen. A.P. HOVEY. Although these troops have been but recently mustered and equipped, and were compelled by the exigences of the service to march to the front without any preparation whatever, they have borne a conspicuous part in the Georgia campaign. The rebels, learning that they were new troops, have on several occasions charged and stormed positions held by them, but without success. The Hoosiers repulsed them each time with dreadful slaughter, and have been repeatedly complimented by their Commanding-Generals for their gallantry and heroism.
lead_paragraph: We have published several complimentary notices in our correspondence from Gen. SHERMAN's army of what is known as the Indiana Division of new troops, commanded by Gen. A.P. HOVEY. abstract: -- In the list of killed of the One Hundred and Thirty-ninth Regiment, published the other day in the TIMES, occurs the name Sergt. F.A. PARKAURST, of Company K, who fell bravely in the ranks in that terrible conflict which reduced the nombers of the regiment from 500 to 160, on the memorable first days of June. Sergt. PARKHURST was the husband of Mrs. PARKHURST, the musical composer. This lady supports herself and daughter by her musical compositions, and several of her ballad pieces have attained much popularity.

abstract: THE LATE HOMICIDE AT PIER NO. 3 NORTH RIVER. -- An inquest was held yesterday by Coroner WILDEY on the body of JOHN BRENNAN, the young man who was stabbed late on Tuesday afternoon last at Pier No. 3 North River, by HENRY HAWKER, an account of which has appeared in the TIMES. HAWKER was a steward and deceased a sailor on board the steamship Northern Light during her last trip to this port. While at sea they became involved in a quarrel, and it was finally agreed that the matter should be settled between them by a free fight, without weapons of any kind, as soon as the two landed in New-York. The testimony in the case showed that as soon as the two belligerents reached the pier HAWKER, in violation of his agreement not to use weapons, ran up to deceased with a knife and stabbed the latter in the left breast, from the effects of which he died soon after. Dr. BOUTON made a post-mortem examination, when he found the knife had entered the victim's heart to the extent of two inches. The jury found a verdict in accordance with the above facts. The accused has been committed to the Tombs, to await the action of the Grand Jury. Deceased was a quiet, inoffensive man. He had been eighteen months in the service of the Government. He was on board the gunboat Cincinnati when she was sunk off Vicksburgh, and was afterward connected with the steam gunboat Choctaw, on an expedition up the Red River.

abstract: The trot for the purse and stake of $350, play or pay, mile heats, best three in five, in harness, which came off on Friday, June 17, attracted a large attendance of the leading members of the trotting turf, although it was an "off-day," and they had scarcely recovered from the excitement of the great Butler, Fillingham and Morgan contest of Wednesday. The original entry for this trot was the sorrel gelding Dan Mace, (better known in trotting circles as Sorrel Dan,) the brown gelding Tartar, and the well-known horse Keystone, but the latter having died since the entry was made, viz., on the same morning that George M. Patcken departed in the afternoon, this match was reduced to a match between Dan Mace and Tartar. The following is the result:

abstract: -- The liberality of the American Telegraph Company, and the enterprise of Postmaster PEASE, have supplied the suburb of Yorkville with all the conveniences of a general and local telegraph. In the post-office building -- and fitted up by the present incumbent at his own risk -- are all the requisite telegraphic apparatus and appliances for transmitting messages any distance from half a league to five thousand miles the whole conducted with the most business-like order and correctness by two lady operators (the Misses PEASE,) who were, we believe, among the first, if not the very first, in the City to set an example to the educated members of their sex in a department of skilled labor which offers so many openings for careful, patient and intelligent industry. The combined conveniences of a post-office, with a house delivery of letters three times a day, and a box delivery from seven in the morning till eight or nine at night, and of a telegraph and express at work, at all reasonable hours, in the same commodious building, are subjects of legitimate congratulation, alike for the worthy enterprisers and the general public.

abstract: Citizens' Association Reforms
snippet: Citizens' Association Reforms
lead_paragraph: Amid the absorbing interest in the progress of the war the public have hardly had leisure to notice a great and beneficent work of peace that has been going on in our City. The "Citizens' Association," it will be remembered, was founded by some of our most eminent citizens, during the past year, for the purpose of securing a pure, efficient and economical City Government. Their labors in Albany to reduce the tax-levy, during the last Winter, are well known to the public. Beside this, they have already formed a large and permanent organization in the various Wards of the City, in order to present candidates of honesty and character, who, if elected, will benefit the community instead of robbing it. Each Ward is to have an executive Committee of 100 persons, representing all classes and conditions within it; of this number each election district will furnish 8 or 9 who will again subdivide the district into blocks, and whose duty it will be to visit every voter, and thus influence him to join the Association or elect its candidates. In this way each Ward will be thoroughly organized, every voter will be known, and the members of the Association will attend the polls, so as to prevent all illegal voting. When this organization is fully completed through the city, there will be some two thousand persons engaged, without regard to politics, in securing the election of honest, upright and competent men for the various offices of our Municipal Government. There will be then a mighty organized force in New-York whose aim is honesty, purity and justice in our municipal affairs. The reform movement, which has made so many spasmodic efforts during the last fifteen years, will then be warmly supported by the masses of intelligent mechanics and small property holders, who see in it the lightening of their burdens and taxes, and it will be pecuniarily propped up by the wealthy classes, who will have learnt by bitter experience that such a movement is absolutely necessary for their interests.
headline: {'main': 'The New City Reform.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The New City Reform.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Grant's Operations
snippet: Grant's Operations
lead_paragraph: Operations have been commenced in earnest south of the James. The entire army under Gen. GRANT has made a safe and speedy crossing, in compact order, and at a point almost within sight of what must be the scene at last of a stupendous and decisive struggle. Discarding a premature telegram, announcing the entry of Gen. W.F. SMITH into Petersburgh on Thursday, we find in the official dispatches addressed to the War Office sufficient evidence of successes achieved to silence even the most persistent cavilers. Gen. SMITH appears to have led the advance from the south bank of the James, having started direct for Petersburgh, with 15,000 men, at early dawn on Wednesday morning. By 4 o'clock in the afternoon of that day, SMITH had carried a line of intrenchments at a place named Beatty's House, the colored troops being conspicuous for the dash and gallantry with which they assaulted and carried the rebel works. At this time HANCOCK's Corps was within three miles of SMITH, and was hurrying forward to his support. Before, however, any assistance had arrived the gallant Eighteenth had carried the enemy's principal line in front of Petersburgh, and before night had closed in, on Wednesday, Gen. SMITH had gained a position commanding Petersburgh, two miles from the town, and had captured thirteen cannon, several stand of colors, and between three and four hundred prisoners.

abstract: The ordination of Rev. W.H. COOKS, Rector of Trinity Church, Lansingburgh, as a Priest of the Episcopal Church, took place to-day, commencing at 10 1/2 o'clock this morning. Bishop POTTER reached the church at an early hour from Saratoga. In the exercises he was assisted by fifteen clergymen, among them Rev. Drs. COIT and TUCKER, Messrs. POTTER, MAXCY, WALTHINGTON, WALSH, ROBINSON and WAINWRIGHT. The ceremonies were exceedingly imposing, and the ordination and confirmation were preceded by a sermon from Rev. Dr. TUCKER, of the Church of the Holy Cross in this city, who took as his text the first chapter of Galatians, eighth to thirteenth verses. -- Troy Times, June 15.

abstract: Our information from Georgia is to the effect that the efforts of the rebel sharpshooters to pick off our officers is fearfully successful -- much more so, indeed, than ever before. Most of them use a recently imported Whitworth gun, which is said to be superior to anything in use by our forces. It is understood that the rebels say as much as $1,500 apiece for these guns. We do not know the kind of money used, but suppose gold or sterling exchange, as Johnny Bu[???]l, from whom they were purchased, would probably insist on good money. One of the guns was captured the other side of Resaca, some time since, in this way: A sharpshooter (rebel) climbed into a tree, and tied a handkerchief round his wrist to prevent his falling in case he should be wounded. The rebel was not more than comfortably fixed, before a Federal sharpshooter fired a shot through his neck and instantly killed him. He hung to the tree until our lines extended to the spot, when he was cut down and his gun taken.

abstract: The Cleveland Convention and its results do not create any sensations here, nor indeed, scarcely attract any attention. The delegates self-constitut ed comprise about the entire party, and are, for the most part, their own only constituency. It is not believed here that FREMONT will consent to have his name paraded before the country as the candidate of such an incongruous and motley assemblage as gathered at Cleveland.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO, Monday, June 6, 1864.

abstract: MYSTERIOUS DOINGS.--The citizens, soldiers, emigrants and others who frequent the Battery, have been entertained, of late, with a series of performances which cast those of HELLER or the DAVENPORTS quite in the shade. There seems, indeed, to be a sort of magical atmosphere hanging over the City just now, from which all kinds of strange doings are eliminated from time to time.
lead_paragraph: MYSTERIOUS DOINGS. -- The citizens, soldiers, emigrants and others who frequent the Battery, have been entertained, of late, with a series of performances which cast those of HELLER or the DAVENPORTS quite in the shade. There seems, indeed, to be a sort of magical atmosphere hanging over the City just now, from which all kinds of strange doings are eliminated from time to time. The exhibitions on the Battery are the work of two sailors, said to be Portuguese, and are apparently intended merely for their own amusement, though the men are not averse to receiving small donations of postage stamps. Their contortions are quite wonderful, and the manner in which they cast off their jackets without other movement than a species of muscular spasm, not using their hands in the least, is really singular, reminding one of the way in which a snake digests himself of his skin in August. One of these men is talkative and agreeable. He calls himself ZAN-ZAN, and says the other is his mate. The latter is tactiturn to a degree, and performs his curious mystifications with a sublimely solemn countenance. Several hundreds have witnessed these tricks within a week past, and have been equally surprised and delighted thereby.

abstract: Journal of Commerce on the Church's Duty to the State; Pennsylvania Prot. Episcopal Convention on Duty in the War
snippet: Journal of Commerce on the Church's Duty to the State; Pennsylvania Prot. Episcopal Convention on Duty in the War
lead_paragraph: During the late sittings of the Pennsylvania Episcopal Convention, the members were divided on the question of adopting certain resolutions bearing on the rebellion and the prosecution of the war for its suppression. Two sets of resolutions were proposed, the textual difference between which, so far as we have been able to analyze them, consisting mainly in the emphasis of certain expletives employed for the purpose of characterizing the agents of the rebellion. The pith and marrow of the resolutions -- that which really gave them purpose and meaning -- is as well brought out in what we take to be the "Conservative" set, whose adoption followed the discussion, as in the less temperate substitute offered by the minority. Thus, while the radical portion of the convention proposed to formally, "as a body of Christian men, pledge to the Government their prayers, sympathy, and support," the majority proposed, "that we hereby declare our unfaltering allegiance to the Government of the United States, that we pledge it our willing devotion and service, and that as a body of Christians we will ever pray that in God's own time and way this rebellion may be put down, and that oppression and Slavery in all its forms may be done away."

abstract: FROM GEN. HUNTER AND THE FIRST WEST VIRGINIA INFANTRY. -- Capt. MELVIN, of the First West Virginia Infantry, arrived in the city yesterday directly from Staunton, bringing with him a list of the casualties in his regiment during the recent fight at Piedmont, near Staunton. Capt. MELVIN was wounded by a shot in the right shoulder, which disabled him. The First Infantry were the first Union soldiers that ever entered the town, never before having been occupied by the Union forces. Capt. MELVIN brings a rebel flag, captured in a desperate charge by his regiment, which he yesterday presented to the Governor. The regimental flag of the First is riddled with bullets, and the gallant regiment should be presented with a new one at once, -- Wheeling Intelligencer, June 17.

abstract: ARRIVAL OF THE ELEVENTH MASSACHUSETTS REGIMENT. -- Two hundred men of the Eleventh Massachusetts Regiment, under command of Lieut.-Col. TRIPP, arrived in Jersey City at an early hour yesterday morning, having left the army at Cold Harbor. An equal number of men, some of them reenlisted, and other recruits, remain in the service under command of Col. BLAISDELL, and retain the regimental organization. No regiment from Massachusetts can point to a more gallant record than the Eleventh. From the first battle of Bull Run to the battle of Cold Harbor, this regiment has passed three years of eventful service in the campaigns in Virginia, Pennsylvania and Maryland. They brought with them the colors presented by the State, and the national banner, which they have proudly borne in many a battle. They left yesterday afternoon in the Fall River boat for home.

abstract: On Wednes  day last RUSSELL CHAPMAN, on going into the backroom of the second story of his leather store, corner of Chapel and Gregson streets, with a customer, found a lad apparently asleep, but subsequent investigation proved him to be dead, and the body partly decomposed. It was found to be the body of WM. LEADEN, aged 14, son of Mr. MICHAEL LEADEN, of No. 6 Gregson ...
lead_paragraph: On Wednes day last RUSSELL CHAPMAN, on going into the backroom of the second story of his leather store, corner of Chapel and Gregson streets, with a customer, found a lad apparently asleep, but subsequent investigation proved him to be dead, and the body partly decomposed. It was found to be the body of WM. LEADEN, aged 14, son of Mr. MICHAEL LEADEN, of No. 6 Gregson-street, who had been missing since 5 o'clock Wednesday afternoon of the preceding week. A hole in the forehead of the deceased proved that he had been shot, and investigation developed the face that a ball from a pistol, which was accidentally discharged while in the hands of a playmate, had caused his death. The Courier says:

abstract: Press, Billingsgate and Boasting
snippet: Press, Billingsgate and Boasting
lead_paragraph: The editors of the Richmond papers are determined that that city shall not be taken, and if loud vociferation that it is entirely secure, and floods of billingsgate poured forth against GRANT and his army and President LINCOLN and his Cabinet could avail anything to check the progress of our armies, we should be compelled to admit that the prospects of the fall of the rebel capital were but meagre. This seems to be about all that the editors can do to keep up the spirits of their comrades, and they certainly are very vigorous in the work.

abstract: A UNITED STATES DEPUTY MARSHAL CHARGED WITH KIDNAPPING. -- Yesterday morning Mr. LOUIS BENJAMIN, a commission merchant of New-York, preferred a charge before Judge COURSOL against G.H. SMITH, of New-York. Deputy United States Marshal, for an attempt to kidnap him. About two months ago Mr. BENJAMIN was arrested in New-York on a charge of shipping goods from New-York to Nassau, N.C., for the blockade-running [???]e. He was imprisoned in Fort Lafayette, where he remained two months, and was then brought before Gen. DIX and was committed to gaol. He was allowed to visit New-York and his family residing there. A few days ago he made his escape and came to Montreal, and the Deputy Marshal who had him in charge thus became responsible for his appearance. He finding that his prisoner had taken a passage Northward, followed him with the ostensible object of persuading him to return to captivity. What particular form of representation he expected to be required to exercise is not clearly stated, but it was alleged by the prosecutor in the case that he had been asked to drink and to take a drive round the mountain, both of which courtesies were declined. The Deputy Marshal showed a singular ignorance of law, judging from his own declaration. He said that Mr. BENJAMIN, while in his custody or under his supervision, had been treated by him like a gentlemen for months; he invited him to visit his family, and he spent one night in his house; and in open violation of all this hospitality he gave him the slip and came to Canada. The Marshal said he had obtained permission to come North and to endeavor to be [???] the complainant to return to "dula[???] [???] and thus restore him, the Deputy-[???], to the position he had forfeited by [???]nce in his fellow-man. Judge COURSOL said that if any act had been committed by Mr. BENJAMIN, while in the United States for which he might be obtained under the Ashburton Treaty, he would be delivered up on the production of the necesssary papers. But as such was not pretended, the Court would be obliged to exact a bond from Mr. SMITH to the amount of $1,000, and from two sureties in $500 each, that he, SMITH, would keep the peace with regard to the complainant for six months. The necessary bail was given. -- Montreal Herald, June 4.

abstract: 25th Annual Commencement
snippet: 25th Annual Commencement
lead_paragraph: The twenty-fifth annual commencement of the Rutger's Female Institute was held on Thursday, the 16th inst., in the Broadway Tabernacle, in the presence of a very large audience. Mr. H.M. PIEROE, the President of the Institute, presided on the occasion. Rev. Dr. J.P. THOMPSON made the opening prayer. The singing was under the direction of Prof. J.C. WOODMAN. The reports of the various committees upon the essays of the pupils, drawing and painting, vocal music, French, penmanship, practical chemistry, and senior examinations, were interesting, and reflected the highest credit upon the managers of this venerable institution. The interest of the anniversary culminated when the graduating class received the diploma of the Institute from the hands of the President. At the close of his address Mr. PIERCE said:

abstract: The Dano-German Conference
snippet: The Dano-German Conference
lead_paragraph: In its session of the 2d instant, the Conference made some little progress. A prolongation of the armistice for fifteen days, was agreed to, and a greater disposition to compromise was manifested on the part of the neutral and German representatives. England, satisfied that without concession on all sides, the Conference might as well break up, abandoned all idea of maintaining the integrity of the Danish monarchy, and proposed that the Teutonic, or extreme southern, portion of Schleswig should be severed from Denmark, and annexed to Holstein. This proposition appeared acceptable in the main to the German plenipotentiaries, though different views prevailed as to how the line of demarkation should run, the diplomats of the mediating Powers insisting that the Schlei and the Dannewirke ought to be the northern boundaries of the ceded territory, while their opponents wanted to encroach still further on Denmark, by so directing the line as to give Flensburg and Duppell to the newly created State.

abstract: Gen. GRANT, in the new campaign against Richmond from the South, will undoubtedly make use of a new and powerful weapon  the gunboats, or, in other words, a strong floating battery, covering his flank. We believe this war is the first in history in which gunboats have been used in connection with a land force.
lead_paragraph: Gen. GRANT, in the new campaign against Richmond from the South, will undoubtedly make use of a new and powerful weapon the gunboats, or, in other words, a strong floating battery, covering his flank. We believe this war is the first in history in which gunboats have been used in connection with a land force. Europe has already followed our example, and Denmark, during the siege of Duppel, found her most powerful weapon of offence against the flank of the enemy's line in an iron-clad gunboat. In the earlier years of this war, our use of gunboats was so constant and so effective that the rebels claimed we never gained a victory without the aid of the naval arm, and the tremendous batteries of the iron-clad gunboats became an object of especial terror to the enemy's forces. Gunboats carried Fort Henry, and their moral effect no doubt hastened the downfall of Fort Donelson; gunboats probably saved the army at Pittsburgh Landing, by the disorder and loss of sleep they occasioned the rebels during the night.

abstract: A correspondent writing from Worthington, Marion county, relates that a remarkable fight took place in the church yard of the Baptist Church of that place on last Sabbath. The fight was between two snakes, a black snake and a spotted rattle snake. They were first discovered by some children, who spread the news of the deadly conflict and in a short time about fifty persons were upon the ground. The snakes fought for about two hours and a half, when at last the black snake seized the rattle snake by the back of the neck and never let go the hold until the rattle snake gave up the ghost. -- Wheeling Intelligencer.

abstract: The news from Gen. GRANT continues to be of a very cheering character. On Thursday the Second and Ninth Corps got up in position to support the Eighteenth, and succeeded in capturing another line of intrenchments, farther south than the lines held by SMITH. Each corps took several redoubts, and the Ninth captured four guns and four hundred and fifty prisoners.
lead_paragraph: The news from Gen. GRANT continues to be of a very cheering character. On Thursday the Second and Ninth Corps got up in position to support the Eighteenth, and succeeded in capturing another line of intrenchments, farther south than the lines held by SMITH. Each corps took several redoubts, and the Ninth captured four guns and four hundred and fifty prisoners. These intrenchments fully command the City of Petersburgh, which the rebels still occupy. Gen. GRANT significantly adds in his dispatch, however, that "our successes are being followed up." To defend Petersburgh the rebels were obliged to evacuate their position in front of Bermuda Hundred, which Gen. BUTLER at once occupied, before LEE could get his forces across the James. The railroad and plank road from Petersburgh and Richmond were also taken possession of, and Gen. GRANT says he hopes to hold them. His description of the recent movement is very forcible, and, though brief, portrays its dangers, its grandeur, and the consummate skill and the great success with which it was executed very vividly. The movement stands unparalleled as a stupendous military achievement.

abstract: Within the past few days changes of an important character have taken place in the administration of naval affairs in this vicinity. It is generally known that Rear Admiral GREGORY is probably the superintendent of as large a fleet of men-of-war as are numbered in any squadron under the American flag. Every vessel in course of construction or repair, belonging to the Navy Department situated east of the Alleghany Mountains, and not at Navy-yards, is under his immediate supervision. He has a larger staff man any other Admiral in the service, and his headquarters are established in this City, where everything relating to the iron-clad vessels is transacted. A large number of engineers are attached to these headquarters, among them some of the ablest in the navy. Besides these, commodores, captains, commanders, lieutenants, and inferior grades of officers are constantly employed under the Admiral's orders. The changes which have taken place in this staff involve almost an entire remodeling of the different branches of business confided to the management of the superintendent. They are as follows:

abstract: Fresenius, Dr. C. R. Qualitative Chemical Analysis; Arnold, H. P. European Mosaics
snippet: Fresenius, Dr. C. R. Qualitative Chemical Analysis; Arnold, H. P. European Mosaics
lead_paragraph: Mr. WILEY is successfully pursuing his laudable enterprise of bringing within the reach of practical men of science the books that, in their original shape, are almost excluded from the country by high duties and the rise in the price of foreign exchange. The work of FRESEMIUS has always, from its publication, maintained its place as the best guide to the study of Qualitative Analysis, Eleven editions of the German copy testify to the estimation in which it is held at home, and the labors of Prof. SAMUEL JOHNSON, of the Yale College Laboratory, have enriched the reprint of the English translation with original matter, the fruit of his own experiments. The most important of these relate to the "Spectral Analysis," incorporating the late discoveries of KERCHOFF and BUNSEN, "Flame Tests," "Reactions of the Alkaloids," &c., so that taken as a whole, this volume more faithfully represents the actual state of scientific knowledge than any of its predecessors.

abstract: Grant's Army, Butler, Lee
snippet: Grant's Army, Butler, Lee
lead_paragraph: If the news from Gen. GRANT's army which we publish this morning fails to meet the expectations of the more sanguine portion of the community it must be put to the account of those conjectural reports which were allowed to come over the wires in advance of the succinct and modest statement forwarded to the War Office by the Lieutenant-General himself. The story of the fall of Petersburgh received here on Saturday, was the invention of an over-excited reporter. Its transmission by telegraph was little less than an unpardonable folly, especially when viewed in the light of the stupendous character of the movement which the army had to undertake before it had even secured its base south of the James. A careful examination of Gen. GRANT's report of that movement will enable even those least versed in military affairs to appreciate the extent and character of the labor which had to be gone through before the army gained its present position. Gen. GRANT started from LEE's immediate front at Cold Harbor, at a point within fifty yards of the enemy's intrenchments; marched the main body of his army, by a flank movement, a distance altogether of fifty-five miles, and crossed the James where it is two thousand feet wide, and eighty-four feet deep, "without the loss of a wagon, or a piece of artillery," and leaving altogether but about 150 stragglers, to be picked up by the rebel cavalry. Simultaneously, SMITH's corps was transferred to its new position with no loss whatever, and arrived at Bermuda Hundred so thoroughly refreshed and prepared for duty, as to be able on the very night of its landing to take up its march direct from the river to Petersburgh, and to surprise and capture, the same night, the strong fortifications northeast of Petersburgh before LEE knew enough of the situation to order forward supports to BEAUREGARD. These herculean tasks surely needed no supplementary coloring from imaginative delineators. But even had it been necessary to enlarge the record in favor of the Lieutenant-General and his noble army, there was sufficient to be said without going a single step into the realms of fancy. We see now, for instance, on reading SHERIDAN's report, how brilliantly conceived that expedition was, viewed merely as a diversion in favor of the movement of the main army. That LEE was effectually deceived as to the scope of SHERIDAN's advance, is apparent in various ways -- first, in SHERIDAN's report of the strong infantry force he found brought to within five miles of Gordonsville, and occupying a strongly intrenched position -- second, in the fact of LEE's having failed to press as he might, and with terrible effect, upon GRANT's right flank, in the long roundabout march from Cold Harbor to the James -- and, third, in the weakness of BEAUREGARD's forced when SMITH attacked his intrenchments on Wednesday, northeast of Petersburgh.

McKEAG, of the One Hundred and Twentieth Illinois, were killed.

abstract: and the Aristocratic Element
snippet: and the Aristocratic Element
lead_paragraph: If there be any man who is qualified to speak as to the causes which led to the rebellion, ANDY JOHNSON is such a man. Born in North Carolina, living all his life at the South, surrounded by Slavery and slaveholders, a member of the Democratic party until that party at the South openly embraced secession, he was yet a man clear-headed enough not to be misled by the wild theories with which the slaveholding leaders were able to deceive so many around him, and clear-sighted enough to see beneath the outer surface of things around him, those hideous shapes which lurked there before they rose from the depths in their fierce onslaught upon the principles of our Government, and became visible in all their malignity to the dullest sight.
headline: {'main': 'The Aristocratic Element.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Aristocratic Element.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: FROM GEN. HUNTER AND THE FIRST WEST VIRGINIA INFANTRY. -- Capt. MELVIN, of the First West Virginia Infantry, arrived in the city yesterday directly from Staunton, bringing with him a list of the casualties in his regiment during the recent fight at Piedmont, near Staunton. Capt. MELVIN was wounded by a shot in the right shoulder, which disabled him. The First Infantry were the first Union soldiers that ever entered the town, never before having been occupied by Union forces. Capt. MELVIN brings a rebel flag, captured in a desperate charge by his regiment, which he yesterday presented to the Governor. The regimental flag of the First is riddled with bullets, and the gallant regiment should be presented with a new one at once. -- Wheeling Intelligencer, June 17.

abstract: on the Navy and the Blockade; The, and the Navy; New-York Evening Post
snippet: on the Navy and the Blockade; The, and the Navy; New-York Evening Post
lead_paragraph: The Evening Post reads us a lecture for having presumed to call official attention to the defects of our new navy, and intimates that American citizens ought to keep quiet on this subject, leaving it to foreigners to find out the faults, if they exist. We do not expect to argue the Post into a concurrence with an opinion concerning our new navy; but we do not intend to allow it to misrepresent our position, and we are able to state facts which ought to be sufficient to satisfy any person not connected with the Navy Department that we are right in our view. The Post thus states our position:

abstract: When the steamer Lexington was burnt in Long Island Sound, January 13, 1840, DAVID CROWLEY, of this city, second mate, was saved on a bale of cotton, upon which he drifted two days and nights, and finally went ashore at Riverhead, Long Island. This bale of cotton Mr. CROWLEY has preserved with religious care until the present time, but the price of the staple to-day has brought out the sacred relic for sale. It is of remarkable quality, and the three hundred pound bale is worth from four to five hundred dollars. -- Providence Journal.

abstract: ARRIVAL OF THE ELEVENTH MASSACHUSETTS REGIMENT. -- Two hundred men of the Eleventh Massachusetts Regiment, under command of Lieut.-Col. TRIPP, arrived in Jersey City at an early hour yesterday morning, having left the army at Cold Harbor. An equal number of men, some of them reenlisted, and other recruits, remain in the service under command of Col. BLAISDELL, and retain the regimental organization. No regiment from Massachusetts can point to a more gallant record than the Eleventh. From the first battle of Bull Run to the battle of Cold Harbor, this regiment has passed three years of eventful service in the campaigns in virginia, Pennsylvania and Maryland. They brought with them the colors presented by the State, and the national banner, which they have proudly borne in many a battle. They left yesterday afternoon in the Fall River boat for home.

abstract: Depot on the Lakes, House Resolution
snippet: Depot on the Lakes, House Resolution
lead_paragraph: -On Saturday, a resolution reported from the Committee on Naval Affaire, authorizing the President to give the requisite notice to the English Government, of the intention to establish a naval depot on the lakes, passed the House. The treaty of 1817, which excludes the war vessels of both Powers from the lakes, requires that six months' notice of its proposed termination shall be given. And, as both the high contracting parties are prepared for the discontinuance of the compact, it may be considered as a settled matter.

abstract: WALLACK'S. Little has transpired worthy of note at any of the theatres during the past week, nor is there much promise of novelty during the coming one. The benefit of Miss JANE COOMBS on Wednesday evening last, was a graceful tribute to that charming actress, who has nearly overcome the habit of artists who have been starring for any length of time, ...
lead_paragraph: WALLACK's. -- Little has transpired worthy of note at any of the theatres during the past week, nor is there much promise of novelty during the coming one. The benefit of Miss JANE COOMBS on Wednesday evening last, was a graceful tribute to that charming actress, who has nearly overcome the habit of artists who have been starring for any length of time, viz., hurrying through her own part glibly, without giving the other performers, by waiting for them to make their points, an opportunity of appearing to advantage. She has one other fault which needs correction, viz., excessive modulation of the voice which causes the utterance of many of her passages more strongly to resemble a vocal recitative, than a spoken dialogue. This was unpleasantly, manifested throughout her rendition of Juliet in the "Hunchback," which play will be repeated this evening. The changes being rung during the balance of the week, are "The Wife's Secret," "The Follies of a Night," "A Bachelor or Arts," and "Rosedale." The season will close on the 30th, but a supplementary Summer one will be commenced on the following Monday, under the management of Mr. Moss, the opening novelty of which will, in all probability be the comedy of "The Winning Suit," which has created to great a sensation in London, where it is pronounced to be the model classical comedy of the age. Another piece, "The Fox Chase," will probably also be brought out.

abstract: Capt. WILLIAM E.B. ANDREWS, one of the most prominent citizens of Sacramento City, Cal., died at that city on the 19th of April last. He was a native of Charlestown, Mass., but emigrated to California in 1849, when the excitement was at its height. He was a man of unusual strength and courage. Happening to be in San Francisco when the Vigilance Committee was organized, and when the City was held in terror by the lawless bands of desperadoes with which it was infested, he, at a time when no other man dared, volunteered to go with two selected men, and bring the leader of the ruffians to justice. His offer was accepted, and the duty was as promptly performed. In consideration of the service he then rendered, and the energy, determination and dating exhibited, he was offered the position of Chief of Police, which he accepted and held until after the committee had disbanded, when, becoming anxious for fresh adventures, he offered his resignation, and in company with the celebrated KIT CARSON, with whom he was a great favorite, started on one of his famed expeditions across the mountains. It is probable that exposure and overexertion while on these expeditions, brought on the disease of which he died.
