abstract: FIRE. -- About 10 o'clock yesterday morning, a fire broke out in the stable of JOSHUA ROGERS & SON, near the corner of Washington and Plymouth streets. The flames extended to the adjoining coal office, owned by the same parties, and both buildings were demolished with contents. Three horses were in the stable when the fire broke out, but it was found impossible to rescue them and they were consumed in the flames. It is not known how the fire originated, but is supposed to be from accident. The loss amounts to $1,200, insured in the Market Company of New-York.

abstract: THE ROBBERY IN NEW HAVEN -- MOST OF STOLEN GOLD RECOVERED. -- About nine hundred of the ten hundred and thirty-nine sovereigns stolen on Monday, were recovered yesterday morning. As anticipated, the money was stolen JOHN PENNOCK, one of the party of three Englishmen who were at the house of Capt. BOWN. After talking the money, PENNOCK went to the barber shop of Mr. FREEMAN, in Broadway, where he was "had been robbed, but that he had got the best of them after all." He offered the barber quite a pile of of gold to secrete him, which offer was rejected. FREEMAN finally consented to down town and purchase a suit of clothes for PENNOCK. The latter put on the clothes and stopped at the shop till dark, when he went to Centreville and lodged at FERGUSON's over night. FERGUSON saw the gold, and, having heard of the robbery, he came to the city early in the morning, took in Messrs. JONHSON and GILL and returned to Centreville. They secured about Â£900 of the gold, paid FERGUSON $400 reward, and came back contented. During the forenoon, FREEMAN, the barber, informed officer KENNEDY of his interview with PENNOCK, and stated that he believed the thief was at Centreville. The officer had not then heard of the recovery of the gold, and be immediately started for Hamden. Arriving at FERGUSON's house, PENNOCK was found, partially intoxicated. KENNEDY arrested him after some resistance, took him into the house of CHARLES DICKERMAN, when the latter harnessed up and brought them to New-Haven. Mr. P. is now in the station-house. -- New-Haven Journal, June 15.

abstract: A DISHONEST DOMESTIC. CATHARINE SMITH, a domestic in the employment of Mr. HYMAN HARRIS, of No. 99 West Twenty-sixth-street, was arrested by Officer BARKER, of the Fifteenth Precinct, yesterday, on a charge of stealing from her employer. It appears that CATHARINE had for some time been employed at the above place, but no suspicion was entertained of her until the day the goods were missed, ...
lead_paragraph: A DISHONEST DOMESTIC. -- CATHARINE SMITH, a domestic in the employment of Mr. HYMAN HARRIS, of No. 99 West Twenty-sixth-street, was arrested by Officer BARKER, of the Fifteenth Precinct, yesterday, on a charge of stealing from her employer. It appears that CATHARINE had for some time been employed at the above place, but no suspicion was entertained of her until the day the goods were missed, when it was discovered that she had made a wholesale onslaught on the feather-beds, table-linen, ladies' dresses and underclothes, to the value of about $100. Upon being accused of the crime, she confessed her guilt and was taken before Justice DODGE, who committed her in default of $500 bail. The prisoner is 22 years of age, a native of Germany, and says she is guilty.

abstract: SHOCKING AFFAIR IN ROCHESTER -- ATTEMPTED SUICIDE OF A LADY. -- About 4 o'clock this (Saturday) morning, the porter at Congress Hall met in the hall leading to the front entrance, a lady covered with blood, who staggered past him and descended the front steps into Railroad-avenue, and fell on the pavement there. He called for help and the unfortunate woman was picked up and conveyed in the office, where it was found that her throat was cut. Drs. BRADLEY and LANGWORTHY were sent for, and she was conveyed up stairs to a private room. She proved to be Mrs. W.W. SMITH, of Dubuque, Iowa, a sister of Rev. Mr. STOWE, of Canandaigua. It is stated that the woman is a victim of religious monomania. She probably cut her throat in the water closet, as blood was found there in considerable quantity, and a razor belonging to her husband who occupied a room with her, is missing. We have no time to give further particulars. The surgeons do not think she will die. -- Rochester Democrat, June 10.

abstract: THE REBEL SHARPSHOOTERS. -- Our information from Georgia is to the effect that the efforts of the rebel sharpshooters to pick off our officers is fearfully successful -- much more so, indeed, than ever before. Most of them use a recently imported Whitworth gun, which is said to be superior to anything in use by our forces. It is understood that the rebels say as much as $1,500 apiece for these guns. We do not know the kind of money used, but suppose gold or sterling exchange, as Johnny Bull, from whom they were purchased, would probably insist on good money. One of the guns was captured the other side of Resaca, some time since, in this way: A sharpshooter (rebel) climbed into a tree, and tied a handkerchief round his wrist to prevent his falling in case he should be wounded. The rebel was not more than comfortably fixed, before a Federal sharpshooter fired a shot through his neck and instantly killed him. He hung to the tree until our lines extended to the spot, when he was cut down and his gun taken.

abstract: The emigration to this country during the last thirty days is without precedent. Over 30,000 foreigners have landed within that period at Castle Garden, the majority of whom are from Germany -- most of them destined for the agricultural districts of the West. Many find an inducement to remain in the vicinity of New-York, owing to the demand for labor on the railroads running from the City. There are now standing applications at Castle Garden for over 10,000 laborers for public works.

abstract: The Copperhead managers, after a good deal of blinking and boggling, have finally concluded to take the bull by the horns. They have settled not to postpone their convention.
lead_paragraph: The Copperhead managers, after a good deal of blinking and boggling, have finally concluded to take the bull by the horns. They have settled not to postpone their convention. Under the circumstances, it is the best decision for them. The postponement until September would have been equivalent to an abandonment by them of the field altogether. It would have been taken by the people as a confession that they had no stomach for the fight, and were anxious to delay it to the latest hour possible. No party, in any circumstances, can afford to leave any considerable portion of an election canvass without an organized opposition; for mere opposition without organization never amounts to anything. Least of all would such inaction fail to be ruinous now, when the minds of the people are so keenly alive to the great issue of the day, and are so impatient of everything that looks like false dealing with these issues.

abstract: The $300 Exemption Clause
snippet: The $300 Exemption Clause
lead_paragraph: The House Military Committee had yesterday under consideration the subject of commutation in connection with the new Conscription Bill, and it is understood that a majority of the committee favor the repeal of the $300 exemption clause. It is doubted, however, and we think with a fair show of reason, whether the House will sustain the views of the majority. If Senator WILSON reports the facts correctly, when he states that, mainly by means of volunteering, the Government has raised, within a period of little more than eight months, not less than six hundred thousand men, there is an argument presented in favor of maintaining the law as it stands, which we take to be altogether too cogent, practical and to the point, to be set aside merely to sustain an abstract theory of the policy of retaining a fixed rate of commutation. It is true, a very large portion of the six hundred thousand recruits of whom Mr. WILSON speaks, are reenlisted men. But that fact, so far from detracting from the merits of the argument, brings out its force, in the strongest possible light. It shows that the United States service, mainly sustained as it has been by volunteering, presents a claim upon those who have entered it, which would be altogether wanting in the case of an absolute conscription. Of the vast body of reenlisted soldiers, there was not a man who had not in the first instance volunteered for the army. And in so far as the exemption fee established under the existing act has tended to maintain the volunteer character of the service, by furnishing a fund for the dispensation of liberal bounties, it has been an unquestionable support to the military requirements of the Government.
headline: {'main': 'The Results of Volunteering and the $300 Exemption Clause.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Results of Volunteering and the $300 Exemption Clause.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: An audience respectable in numbers assembled last evening at the Cooper Institute, to listen to a lecture by GEORGE FRANCIS TRAIN, on "The Course of Empire," delivered in aid of the suffering families of volunteers. abstract: Gen. FORREST'S victory is greater than at first supposed. Our loss is 150 killed and 459 wounded. The enemy's loss is 1,000 killed and 3,000 captured. The balance is scattered through the woods, and are still being pursued, having traveled 58 miles in 31 hours. The entire army is destroyed.

abstract: PATRICK KENNEDY died yesterday at Bellevue Hospital from the effects of injuries received on Sunday last. The facts of the case, so far as they can be as-...
lead_paragraph: PATRICK KENNEDY died yesterday at Bellevue Hospital from the effects of injuries received on Sunday last. The facts of the case, so far as they can be ascertained previous to the inquest, are as follows: An officer of the Twelfth Precinct was called upon Sunday morning to arrest a disorderly character on the corner of Third-avenue and One Hundred and Twenty-fourth-street. The latter was taken into custody, and the policeman started to the Station-house with him. He had proceeded but a short distance, when a gang of roughs numbering about thirty, attacked the officer, and made a determined effort to rescue the prisoner. An alarm was given, and a roundsman and two other officers immediately made their appearance. A severe struggle then ensued, during which KENNEDY, the deceased, seized a stone of four or five pounds weight, and threw it at the head of the officer who made the arrest. The missile missed its aim, and struck the prisoner, knocking him down. The roundsman, who saw the murderous assault by KENNEDY, instantly struck the latter a blow with his club, from the effects of which he died at the hospital as above stated. A partial examination made after death, showed that the skull was fractured. Deceased was 22 years of age, and had been in this country fifteen months. Coroner RANNEY will hold an inquest on the body to-day.

abstract: States Circuit Court, Judges DAVID DAVIS and S.H. TREAT, upon the bench, an important decision was rendered on Wednesday last. It was on a motion to quash the indictment in the case of the "United States vs. JOHN GRAHAM and others," for resistance to the enrollment in Fulton County last Summer. The case was ably argued for the prosecution by Messrs. LAWRENCE, WELDON and W.H. HERNDON, and by Messrs. JUDD and JAMES for the defense. The court rendered a decision affirming the constitutionality of the Enrollment Act, based upon the provision of the Constitution empowering Congress to raise and equip armies.
lead_paragraph: States Circuit Court, Judges DAVID DAVIS and S.H. TREAT, upon the bench, an important decision was rendered on Wednesday last. abstract: The three great trotting horses of the present epoch Gen. Butles and Robert Fillingham meet once more in the second of their great trotting contests, at the Fashion courts to-morrow, to fight their last Wednesday's battle for, supremacy on the trotling turf, over again. The immense excitement that...
lead_paragraph: The three great trotting horses of the present epoch -- Gen. Butles and Robert Fillingham -- meet once more in the second of their great trotting contests, at the Fashion courts to-morrow, to fight their last Wednesday's battle for, supremacy on the trotling turf, over again. The immense excitement that ensued last week bids fair to be eclipsed on the forthcoming occasion. The trot is much talked about not only in sporting circles, but among the general public, who have no financial interest in the result, but who delight to witness such gallant struggles between such noble animals as the above three. Few among the teeming thousands who were on the course last week will be absent, and their places will be more than filled by those who were absent then, but would not be on any account to-morrow. The last race was in harness -- the coming one is to waggons, and which will prove the better in the change of vehicle remains to be proved. The idle rumor that Fillingham would not start, we can contradict on the authority of his owner, who asserts that he is well and fit -- and the supporters of the horse aver that he will beat Butler this time. The latter is a notoriously good waggon horse, and his party say he is sure to repeat his triumph -- whilst the Morgan party declare he will make the race far too warm to be agreeable to either of the other two. At any event, the trot will be the most exciting one of the season. The most ample arrangements have been made for the comfort and protection of the visitors and the preservation of order on the course.

abstract: Mr. SAULSBERY said if we would put men into the field who were wearing our uniform in the loyal States, and battling against the rights of loyal citizens, we would be doing the country more service than in employing the wild Indians.
lead_paragraph: Mr. SAULSBERY said if we would put men into the field who were wearing our uniform in the loyal States, and battling against the rights of loyal citizens, we would be doing the country more service than in employing the wild Indians. Men had been used to infringe the right of citizens of Delaware and Maryland, who could have been employed to great advantage in the field against the common enemy. Instead of these soldiers being thus used, they had been sent into our army election districts to influence and control our elections. He called upon the Administration, before it placed any of these savages in the field, to call upon these while soldiers to take up arms against the enemy in the front, as there was no sane man who believed there was any necessity for an armed force among the peaceful and quiet citizens of the loyal States. Two million and five thousand troops, or one in ten of our entire population have gone into this war, and we were not only calling for more men of a kindred race, but appealing to have the savage tribes called out. Mr. SAULSBURY then went on to prove that the amount of men be had heretofore named had been in service, by enumerating the different calls. He said it we passed this amendment, we must forget the indignity with which it would be looked upon by our fathers.

abstract: Mr. EDWARD's, for several years past a resident of Staunton, Virginia, arrived in this city yesterday, direct from that place. He came as far as Beverly with the eleven hundred prisoners recently captured by Gen. HUNTER. When our army entered Staunton Mr. EDWARDS was one of four or five men who remained in the town, and he would have been driven into the rebel militia, only that he shut himself up in his room until Gen. HUNTER took possession of the place. The rebels were terribly whipped at Weirs' Cave, or Piedmont, as the battle, is called. They suffered dreadfully in killed. They threw up fortifications of fence rails, and when shell or ball from our guns would strike a pile of the rails, the slaughter was very great, the splinters and fragments of rails being quite as destructive as the shells. The rebels acknowledged themselves badly beaten and all were very chop-fallen. -- Wheeling Intelligencer, June 18.

abstract: The People vs. John Clancy. -- It being generally known, that the noted libel case, in which George the Count Joannes is complainant and John Clancy, Editor of the Leader, is defendant and "prisoner at the war" was to come on for trial yesterday, a grand rush for the Court of General Sessions was the result. Every nook and corner of the court was crowded to its utmost capacity with every variety of classes, promiscuously packed. Among these were many faces shown to the community, and whose owners are in [???] [???]. All were, however, doomed to disappointment, and their faces gave expression to the emotion when the court announced that, after con[???] with the District Attorney, it had been thought but just to try the other cases ahead of this case on the calendar first. Hence the case was adjourned until a week from to-day. The Count, who was present, did not wish it to come off a week from yesterday, for on that day he had a "motion to make" in Lower court. The Count's wishes were regarded, as the result indicates.
lead_paragraph: The People vs. John Clancy. -- It being generally known, that the noted libel case, in which George the Count Joannes is complainant and John Clancy, Editor of the Leader, is defendant and "prisoner at the war" was to come on for trial yesterday, a grand rush for the Court of General Sessions was the result. Every nook and corner of the court was crowded to its utmost capacity with every variety of classes, promiscuously packed. Among these were many faces shown to the community, and whose owners are in [???] [???]. All were, however, doomed to disappointment, and their faces gave expression to the emotion when the court announced that, after con[???] with the District Attorney, it had been thought but just to try the other cases ahead of this case on the calendar first. Hence the case was adjourned until a week from to-day. The Count, who was present, did not wish it to come off a week from yesterday, for on that day he had a "motion to make" in Lower court. The Count's wishes were regarded, as the result indicates.

abstract: The news from Gen. GRANT is up to last night. During Sunday and yesterday there were no military operations of any moment, and everything remained quiet. On Friday and Saturday the ...
lead_paragraph: The news from Gen. GRANT is up to last night. During Sunday and yesterday there were no military operations of any moment, and everything remained quiet. On Friday and Saturday the fighting was quite severe, and our losses considerable, one dispatch setting them down at eight thousand killed and wounded. The advantages gained on those days do not appear to have been particularly decisive, though the rebels were so far forced back that our advanced lines are now within one mile of Petersburgh, and the city is in plain sight under our guns, and can be destroyed with ease should Gen. GRANT order it done. The rebel line is described as forming a semi-circle in front of Petersburgh, with the flanks resting on the Appomattox.

abstract: It will be recollected that Mr. DANIEL H. BROOKS, of the firm of BROOKS BROTHERS, on the 28th of May last, while riding from the depot at Portchester to his residence, was stopped by two high-
lead_paragraph: It will be recollected that Mr. DANIEL H. BROOKS, of the firm of BROOKS BROTHERS, on the 28th of May last, while riding from the depot at Portchester to his residence, was stopped by two highway men in disguise; one seized the horses and intimidated the driver, while the other presented a four-barrel pistol to the breast of Mr. BROOKS, at the same time demanding his money or his life. Mrs. BROOKS was in the carriage at the time. Mr. BROOKS not feeling disposed to die at that particular time, handed to the robber a roll of greenbacks amounting in all to $9. This roll of bills the robber took and then permitted Mr. BROOKS to drive on.

abstract: The Montreal Company's steamship North American, from Liverpool on the 9th, and Londonderry on the 10th inst., passed Cape Race at 2 o'clock on Sunday morning, bringing intelligence five days later. There is nothing notable in the ...
lead_paragraph: The Montreal Company's steamship North American, from Liverpool on the 9th, and Londonderry on the 10th inst., passed Cape Race at 2 o'clock on Sunday morning, bringing intelligence five days later. There is nothing notable in the news. The Dano-German Conference had made no practical progress. It was stated, however, on the authority of a Paris paper, that the Germans consent to the prolongation of the armistice for another fortnight. Denmark absolutely refuses to treat for a settlement on the Schleswig line. The Conference was adjourned to the 25th of June. Russia has transferred to the House of Oldenburgh, all the claims of the imperial family of Russia to the Holstein succession. A debate had taken place in the House of Commons, on the question of Federal recruiting in Ireland, and strong remonstrances were made against it by Lord RUSSEL, who is said to have made complaints of the non-attention of the United States authorities to the representations of Lord LYONS on the subject. A moderate Temperance Bill had been defeated in the House of Commons by an overwhelming majority. M. DE KISSALEFF, the Russian Minister at Rome, is recalled, as a mark, it is said, of the Czar's displeasure at the Pope's proceedings relative to Poland. The duty upon most kinds of goods exported from Russia and Poland, for purposes of Europen commerce, has been abolished. The ship Rockingham, from Callao for Queenstown, was burnt by the pirate Alabama, on the 23d of April, in lat. 15° south, lon. 32° west. The Alabama was spoken on the following day by a vessel which had arrived at London.

abstract: We have read  with great satisfaction the accounts of the excellent behavior of the colored troops in our armies during the recent battles. They come from perfectly reliable and disinterested sources, and leave no doubt, that in all the essential qualities of good soldiers they are fully up to the requirements of the service.
lead_paragraph: -- We have read with great satisfaction the accounts of the excellent behavior of the colored troops in our armies during the recent battles. They come from perfectly reliable and disinterested sources, and leave no doubt, that in all the essential qualities of good soldiers they are fully up to the requirements of the service. But we submit to some of our cotemporaries that it is not necessary to disparage the character of our white soldiers, in order to give the colored troops their just praise. We notice in one or two City journals special mention made of the fact that in some instances not a colored soldier flinched, while the whites "skulked." It is quite possible that in individual cases this may have been true; but it is absurd to cite them as evidences of the superiority of negroes over our own soldiers. Nothing is to be gained in any quarter by such misrepresentations, while gross and unpardonable injustice is done to as brave troops as ever fought for a just cause anywhere on the face of the earth. We rejoice to know that full justice will be done by both the Government and people to the colored soldiers who have been brought into the service: but it certainly is not necessary or proper that others should be disparaged.
headline: {'main': 'INJUSTICE TO OUR TROOPS.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'INJUSTICE TO OUR TROOPS.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: A young man known as JOHN CAHILL, alias "Nuge" Cahull, was brought before Coroner NAUMAN yesterday, on the charge of being the person who murdered Policeman GEORGE W. DURYEA, at the corner of Second-avenue and Sixty-fifth-street, on the afternoon of the 16th of May last, by shooting him through the head while that officer was in the discharge of his duty. Since the commission of the homicide, the Police throughout this City and Brooklyn, have been endeavoring to secure the offender. From information imparted to them they were induced to believe that CAHILL was, without doubt, the guiltyperson. The latter is well known throughout the Eighteenth and Twenty-first Precincts as a bad character. In 1860 he was arrested, tried, convicted and sentenced to State Prison for the crime of burglary. He was released from Sing Sing but a month since. The Coroner committed him to the Tombs to await an indictment. He is 22 years of age and a native of Ireland.

abstract: Undoubtedly the best contested and most exciting game of base ball this season came off yesterday on the ground of the Mutual Club, at Hoboken, between that club and the Newark Club, of Newark, N.J. A large assemblage of the lovers of the game were present, and we venture to say that no game this season has afforded so much pleasure. Some most excellent play was exhibited on both sides, the "double play" of the Mutuals being very fine indeed. On the eight innings the score stood; Mutual 15, Newark 19, thus compelling the Mutual to make at least five on the ninth innings, and put the Newarkites out with a round 0 beside, or else lose the game. This was accomplished, however, as the following score will show. There was great cheering at the conclusion, the admirers of the Mutual, who stood by their favorite club to the last, being in high glee. To show the confidence entertained in the Mutual Club winning, one bet of $35 to $5 was made at the commencement of the ninth innings that that club would win.

abstract: The Forty-first Regiment, Col. VON GILSA, was tendered a public reception yesterday afternoon. The regiment, escorted by the Fifth New-York, assembled in the City Hall Park at 3 1/2 o'clock, and passed in review before several members of the Board of Common Council. The Mayor was unable to be present, but sent a letter of regret to Col. GILSA. The regiment then marched to the Liberty Garden, in the Bowery, where the returned veterans partook of an excellent dinner.

lead_paragraph: THE TWELFTH WARD HOMICIDE -- THE PERPETRATOR UNKNOWN, -- An inquest was held yesterday by Coroner RANNEY, at Bellevue Hospital, on the body of PATRICK KENNEDY, who died from the effects of injuries received on Sunday morning last, at the corner of Third-avenue and One Hundred and Eighteenth-street. The testimony in the case all tended to corroborate the statements already published, with one exception. It had been reported that Roundsman MCCRUM, of the Twelfth Precinct, was the person who inflicted the deadly wounds on the head of deceased. MCCRUM was sworn on the inquest, and in his testimony he positively denies having struck deceased. None of the witnesses were able to tell who committed the deed. The jury rendered the following verdict: "We find that the deceased, PATRICK KENNEDY, came to his death at the hand of some person unknown, on the morning of the 19th inst., at about the hour of 1 1/4 o'clock; the evidence being of an unsatisfactory character. The jury also recommend the closing of PETER MOUSAIRS's, and like establishments, before the hour of 12 on Saturday nights." It is alleged that the MOUSAIR above referred to keeps a public house in the vicinity of where the affray occurred.

LONG- STREET'S corps of the rebel army, occupies the intrenchments in front of Gen. BUTLER'S com- ...
lead_paragraph: The latest news from Gen. GRANT is up to Monday evening. There were no operations of any moment on that day. Our lines in front of Peters- burgh still press the enemy so closely that its evacuation is looked upon as a possibility. Gen. LONG- STREET'S corps of the rebel army, occupies the intrenchments in front of Gen. BUTLER'S command. One of our correspondents speaks of the probability that Petersburgh will be shelled, if it is not given up when the demand is made. It is said to be under our guns, at a distance in some places of but fifteen hundred yards. BEAUREGARD's and LEE's dispatches with reference to affairs up to Thursday, assume that everything is going on well for the rebels, and make no mention whatever of the loss of either intrenchments, prisoners or guns.

abstract: our Candidate for Vice-President
snippet: our Candidate for Vice-President
lead_paragraph: The thoroughly unsectional character of the Union party is strikingly evinced in the ardent satisfaction with which the nomination of ANDREW JOHNSON for the Vice-Presidency is hailed by the party throughout the North. We have yet to hear of the slightest murmur. Neither in the Middle nor in the Eastern States is there any complaint that both candidates on the ticket come from the States west of the Alleghanies. All local jealousy is swallowed up in the general sense of the propriety of making special recognition of the peculiar desert of Southern loyalty.

abstract: Movement to Supply Men
snippet: Movement to Supply Men
lead_paragraph: A movement has been already commenced among some of the wealthier citizens of NewYork for the supply of men for the army, and in advance of the draft. And it is understood that many will subscribe who are exempt, either on account of age or for physical disability. It is highly desirable, for social as well as political reasons, that this should be kept up and carried on. There is nothing better calculated to produce discontent with the war and hostility to the Government, among the poor, than any appearance on the part of the rich of an indisposition to share the burdens of the struggle. The conscription is a tax, which, arrange it how we will, bears unequally on different classes of the community. There are no means of making it otherwise by any legislative provision. It is not possible to arrange matters so that when a man is wanted out of every ten, that each of the ten shall furnish a tenth part of him. The nearest approach the Government can make to the equal distribution of the burden, is to select its recruits by lot. Whatever is done to mitigate the inevitable hardships of the law, must be done by the voluntary efforts of individuals. The Government has to consider the national welfare above all things. Private griefs are nothing to it. It has to leave the right of furnishing substitutes to everybody who has got money enough to pay for them, as the only means of sparing that class of the community whose labors are of most value to the nation, and who, once lost, cannot readily be replaced; namely, those who work with their brains -- who do the planning and directing of the national industry.

abstract: THE GREAT TROT AT THE FASHION COURSE TO-DAY. -- There is no peradventure or doubt about the second of the great contests between Gen. Butler, Robert Fillingham and John Morgan, coming off at the Fashion Course to-day, unless the weather proves so unpropitious to all attempts at fair and square trotting, that it would be madness to undertake, under such circumstances, to decide so great a contest as this. abstract: Speech at N. Y. Ninth Ward Union Meeting
snippet: Speech at N. Y. Ninth Ward Union Meeting
lead_paragraph: A ratification meeting of the Ninth Ward Lincoln and Johnson Campaign Club was held Monday evening at the Bleecker Building, Mr. KEECH presiding. A series of resolutions, indorsing the Baltimore nominations, were read and unanimously adopted. The Chairman stated that Gov. WRIGHT, of Indiana, who was expected to attend, was not present, but that he had the pleasure of introducing Hon. HENRY J. RAYMOND, who although suffering from indisposition had consented to comply with the request of the committee to address the meeting. Mr. RAYMOND, after the cheers which greeted him had subsided, said he did not think he would have attempted to speak that evening on any political topic, except at the old Ninth Ward. He referred to his early associations with the Ward, remarking that his first advent into public life was there. He knew that in the din of war it seemed like breaking in upon the affairs of the hour to speak of politics, but in the present campaign campaign we had to decide that war. The object of the nation had not been accomplished, the rebel armies had not been dispersed, and much depended upon the character of the Government. The Baltimore Convention had placed in nomination good and true men who would support that Government, and it had taken into consideration that ABRAHAM LINCOLN had been President for three years; that he had been surrounded by difficulties even greater than WASHINGTON, and had always been steadfast in his purpose to preserve the Union. He (the speaker) remembered the time when they met to advocate the election of ABRAHAM LINCOLN. Then it was not thought the South could plunge this country into civil war, but at the very threshold of going into power the Administration met with rebellion. The President had first, last and always called upon the people. Some thought he ought to have marked out a distinct path for the people, but the exigencies of the times had never been lost sight of, and the President had never taken a position from which he had receded a single step. The speaker thought that the people had done well in deciding to place ABRAHAM LINCOLN in power for four years more. It was always thought that Slavery was constitutional but local. The South proposed to build up Slavery into a political power, and it became a question between Slavery and the Constitution. A victory won, Slavery would cease forever. Our aim should be to show that the South was wrong, for everything had been done to satisfy that portion of the country that we did not wish to interfere with Slavery; and in that respect the President had done nothing except so far as it was necessary to preserve the Union. In a civil war we must rely upon events to educate the people. When we saw that the South did not believe in our disposition to let Slavery alone, everybody became convinced we must strike a blow at the institution. This was not done hastily. We are now in favor of putting a clause of prohibition of Slavery in the Constitution, so that it may never again be the cause of rebellion in this country. The speaker pronounced a glowing eulogy on the patriotism of the Union men of the South and said that he felt ashamed when their loyalty was questioned. He concluded by saying, that he believed, as far as the prospects were concerned, that, it everything went on fair, ABRAHAM LINCOLN would as surely be reelected as he is now President.

abstract: Having passed several sleepless nights, disturbed by the agonies and cries of a suffering child, and becoming convinced that Mrs. WINSLOW's SOOTHING SYRUP was just the article needed, procured a supply for the child. On reaching home, and acquainting his wife with what he had done, she refused to have it administered to the child, as she was strongly in favor of Homeopathy. That night the child passed in suffering, and the parents without sleep. Returning home the day following, the father found the baby still worse; and while contemplating another sleepless night, the mother stepped from the room to attend to some domestic duties, and left the father with the child. During her absence he administered a portion of the Soothing Syrup to the baby, and said nothing. That night all hands slept well, and the little fellow awoke in the morning bright and happy. The mother was delighted with the sudden and wonderful change, and although at first offended at the deception practiced upon her, has continued to use the Syrup, and suffering, crying babies and restless nights have disappeared. A single trial of the Syrup never yet failed to relieve the baby, and overcome the prejudice of the mother. Thirty-five cents a bottle. Sold by all druggists.

abstract: -It may be computed with reason that LEE's family of consumers has been increased within the last ten days to the tune of full fifty thousand non-combatants, by the advance of our forces south of the James. The close pressure of the National army has at least added this number of hungry and homeless sympathizers to the daily ration list of the chief rebel Commissary-General. Within the same brief period, Gen. LEE has found his means of supply diminished in the same or even in greater proportion. With HUNTER, AVERILL and CROOK on the Central Virginia Railroad, and thirty miles of it rendered useless for transportation; with the Danville road already all but in our possession, the chances of the rebel camp followers for daily sustenance must be diminishing at a rate which a fortnight ago they had barely reckoned on. A transfer of the defence of Richmond to the intrenchments of Petersburgh brings the rebel commissary a few miles nearer his main source of supply. But unless HUNTER and the cooperating column of AVERILL and CROOK are forced to retreat -- of which, even accepting the rebel accounts published in other columns, there are no symptoms whatever -- LEE's army must either go further South to be fed, or the rebel chief must shortly risk a battle outside of his intrenchments.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, Mr. HALE reported, without amendment, the House joint resolution authorizing the Secretary of the Navy to amend the contract with JOHN ERICSSON for the construction of the two floating batteries, Dictator and Puritan. The bill was also roported to secure homesteads for soilders and sailors on forfeited rebel estates.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, Mr. HALE reported, without amendment, the House joint resolution authorizing the Secretary of the Navy to amend the contract with JOHN ERICSSON for the construction of the two floating batteries, Dictator and Puritan. The bill was also roported to secure homesteads for soilders and sailors on forfeited rebel estates. A letter was submitted from Mr. FISHBACK, protesting against the charges of disloyalty made against him, and making averments of his entire loyalty to the Constitution and Government of the United States. The Internationel Telegraph Bill was then brought up, and after considerable discussion, passed as amended. It therefore simply grants the right of way, the assistance of the navy to a certain extent, and the protection of the army to the company while building the line, with the use of forty acres of land for each station. A motion to take up the House Bill to repeal the Fugitive Slave Act, was carried. The Military Committee reported a bill for the repeal of the three hundred dollar clause. During the evening session nothing of importance was done.

snippet: Donovan, J. C., Intended Voyage to Europe in Sail-boat
lead_paragraph: Capt. JOHN C. DONOVAN is about to venture across the ocean in the smallest craft that ever attempted such a voyage. The dimensions of his vessel, called the Vision, which is hermaphrodite brig rigged, are: length of keel, 15 feet; breadth of beam, 4 feet 6 inches; depth of hold, 2 feet 6 inches. Yesterday the Captain started on a trial trip down the bay from the foot of Grand-street, East River, where his little craft has been lying for some time.

abstract: Since the successful passage of the James River, and the advance on Petersburgh, many people have begun once more to fix a day on which Richmond is to be in our possession. The more sanguine spirits have, as might have been expected, fixed upon the Fourth of July, while others refuse to defer the realization of their hopes for more than one week more at the outside.
lead_paragraph: Since the successful passage of the James River, and the advance on Petersburgh, many people have begun once more to fix a day on which Richmond is to be in our possession. The more sanguine spirits have, as might have been expected, fixed upon the Fourth of July, while others refuse to defer the realization of their hopes for more than one week more at the outside. The speedy capture of the place is looked forward to by a still larger number, who refrain from meddling with dates, but expect the news of it every week. All this, we need hardly say, is but a repetition of what we have been witnessing ever since the war began. After the commencement of every new movement, if it should be attended with the smallest success, a portion of the public has at once rushed to the conclusion that "the back of the rebellion was broken;" that the rebel army was demoralized, and incapable of further resistance. We witnessed this after Mill Spring, after Roanoke, after Fort Donelson, after the fall of New-Orleans, and after that of Vicksburgh. No amount of experience of the risks and uncertainty of war, and of the desperation with which the enemy is fighting, seems sufficient to counteract this most unfortunate tendency to exaggeration. More recently, we have witnessed it after the battle of the Wilderness. GRANT's successful advance threw the public into its usual fever, and they looked for nothing less than his unbroken progress and immediate entry into Richmond.
headline: {'main': 'Public Impatience About Military Movements.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Public Impatience About Military Movements.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: vented by Dr. LEVETT, the eminent dentist, of No. 832 Broadway. It consists of perforated cellular plate, on which the teeth are set, and is held firmly in its place by atmospheric pressure. It occupies, when worn, about one-third of the space of the old-fashioned plate, which covered the whole of the roof of the mouth, and extended back to the palate. It is light, durable, and is recommended in strong terms by Prof. Carnochan, the great surgeon, and other physicians of exalted rank. Its production shows that a vast stride has been taken in the dental art by Dr. LEVETT. -- Sunday Dispatch, June 4, 1858.

abstract: Early yesterday morning a rumor was reported of the capture of Lexington, Va., by the enemy under Gens, CROOK and AVERILL. As the same rumor had once before gone round, not much credit was given it, but it being afterward confirmed by official intelligence, the question was at last settled. The enemy's  forces were reported to be about 16,000 strong, and consisted mainly of cavalry, with a dozen pieces of artillery.

abstract: -- There is, we believe, not a single organ of public opinion outside of Congress that did not echo the demand, that the commutation clause shall not be struck from the Conscription Act. In the House, Mr. SCHENCK exhausted all the arguments, we presume, that could be advanced in favor of repealing the clause; but it was altogether impossible that these should outweigh the all but unanimous judgment of the outside public. And we are not surprised that the House, by a majority of two to one, refused to have the clause repealed. The Volunteer boards will now, we trust, resume business with a zeal which will even put to shame their former efforts. New-York is already eleven hundred to the good on the next draft, with a disputed claim of three hundred more, which will probably be settled in her favor. The enrollment, therefore, will have no terrors for our citizens. Volunteers will be had in abundance as fast as they are wanted.

abstract: Ireland; Federal Enlistments Debate
snippet: Ireland; Federal Enlistments Debate
lead_paragraph: The telegraphic news by the Africa, which we publish this morning, presents a fuller view than was given in the abstract by the North American, of the latest neutrality grievance, as it came under discussion in the House of Lords on the 9th inst. The debate, or rather the Parliamentary conversation, on the subject of enlistments in Ireland, arose upon a motion by the Marquis of CLANRICARDE for the production of papers -- a formal mode of getting a chance to speak on the question at issue. It is altogether a happy arrangement which makes Lord CLANRICARDE the special champion of the Slaveholding conspiracy in the British Parliament. His complete ostracism from any regular party organization, the obliquity of his public history which formerly made his official connection with the Whigs all but fatal to the existence of a ministry otherwise popular, and the infamous social reputation he has held for many years, all conspire to designate him for the task of representing the rebel Confederacy, and of bringing his country, in the interest of that Confederacy, into collision with a friendly Power.

abstract: Henderson, J., on the Navy Agent and Mr. Weed
snippet: Henderson, J., on the Navy Agent and Mr. Weed
lead_paragraph: ISAAC HENDERSON, Navy Agent at this City, and business manager of the Evening Post, was arrested at his office yesterday afternoon on a warrant issued by United States Commisioner BETTS. He is charged with defrauding the United States Treasury in the sum of several thousand dollars by means of false vouchers issued in his capacity as Navy Agent.

abstract: The steamship Africa, from Liverpool on the 11th inst., via Queenstown on the 12th inst., arrived at Halifax yesterday afternoon. She brings two days later news from Europe. The ship Kent, which had arrived at London, reports that a boarding officer from the rebel steamer Alabama stated that she had burned a large number of American vessels, and had a great number of...
lead_paragraph: The steamship Africa, from Liverpool on the 11th inst., via Queenstown on the 12th inst., arrived at Halifax yesterday afternoon. She brings two days later news from Europe. The ship Kent, which had arrived at London, reports that a boarding officer from the rebel steamer Alabama stated that she had burned a large number of American vessels, and had a great number of prisoners on board. In the House of Lords, the matter of Irish enlistments in the American service was brought up, the Marquis of Clanricarde and Lord BROUGHAM speaking very strongly in opposition to it, and expressing the hope that European Powers would soon interfere, and stop the present war. The Marquis of Clanricarde also stated that it was notorious that Federal recruiting was going on in Ireland. Earl RUSSELL, in reply, defended the conduct of Lord LYONS and himself, but also thought the action of the American Government highly discreditable. He wished that proofs might be furnished that Federal recruiting was going on in Ireland, that the proper parties might be punished. The Times thinks the matter has been greatly exaggerated, and believes the number of men obtained by the Federals from the British isles to be very small, and also that if they had received twice the number, England could not reasonably make it a cause of war, on the ground that the Government cannot prevent emigration, and that if emigration ends in enlistments, that is a matter beyond their control. The Dano-German Conference Committee met again on the 9th inst. The armistice has been extended until the 26th of June. The Germans insist on the lines proposed by them. The Danes, however, seem determined to make no concessions, and the campaign will probably reopen on the 26th inst. The Le Nord says that Russia will not send a new Minister to Rome.

abstract: In the Senate yesterday, a petition was received from a colored citizen of Washington for relief to purchase his daughter, who he claims to have purchased when a slave. He states that the Emancipation Commissioners refused to allow the claim, on the ground that a slave could not acquire slave property.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate yesterday, a petition was received from a colored citizen of Washington for relief to purchase his daughter, who he claims to have purchased when a slave. He states that the Emancipation Commissioners refused to allow the claim, on the ground that a slave could not acquire slave property. He therefore asked Congress for compensation. A petition was presented asking that Polish citizens who are serving in the United States Army may not be returned to the Russian Government as prisoners. The House bill authorizing the President to negotiate with certain Indian tribes for a relinquishment of certain rights, was passed with an amendment. The bill to prevent military interference was passed, with an important amendment to the effect that military may be employed to keep the peace at the polls. The bill to allow the transfer of persons from the military to the naval service was passed. The bill to compensate the officers and crew of the gunboat Essex for the capture of the rebel ram Arkansas, was passed. The bill to establish a Navy-yard and depot at Cairo was passed. The bill for the relief of officers and seamen in the naval service, to compensate for losses, &c., was passed. The House resolution for the relief of JOHN ERICSSON was passed without amendments. A bill was passed to repeal so much of the Deficiency Bill of last March as appropriated $25,000 for a naval hospital at Kittery, Me. The bill to repeal the Fugitive Slave Law was taken up, and after various [???]latory motions had been made to adjourn, postpone, &c., a compromise was finally made, and the bill was allowed to be reported to the Senate as from Committee of the Whole. The Senate [???]en went into executive session, and shortly afterward adjourned.

abstract: -- The news from Europe which we publish this morning, gives positive confirmation of the previous reports, that Spain disavows the recent outrageous acts of her agents on the Pacific coast. Admiral PINZON is recalled. His colleague, Senor SALAZAR took time by the forelock, got hastily ashamed or afraid of what he had done, and made his escape. And the Government of Her Catholic Majesty, having had special advice of the action taken by the American and British Ministers at Lima, as well as of the decided attitude taken by Peru herself, and her sister Republics, has hastened to get out of her false position almost as soon as she got into it. This is, so far, well. But the independent States of South America have had a warning which it will be their own fault if they do not profit by. Spain has come to consider herself as entitled to put forward pretensions which she would barely have dreamed of twenty-five years ago. And her ambition has been piqued in no common measure by the events which have transpired and are now transpiring in Mexico. Vigilance and union must be the watchwords of the South American Republics, unless they are to revert incontinently to the condition of dependencies, or become subjects of that regenerative process which has already been applied to one community of the "Latin race" on this continent.

abstract: Chicago Convention and the Peace Democracy
snippet: Chicago Convention and the Peace Democracy
lead_paragraph: The leaders of the Peace party in this State have decided to hold a mass meeting in this City on the Wednesday preceding the Chicago Convention. Their object, to use the words of their organ, the Daily News, is "to convince the Democratic North that it would be madness and defeat to ignore so potent a principle, and so vast an army of voters sworn to its support." The movement has the same reference to the Chicago Convention that the Cleveland gathering had to the Baltimore Convention. Its object is to bring to bear an outside constraint. Whether, as in the other case, it will be carried through to an open rupture, remains to be seen.

abstract: NEW-YORK UNIVERSITY GRAMMAR SCHOOL EXHIBITION. -- The annual exhibition took place yesterday at the University chapel, and was largely attended. Dodworth's Band was in attendance, and many excellent poems, recitations and dialogues delivered by the pupils; at their conclusion, Rev. Dr. FERRIS distributed the prizes as follows: For exemplary conduct and proficiency, primary department -- Albert J. Loder. Classical and Commercial Departments -- Samuel Baker, Jr., of first class, prize for Latin and Greek; Samuel S. McCutcheon, of second class, prize for Latin; Frank E. Weston, of second Greek class, prize for Greek; Henry D. Loder, of third Latin class, prize for Latin. Mathematics -- Samuel Baker, Jr., first prize, and Samuel S. McCutcheon, second prize. English Composition -- Samuel Baker, Jr. Exemplary Conduct -- Henry M. Kirk and Neilson. The exercises were concluded with the benediction.

abstract: FIRE IN R. HOE & CO.'s BOSTON ESTABLISHMENT. -- The fire at 7:30 o'clock last evening was in the printing press manufactory of R. HOE & CO., on Foundry-street, South Boston. It caught in the engine room, which is connected with the main buildings and workshops. The boiler was badly damaged, and, by the burning of a floor above, a lot of paper cutting machines stored in the second story were precipitated into the engine-room. The flames did some slight damage to the main building. The locomotives were removed from the engine-house of the Old Colony Railroad, as it was feared the fire might extend in that direction. Messrs. HOE & CO.'s loss will amount to several thousand dollars, and they are fully insured. -- Boston Traveller, June 21.
lead_paragraph: FIRE IN R. HOE & CO.'s BOSTON ESTABLISHMENT. -- The fire at 7:30 o'clock last evening was in the printing press manufactory of R. HOE & CO., on Foundry-street, South Boston. abstract: The news from Gen. GRANT'S army is up to 4 o'clock yesterday. There was no fighting during the day, but Secretary STANTON says important movements were in progress, which, at the time of writing, were not proper for publication.
lead_paragraph: The news from Gen. GRANT'S army is up to 4 o'clock yesterday. There was no fighting during the day, but Secretary STANTON says important movements were in progress, which, at the time of writing, were not proper for publication. He adds that late Richmond papers report an attack on Lynchburgh by Gen. HUNTER and his repulse, but the Secretary adds that it was probably a mere reconnaissance, by which HUNTER ascertained that the place was strongly defended, and then proceeded to operate on the railroad communications south and east of it. From the Army of the Potomac we have a report that EWELL's corps has gone to find HUNTER, but it is only a surmise.

abstract: The Joint Special Committee of the Common Council to inquire into the abuses and illegalities of our City railroads, gave another hearing yesterday Mr. GILBERT, who spoke at the former hearing, narrated particulars of damage done to carts and drivers by accidents happening from getting into or while crossing the deeply grooved and projecting rails used by some companies. Mr. JOHN R. MCCOMB stated that he loses $1,000 a year on rent of a building in Washington-street, in consequence of the railroad in that street passing the door, rendering it quite impossible to receive and deliver goods from carts. Mr. GILBERT said, as before, that the police protect the cars against the carts, and abused, and sometimes clubbed the cartmen, if they were not as active in getting off the track for the cars, as the policemen impatiently expected they should be.

abstract: And the Navy; Evening Post on
snippet: And the Navy; Evening Post on
lead_paragraph: The Post rejoins to our article of Monday last, by quoting a letter from the Charleston Courier, written by some rebel in Nassau to that journal, in which it is stated that "one thousand tons" of rebel bacon is spoiling in that port, and that rebel bonds are selling there at nominal prices; and from this letter the Post draws the conclusion that our statements are incorrect. Again it is our duty to correct misrepresentation, and to mend bad logic. We did not say that the Confederate bonds, generally, were equal to ours in Europe, but that their Cotton Loan was, whose only value consists in the fact that cotton, in the Southern States, is pledged for its payment, and that the blockade is of so inefficient a character that this cotton can come out to perform its pledged duty. Is not this true? And eannot the Post perceive that the utter worthlessness of the common bonds of the South makes the high value of their "cotton bonds" the more striking, since it is evident that there is no general responsibility behind them, but only the certainty that cotton can run the blockade? If Confederate bonds generally were worth as much as ours in Europe, the fact that these cotton bonds were also equally valuable would prove nothing -- otherwise it proves that the blockade is worthless.
headline: {'main': 'The Navy and the Blockade.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Navy and the Blockade.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The grand match between the above famous clubs, which was commenced on Wednesday, on the Bedford Cricket Grounds, Broklyn, was concluded, yesterday afternoon, in favor of the Philadelphians -- the total scores standing 216 to 189. The players from the Quaker City, who, by-the-bye, are, with one exception, young American players, and exceedingly active, in the field, far surpassing the eleven of New-York. The fine bowling of MCBRIDE and HUNT is especially worthy of notice; the splendid fielding of NEWHALL also was of the highest order. The result undoubtedly was as unexpected to the victors as it was to the vanquished. It proves the saying that, "young blood will tell." The representation from Pennsylvania took their departure homeward last evening,  highly elated with the success they had achieved, and extended a cordial invitation to their adversaries to visit Philadelphia, when they would make the visit a pleasant one to them.

abstract: Sumptuary Laws in
snippet: Sumptuary Laws in
lead_paragraph: -- The state of public opinion in England on the question of sumptuary laws is illustrated in the division which took place in the House of Commons, on a bill introduced by a Mr. LAWSON, empowering the parish authorities throughout the United Kingdom to prohibit liquor-selling within their several jurisdictions. In a House of 337 members the bill, after a short debate, was thrown out by a majority of 257, only thirty-five members voting for the second reading. Even the brief discussion which took place was carried on amid constant interruptions -- so entirely was the feeling of the House, irrespective of party, in favor of a speedy and complete condemnation of the whole principle of sumptuary legislation.

abstract: University; 33d Annual Commencement
snippet: University; 33d Annual Commencement
lead_paragraph: The Thirty-third Annual Commencement of the University of New-York took place yesterday, in Niblo's Theatre. The large and brilliant audience was, as usual on similar occasions, composed principally of ladies, who provided themselves with beautiful and costly bouquets, with which they rewarded the oratorical efforts of the graduates. The orchestra was occupied by Helmsmuller's Band and the musical selections were of the most charming and varied order.

abstract: The People ex rel., Thomas Thatcher vs. The New-York Commercial Association. -- In January, 1862, the Board of Managers of this association expelled the relator, Thatcher, for charges preferred against him by one Parker. The relator, claiming that the managers had no jurisdiction of the charges, obtained a writ of mandamus to compel his restoration, or to have cause shown why he should not be restored. This was a motion to quash the return made to the writ, on the ground that it was made by the corporation, and not by the Board of Managers, to whom the writ was issued. It was further alleged that the respondents had failed to set out all the facts.
lead_paragraph: The People ex rel., Thomas Thatcher vs. The New-York Commercial Association. -- In January, 1862, the Board of Managers of this association expelled the relator, Thatcher, for charges preferred against him by one Parker. The relator, claiming that the managers had no jurisdiction of the charges, obtained a writ of mandamus to compel his restoration, or to have cause shown why he should not be restored. This was a motion to quash the return made to the writ, on the ground that it was made by the corporation, and not by the Board of Managers, to whom the writ was issued. It was further alleged that the respondents had failed to set out all the facts.

abstract: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter  of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by
lead_paragraph: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of all military movements in the different departments from the pens of our special correspondents. Also, all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news, European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, giving the tone of public feeling abroad, made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports; items of agricultural and domestic interest complied from sources many of which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader; and marriages and deaths of the week.

abstract: Palmerston, Lord, Out of Temper on the Danish Question
snippet: Palmerston, Lord, Out of Temper on the Danish Question
lead_paragraph: -- In the discussion which took place in the House of Commons on the 6th inst., on the questionings to which Ministers were subjected relative to the Dano German Conference, Lord PALMERSTON showed symptoms of feebleness of an altogether unusual character. Mr. B. OSBORNE, one of the first Minister's old retainers, in asking for official information, opened the way for one of Mr. DISRAELI's bitterest attacks on the foreign policy of the Government: and so hard were the hits, that the jaunty Premier fairly lost his equanimity and burst into an undignified bit of temper, during which he said probably the most memorably foolish thing in his whole parliamentary career. Let us quote his words. Replying directly to Mr. DISRAELI's attack:

abstract: The news from the armies this morning is very meagre. The latest intelligence from the army in front of Petersburgh represents everything as quiet, and that there had been no fighting since the rebel attack of Sunday night. The important movements in progress spoken of yesterday in Secretary STANTON's dispatch do not seem to have been developed yet. On Tuesday there was quite a lively fight at White House, between our forces there under Gen. ABERCROMBIE, aided by one or two gunboats, and the rebel cavalry under HAMPTON and one of the LEES. The enemy were driven off SHERIDAN's cavalry arrived before the fight was over, and aided in the repulse of the rebels. Gen. GETTY now commands at White House.
lead_paragraph: The news from the armies this morning is very meagre. abstract: Henderson, Isaac, N. Y. Navy Agent, Arrest of for Alleged Fraud
snippet: Henderson, Isaac, N. Y. Navy Agent, Arrest of for Alleged Fraud
lead_paragraph: Mr. ISAAC HENDERSON, late Navy Agent at this City, was arrested on a charge made under the Sub-Treasury Act of 1846, which provides that "if any officer charged with the disbursement of public moneys, shall accept or receive, or transmit to the Treasury Department to be allowed in his favor any receipt or voucher from a creditor of the United States without having paid to said creditor * * * the full amount specified in such receipt or voucher, every such act shall be deemed to be a conversion by such officer to his own use of the amount specified in such receipt or voucher."

abstract: ANNUAL EXHIBITION AT THE ST. PETER's ACADEMY. -- Yesterday afternoon the pupils of St. Peter's Academy gave their customary annual exhibition, under charge of the Sisters of Charity. The exercises consisted of music, (vocal and instrumental,) dialogues, &c. At the conclusion of the programme, the pastor (Rev. Mr. QUINN) distributed premiums and awards of merit to the successful contestants, when the exhibition was terminated by an address by Miss O'BRIEN and a grand chorus by all the pupils.

abstract: New-York, Garrity, Margaret, a child, by Mrs. Dora Clinton
snippet: New-York, Garrity, Margaret, a child, by Mrs. Dora Clinton
lead_paragraph: Coroner WILDEY was yesterday called upon to hold an inquest on the body of a little girl named MARY GERRITY, aged three years and three months, who, according to the verdict of the jury, rendered after a careful and thorough investigation of all the facts in the case, "came to her death by exhaustion from injuries received at the hands of DORA CLINTON. We furthermore consider that WM. CLINTON was an accessory."

abstract: DEATH OF MR. BEECHER. -- WM.A. BEECHER, who accidentally tell from one of the windows of the Custom-house on Wednesday last, as previously reported, died on the following evening at the New-York Hospital from the effects of his injuries. An inquest was held on the body yesterday by Coroner COLLIN, when it appeared that his skull had been fractured, and he was otherwise seriously wounded by the fall. The jury rendered a verdict of accidental death. Deceased was a native of New-Haven, Conn., aged 65 years.

abstract: The European mail which arrived last evening puts us in possession of full text of the speeches delivered in the House of Lords during the debate on Irish enlistments. Lord RUSSELL's remarks we publish at length in other columns. They will be found to be a mixture of half-friendly argument and querulous complaint -- the latter naturally directed against the Government of the United States. Lord RUSSELL, in short, appears in one of his most fretful moods; and it will be seen he travels far beyond the record toward the close of his speech, in order to declaim against the war and insinuate a plea for the right of secession.
lead_paragraph: The European mail which arrived last evening puts us in possession of full text of the speeches delivered in the House of Lords during the debate on Irish enlistments. abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, a bill to amend the act to establish and equalize the grade of line officers in the navy was referred to the Naval Committee. A report was agreed to, recommending that the Senate recede from its amendments to the bill for the repair and preservation of certain public works of the United States. The bill for the promotion of commerce and the improvement of navigation was passed. The Pacific Telegraph bill was amended and passed. A bill was reported to provide salaries in lieu of commissions for Postmasters. The Civil Appropriation bill was then brought up for consideration, and several amendments were made. In evening session the Miscellaneous Appropriation bill was taken up and the final consideration of it postponed.

abstract: the, which Side must give Way
snippet: the, which Side must give Way
lead_paragraph: It is certain that this war, which has now been in progress for about three years, has a positive limit, beyond which it cannot go. It imposes sacrifices upon both parties to it which no human power can stand indefinitely. Assuming that both sides are determined to fight it through, the question which will give way first depends solely upon their relative vital resources. We say vital resources, for the time has come when they alone are to be taken into account.

abstract: The Board of Aldermen referred a resolution declaring the Gansevoort property, now again vested in the City, a site for a market, and directing the Street Commissioner to make it complete for that purpose. A communication from City Inspector BOOLE, again calling attention to the fat-boiling nuisance, and expressing the opinion that the Board of Health have the right of themselves, without the concurrence of their President, (the Mayor,) to convene and transact business, was referred, to obtain a report upon the legal aspect of this question. The recent nomination by the Fire Department of BERNARD KINNEY to be an Assistant Engineer, vice JOHN BAULCH, who is in the Government service at Fortress Monroe, was laid over, the nomination being premature, Mr. BAULCH's resignation not yet having been accented by the Common Council. The Mayor sent in a message covering and commending to the attention of the Common Council a circular from the head of the State Bureau of Military Statistics, soliciting a collection of facts of interest concerning the New-York regiments participating in the war. The Aldermen adjourned to next Thursday, and the Councilman to next Monday, at 2 P.M.

abstract: By the arrival of the schooner George Prescott, Capt. JOHNSON, from Jacmel at this port yesterday, we learn that on May 19, at 4 o'clock, A.M., a very heavy shock or an earthquake was felt on board the schooner; it felt as if she had run ashore; it destroyed a great number of houses on shore. An hour later on the same morning there was another shock, but not so violent as the first. On the 21st another shock was felt, which also destroyed a number of houses, among them the British Consul's dwelling, and the consul himself was covered up in the ruins, but was rescued. On the 1st inst., another slight shock was experienced, but no damage was done.
lead_paragraph: By the arrival of the schooner George Prescott, Capt. abstract: In our advertising columns will be found a card and announcement convoking a meeting of the New-York Managers at Mr. WALLACK's private residence in Fourteenth-street, at 2 o'clock on Tuesday next. The object being to take some united action in view of the increased demands of the "Musical Protective Union," which, it is alleged, undertakes to dictate to managers whom they shall employ, and what prices they shall pay -- reserving to themselves the privilege of leaving any Manager without an orchestra, unless he succumbs to their demands. The New-York Managers dissent. "They offer their old orchestras increased compensation for the ensuing season, on signing an agreement for that period, which, under advisement of the association," they refused to do.
lead_paragraph: In our advertising columns will be found a card and announcement convoking a meeting of the New-York Managers at Mr. WALLACK's private residence in Fourteenth-street, at 2 o'clock on Tuesday next. The New-York Managers dissent. "They offer their old orchestras increased compensation for the ensuing season, on signing an agreement for that period, which, under advisement of the association," they refused to do.

abstract: The latest intelligence from Gen. GRANT's army is an unofficial dispatch under date of June 23, at 6 A.M., which gives very meagre and indefinite details of Gen. GRANT's latest movements. Our own dispatches, under date of 22d, give particulars of that affair, from which it appears that two corps, under HANCOCK and WRIGHT, marched from the right to the left on the night of the 21st for the purpose of extending the left, and more closely investing the City by covering the Weldon Railroad. WILSON's cavalry division moved off on a raid by a circuitous route, and when last heard from had struck the railroad, and were busily engaged in tearing up the track. Our infantry, after marching several miles, were suddenly confronted by A.P. HILL's corps, and a skirmish ensued, in which we lost four guns by a blunder in the disposition of our supporting force. Our columns soon rallied, however, and drove the enemy back to their original position. A reconnoissance was then made, which developed the enemy in strong force on a strong line, partly intrenched. Orders were then given for the advance of the whole army to that point, and a line of battle was formed. A general engagement on Thursday seemed imminent, and parties who left City Point that day say that very heavy cannonading was heard throughout the day, but no results were learned.

abstract: -- A meeting was held at the Brooklyn Academy of Music last evening, for the purpose of organizing a permanent institution, to be styled "The Home Commission." having for its object the relief, of any person made needy by the casualties of war. GEO. B. LINCOLN, Esq., called the meeting to order by nominating S.B. CHITTENDEN, Esq., as chairman, which was unanimously agreed to. The President stated the object of the meeting, after which addresses were made by Rev. H.W. Beecher, Rev. R.M. Hatfield, Rev. A.A. Willets, Rev. E.M. Johnson, and Hon. George Hall. Resolutions organizing the association were adopted. The veterans of the Fourteenth and Sixty-seventh Regiments were present.

abstract: -- The Tenth Massachusetts Regiment, under command of Lieut.-Col. JOSEPH PARSONS, arrived at the Park Barracks at one o'clock yesterday morning, from the Army of the Potomac. The regiment returns with two hundred men. It was mustered into the service on the 21st of June, 1861, since which time it has been engaged in fourteen battles. It was with MCCLELLAN all through the Peninsula campaign, and has lost, as will be seen by its decimated ranks, a large number or its men. Col. HENRY S. BRIGGS, its first Commandant, and a son of Gov. BRIGGS, of Massachusetts, was promoted to a Brigadier-Generalship, as was also Col. EUSTACE, its subsequent Commandant. The regiment left for Springfield last evening.

abstract: Practicing on Northern Credulity
snippet: Practicing on Northern Credulity
lead_paragraph: The American people are credulous. Give them a fact plain, probable and undisputed, and they readily credit it. Give them a false hood positively stated, and they believe it with almost equal readiness, even though it bear evidence of falsity upon its face. And to such an extent does this popular credulity exist that a well-started and well-circulated falsehood stands little, if any, chance of ever being successfully contradicted. -- fully illustrating the old adage that "a lie will travel a thousand miles while truth is putting on her boots." But this peculiarity of the American people is not a bad one -- on the contrary, unabused, it is a good characteristic. It is part of the foundation of that principle of mutual confidence which is so necessary to business and society, causing men to respect and place dependence upon the word of each other.
headline: {'main': 'The Abuse of Public Credulity.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Abuse of Public Credulity.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: There is no later news from Gen. GRANT this morning. Further details of the movement and fights on Wednesday are given, from  which it seems that the rebels observed our columns in motion, and moved out a corps under HILL to see what it meant, by which they happened to get in between the Second and Sixth Corps, as much to their surprise as ours.
lead_paragraph: There is no later news from Gen. GRANT this morning. Further details of the movement and fights on Wednesday are given, from which it seems that the rebels observed our columns in motion, and moved out a corps under HILL to see what it meant, by which they happened to get in between the Second and Sixth Corps, as much to their surprise as ours. But the rebels were the first to discover the fact, and quickly attacked the Second Corps in the rear, throwing our troops into confusion, capturing four guns and several hundred prisoners. Our columns were soon rallied, however, and attacked the rebels vigorously, the Sixth Corps coming gallantly up on a charge, and driving the enemy back, recovering the lost ground, recapturing many of the prisoners, and taking a large number of prisoners from the enemy. The rebels afterward took up a strong position, from which no attempt was made to drive them. Our army now holds the Weldon Railroad, which can be destroyed in our rear as far as Gen. GRANT chooses. Our total loss in this affair is put down at twenty-five hundred in killed, wounded and missing.

abstract: having the fear of the draft before his eyes, had the front teeth of his upper jaw extracted a few days ago. They were perfectly sound. The Salem, Massachusetts Register says that STEPHEN H. MORSE, of Amesbury, who was drafted in July, 1863, had eight teeth extracted to secure exemption, which he obtained, but the facts becoming known to the provost-marshal a few days ago, MORSE was arrested, and held to service, and assigned to the artillery, without the privilege of paying commutation or furnishing a substitute. He was sent to Gallon's Island on Tuesday. The Springfield Republican says a foolish conscript in Dalton cut off the index finger of his right hand after he was drafted, supposing he would be exempted for it. But the game didn't work. When he came to visit the board of enrollment he was accepted and sent to camp.

abstract: The recent advent of Â£1,039 in gold sovereigns in New-Haven has already made more or less trouble for three Englishmen. But, as many anticipated, the legitimate owners belong in England, and its disappearance has created a good deal of excitement there. It appears that on Thursday of last week, Mr. JOHN E. HUNT, Inspector of the Detective Department at Town Hall, Leeds, arrived in New-York, per steamer Scotia, accompanied by Capt. WARD, an officer connected with the Leeds Banking Company. They were in search of JOHN SPENCE, alias Gill, who, they claim, had absconded with nearly $25,000 belonging to that institution. It appears that, upon arriving here, Mr. SPENCE assumed the name of GILL. The detective first heard of the man at the United States Hotel, in New-York, and subsequently traced him to New-Haven. Here he communicated with the police, and yesterday noon Mr. GILL was taken in custody. Deputy Sheriff MIX, accompanied by Chief of Police POND, made the arrest in Fair Haven, while GILL was returning from a fishing excursion. Mr. GILL was welcomed by the Sheriff with. "How are you, Mr. SPENCE?" which cognomen the foreign gentleman had not heard pronounced for so long, that it quite surprised him, He was taken to the station-house where "lawyers for the Crown" and "lawyers for the prisoner," were full of business. The result of all this legal advice is, that Mr. SPENCE is now at liberty. It is understood that he produced such funds as he could command, sufficient in fact to satisfy the foreign officers, who were content to take up with a portion. Mr. GILL has conducted himself in a very gentlemanly manner since his debut in this city, and even now insists that the whole affair is the result of misunderstanding on the part of the English officer. -- New-Haven Journal, June 22.

abstract: Ithaca, N. Y., Heggie, Miss, Poisoned by her Mother
snippet: Ithaca, N. Y., Heggie, Miss, Poisoned by her Mother
lead_paragraph: The citizens of Ithaca, in this State, have been horrified at the death of Miss CHARLOTTE L. HEGGIE, on Wednesday, the 15th instant, by poisoning. She had been engaged at sewing by the Ladies' Aid Society in that village, when she was attacked with vomiting, burning at the stomach and other painful symptoms. Medical aid was rendered, but without success. She obtained no relief; and after lingering eight days was finally relieved by death. She was the oldest daughter of Mr. J.M. HEGGIE, of Ithaca, and was greatly esteemed.
