abstract: Egyptian, Origin and Importance of Supply
snippet: Egyptian, Origin and Importance of Supply
lead_paragraph: At the present time, when the cotton culture of the world is seeking an entirely new develop ment, and science is testing the capacities of various soils in every quarter of the globe, it may be of interest and importance to the public at large to examine one very striking source of supply which seems destined to immense productiveness. We refer to Egypt, where the famous Jumel cotton is making such rapid strides. The origin even of the name thus given to the North African commodity is scarcely understood by the vast majority of traders and consumers. The new Egyptian journal recently established under the name of the Isthmus of [???] contains many valuable statistics in reference to this article, and a full narrative of its late rise and progress in the annals of commerce, which we epitomize for the benefit of our readers.

abstract: and the Union; the Constitutional Amendment
snippet: and the Union; the Constitutional Amendment
lead_paragraph: We trust that we shall receive from those who are opposed to the abolition of Slavery by an amendment to the Constitution, a full and particular statement in the course of the Summer, of the manner in which they expect to see the Union restored and preserved without the abolition of Slavery. As far as we have been able to extract any definite meaning from Democratic speeches and letters on this subject hitherto, they acknowledge Slavery to be a source of danger to the Union, but solely owing to the extreme sensitiveness of the slave owners. Slavery, they say, is the proper condition of the negro, the only one suited to his powers and weaknesses, and the only one in which, as a race, he can receive all development of which he is capable. The strongest argument in its favor is that drawn from his needs. The benefit derived from his labor by the master is, after all, but a secondary consideration. If it were twice as great as it really is, it would be, urge these men, but a poor return for the education and protection bestowed by the master -- not, certainly, the education of books, but that better and more effectual kind, which consists in continuous restraint and judicious punishment. Socially, therefore, Slavery is an unmixed blessing, both for the negro and his owner. Politically, it may, in a Republic such as ours, become dangerous, not through any fault of its own, but through the turbulence and combativeness of its enemies. It becomes a source of anxiety only when the people of the Free States refuse to let it alone. If the North would make up its mind not to meddle with the institution, it would continue to be in the future, what it has been in the past, the great elevator of the negro, and the great enricher of the white man.
headline: {'main': 'Slavery and the Union.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Slavery and the Union.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: -- We understand that since the removal of Mr. STIMERS from the position of Chief Engineer of the new monitors, Mr. ERICSSON has taken charge of them, and will make radical changes on them, to make them, if possible, serviceable to the Government. It has been decided to fit up three or four of them to remove torpedoes. The turrets will be taken off, the extra piping in the water compartments taken out, and outriggers put on the bows, with appliances to remove torpedoes and other obstructions.

abstract: Examiner on Fourth of July and Declaration of Independence
snippet: Examiner on Fourth of July and Declaration of Independence
lead_paragraph: The Richmond papers seem not to think to much of the Fourth of July as they used to. As that anniversary comes round again, and they see that GRANT and his army persist in continuing to attack Richmond, when by all rules they ought to be in full retreat; and as the news comes to them of the destruction of the railroads in every direction, their thoughts naturally go back to the Fourth of July of last year, when PEMBERTON surrendered Vicksburgh to the same indomitable man, after a somewhat similar series of performances. The Richmond Examiner, in perhaps not the very best taste, refers to this surrender of PEMBERTON's in an article upon the political prospects of the Summer. JEFF. DAVIS and his protegee PEMBERTON, we should think, would hardly thank the Examiner for the allusion. Talking about ropes to a man whose father has been hung, has always been considered to be not quite the thing; and if the man stands in imminent danger of having his own neck stretched by the same rope, ordinary common sense would seem to insure the avoidance of such a subject.
headline: {'main': 'The Declaration of Independence Cars.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Declaration of Independence Cars.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: There is one article very much needed for the comfort of soldiers with amputated limbs, which neither the Sanitary nor the State agencies were able to supply in Fredericksburgh to any considerable extent, and that was the email cushions filled with sawdust or straw, to be put under the stump of a leg or arm. Where a stump lies flat upon the ground there are three evils attending it, viz.: the increased danger of vermin, the pain of the hard bed, and, more dangerous, perhaps, than either, the difficulty of discharging the pus, the reabsorption of which into the system is usually fatal. Many of the sheets sent to Fredericksburgh were torn into pieces, and the cushions hastily basted up and filled with straw, to supply the emergency.
lead_paragraph: There is one article very much needed for the comfort of soldiers with amputated limbs, which neither the Sanitary nor the State agencies were able to supply in Fredericksburgh to any considerable extent, and that was the email cushions filled with sawdust or straw, to be put under the stump of a leg or arm. Where a stump lies flat upon the ground there are three evils attending it, viz.: the increased danger of vermin, the pain of the hard bed, and, more dangerous, perhaps, than either, the difficulty of discharging the pus, the reabsorption of which into the system is usually fatal. Many of the sheets sent to Fredericksburgh were torn into pieces, and the cushions hastily basted up and filled with straw, to supply the emergency.

abstract: -- As there are many con[???]ting reports as to the manner of the [???]ng of J. P[???], SPARKS, Esq., the late representative of Henry County, we give the following facts, from one who attended his funeral: "On the day before Mr. SPARKS was murdered, a band of robbers, under the lead of 'black' DA[???] MARTIN, of [???]by County, had robbed Mr. SPARKS of $500 in money, about the same time that the burned the cars. On the next day, a similar band, [???] the leadership of BART JENKINS, of Henry County was passing, through Pleasureville, where Mr. SPARKS lived. Mr. SPARKS was lying asleep on a counter, in a store in Pleasureville, at the time the band was coming into town. Some friends of Mr. SPARKS waked him up, and told him to flee, that the rebels were coming. Mr. SPARKS started to run through a vacant lot to his house, which was only a short distance away. As JENKINS was coming into town he was heard to say: 'G -- d d -- n PRES. SPARKS; he has represented Henry County long enough.' As Mr. SPARKS was running across the vacant lot, to get away from the gang, and before Mr. SPARKS had shot at any of them. BART. JENKINS drew his pistol and shot SPARKS, the ball entering the side of SPARKS, producing his death in about 25 or 30 minutes. During the few minutes that he lived, Mr. GRIFFIN KELLY wrote his will at his request, dividing all his property between his sister and his daughter, who lived with him. It is certain that SPARKS had not fired at any of the gang, for SPARKS so said on his death-bed; and the fact that all the leads were still in his pistol when he died, puts this statement beyond further controversy. So foul & murder has rarely ever been perpetrated in Kentucky. We understand that JENKINS had a personal grudge against SPARKS, and this was doubtless the case of his murder." -- Frankfort Commonwealth, June 17.

abstract: The Directors of the Young Men's Christian Association of Richmond respectfully but earnestly submit to the benevolent and the patriotic throughout the Confederate States an appeal in behalf of the soldiers' families in this city. Since the commencement of the war Richmond has been a refuge for those who have been driven from their homes by our ruthless enemies. Thousands of helpless women and children, not from the devastated counties of Virginia alone, but from nearly every State of the Confederacy, have sought an asylum in our midst. Our citizens have been appealed to in numberless instances to relieve the sick and wounded soldiers, to furnish shoes and clothing for soldiers in the field and hospital, and to afford food and shelter for their suffering families, and nobly have they, in the great majority of instances, responded to every appeal.

abstract: -- The new ferry-boat Central, which attracts attention as and now lies in our river, opposite the foot of Market-street, is intended to run between Commu[???], near Jersey City, and New-York, in connection with the New-Jersey Central Railroad, as soon as their terminus in the former city is completed and their ferry established -- their dock on the New-York side being at the foot of Liberty-street. This beautiful boat is said to be the largest of the kind over built, being 225 feet long, 65 feet wide, and 13 feet 3 inches deep. It has an upper deck 14 feet high, 178 feet long, and 63 feet wide, under which are cabins on each side to accommodate 270 persons, besides spacious carriage-ways on each side of the engine. The cabins are furnished with mahogany doors, the floors are l [???]d with alternate strips of white ash and walnut, oiled, and the ceiling is covered with enameled cloth, in red, white and blue square and diamond forms. They are lighted by stained glass skylights by day, and have chandeliers each at night. They are also warmed by steam. The engine is very powerful. (50 inch cylinder and 11 feet stroke,) and cost $75,000. It is altogether the richest specimen of ferry-boat architecture we have ever seen. -- Newark Advertiser.

abstract: -- The Codex Sinaiticus. The library of Yale College has just received from the Emperor of Russia a gift of rare value and beauty. It is a fac-simile copy of the celebrated Greek manuscript of the Holy Bible, found in 1859 at the Convent of St. Catherine, on Mount Sinai, by Dr. TISCHENDORF, well known as one of the most learned students and critics of the sacred texts. At his request, the monks, in whose keeping this precious manuscript was found, agreed to present it to the Emperor ALEXANDER I, of Russia. This intelligent monarch at once appreciated the value of the Codex, and determined to have it elaborately reproduced (by means of fac-simile type especially cast for the purpose) so that copies might be presented to the chief public libraries of the world. So soon as the gift reached St. Petersburgh by the hands of Dr. TISCHENDORF, the text was transcribed, illustrated with a learned introduction and published in four quarto volumes. Three hundred copies were printed, two hundred of which the Emperor proposed to distribute to public institutions. A few were given to Dr. TISCHENDORF, through whom they were placed on sale, first at £25 and afterwards at £34 108.

abstract: an organized gang of bounty-swindlers in New-York, who depredate extensively in this State. They are shrewd, sharp fellows, and are seldom caught. We have heard of instances where some of these rascals have enlisted five times in New-Jersey, receiving $400 each time. An officer of the Thirty-fourth informed us yesterday that twelve hundred men had been equipped for his regiment. Of these about three hundred and fifty deserted before leaving the State, and about two hundred more on the route to Tennesse. -- Trenton Republican, June 24.

abstract: Fresh troops from the North are constantly arriving along the line of communication from Nashville to Chattanooga, and relieving the veteran forces from guard and garrison duty, that they may enter upon more active duty at the front. abstract: -- Another locomotive went to the depot this morning. It was drawn up by twelve horses. These locomotives are sent to St. Louis, for use on military roads in Tennessee and Georgia, Government having possession of five hundred miles of railroads in those States. By the first week in July there will have been turned out fifty locomotives for Government use by the works in this city, and it is not improbable that a further contract will be entered into by these parties. -- Paterson Gmordian, June 22.

abstract: TRIAL TRIP OF THE CHAUNCEY VIBBARD. --This new and swift North River clipper passenger steamer made her first trip from New-York to Albany, on Saturday, the 18th. She unmoored from her berth, foot of Desbrosses-street, at 7 A.M., and reached the dock at Albany at 3:30, having made a passage of remarkable speed, considering the usual disadvantages of foaming boilers, heated journals, &c., attending new engines. Indeed, her time between Rhinebeck and Catskill, one hour and six minutes, was the fastest ever made on the river between these points. From New-York to Rhinebeck, 100 miles, she ran in four hours forty-two minutes, making four landings. Her lines are singularly fine, and she cute the water forward and leaves it aft with almost no disturbance whatever. She made not more than twenty-five or twenty-five and a half revolutions a minute at most, upon her present trip; but experts on board say that without doubt she can make 25 miles an hour with 28 turns, after her machinery and boilers get into working order; and they anticipate that she will be the fastest boat on the river. The Vibbard is 285 feet long over all, 275 feet keel, 34 feet beam, 62 feet over the guards, 9 feet deep 860 tons burden, and draws 4 feet 7 inches of water. She was built for Messrs. VAN SANTVOORD & DAVIDSON, by LAWRENCE & FOULKS, North Fifth-street, Williamsburgh. Her engines are by FLETCHER, HARRISON & Co., and are of their usual style, having all the recent improvements. Her cylinder is of 55 inches diameter, 12 feet stroke; wheels 30 feet diameter. Her joiner work is by King & Eells, painting by Stephen Rogers, ornamental work by Barney & Styles, gilding, mirrors, &c., by J.B. Downing, and upholstery by A.T. Stewart & Co. Her frescoing and decorative finish are in cool and pleasant colors and graceful designs, showing uncommon good taste. Her appointments of every kind are very complete; they are in general of the usual character, one feature only requiring notice. This is her large extent of state-room accommodation secured by throwing into state-rooms the whole after-hold, commonly fitted with berths. The smoothness of the Hudson renders this practicable, permitting window ventilation under the guards. The Vibbard's officers are as follows: Captain, DAVID HITCHCOCK; Mate, Peter Bishop; Clerk, Alonzo W. Collyer; Chief Engineer, Wm.H. Gage; Second Engineer, Lewis Reiffenberg; Pilot, Guernsey Belts; Steward, C. Fairchild Steward John H. Conover of the Armenia was also, on board, and promoted efficiently the pleasure of the trip. Messrs. Van Santvoord, Foulks, and Fletcher, Supervisor Smith of this City, Capt. Peck of the St. John, and other steamboat men of renown, were present. The day was perfect, the guests well pleased, the boat very successful, the cooking and the table very good indeed, the officers attentive in that wisest of ways which enables the guest to feel himself welcome and at home. No journey could well be more complete in its kind. -- Tribune.

abstract: -- A letter from Kanawha River, West Virginia, says: "On the passage up, a few days ago, of a party of the Thirty-eighth Ohio, a man named HEMPHREYS leaped overboard and swam ashore. Passing by his home, he had asked for permission to stop a few minutes, and was refused, when he rushed suddenly to the hurricane deck and made a leap for the river. Rising to the surface, he struck out bravely for the shore amid a volley of cheers, and reached it safely. The boat passed on. After having kissed his wife he mounted a horse, and in fifteen minutes passed the boat, shouting lustily to be taken on. At the next station it was done.
lead_paragraph: -- A letter from Kanawha River, West Virginia, says: "On the passage up, a few days ago, of a party of the Thirty-eighth Ohio, a man named HEMPHREYS leaped overboard and swam ashore. After having kissed his wife he mounted a horse, and in fifteen minutes passed the boat, shouting lustily to be taken on. At the next station it was done.

abstract: Belligerent, England as a
snippet: Belligerent, England as a
lead_paragraph: The increasing probability of an interference in the Dano-German quarrel on the part of England, promises as, before very long, a full and satisfactory solution of the great question of neutral duties. It is not likely that England will send any large land force to the aid of the Dance. She will rely mainly on her fleet; will use it for the protection of Copenhagen, the blockade of Trieste and Venice, and the destruction of the Austrian fleet; and the English public look forward, we need hardly say, to a very easy vicinity. In a recent debate in the House of Commons, on the navy, it was boasted that one of the new iron-clads could destroy the whole Common navy.

abstract: The Broome-street Barracks, at the corner of Broome and Elm streets, contains at present but thirty-two prisoners, twelve of whom are alleged deserters awaiting trial. The others are confined for various military offences, mostly of a light character. Judging from a recent inspection of the premises, the unfavorable reports in regard to the state of the barracks, and the treatment of prisoners confined there, which have been circulated by friends of some of the inmates, have no foundation in fact. The rooms and halls are kept scrupulously clean and well ventilated; the daily rations served to the prisoners are ample, and of a good quality, and no unnecessary severity appears to be exercised in preserving order and discipline. Occasionally a turbulent bounty jumper or deserter, who shows a disposition to create a disturbance, or to make his exit through the windows -- a feat which several prisoners have successfully performed -- is compelled to tug about a chain and ball for a few days, or until he makes up his mind to accommodate himself with proper resignation and patience to a position into which his own folly has placed him. One trial of this is generally sufficient to accomplish the object.

abstract: a fire broke out on the third floor of No. 65 Vesey-street, in premises occupied by C. TOEPFER as a type foundry and dwelling. The upper floors and roof were entirely consumed. Mr. TOEPFER's loss will be about $1,000; supposed to be insured. The first floor occupied by S.B. ADAMS as a liquor store; damage by water about $300; insured for $2,000 in the Hamilton and Citizen's Insurance Companies. The building belongs to the estate of WILLIAM H. CAREY. It is damged about $2,500; insured. There was some slight damage done by water to the occupants of No. 63. The origin of the fire is unknown at present.

ADAMS as a liquor store; damage by water about $300; insured for $2,000 in the Hamilton and Citizen's Insurance Companies. The building belongs to the estate of WILLIAM H. CAREY. It is damged about $2,500; insured. There was some slight damage done by water to the occupants of No. 63. The origin of the fire is unknown at present.

abstract: BRUTAL OUTRAGE ON A WOMAN-A young man, who gave his name as JAMES CONNOLLY, was arraigned yesterday before Justice LEDWITH, at the Jefferson Market Police Court, on the charge of having, in company with another man, whose name is unknown, brutally beaten and afterward violated the person of BRIDGET WELSH, who is the complainant in the case. The latter testified that she is a resident of New-Brighton, Staten Island; that on Satur-...
lead_paragraph: BRUTAL OUTRAGE ON A WOMAN. -- A young man, who gave his name as JAMES CONNOLLY, was arraigned yesterday before Justice LEDWITH, at the Jefferson Market Police Court, on the charge of having, in company with another man, whose name is unknown, brutally beaten and afterward violated the person of BRIDGET WELSH, who is the complainant in the case. The latter testified that she is a resident of New-Brighton, Staten Island; that on Saturday afternoon she came up to the City for the purpose of finding a relative of hers named JAMES WELSH, who she was told lived in the vicinity of Second-avenue and Twenty-second-street; that she was an utter stranger in the City and searched until after dark before she found the street above-mentioned. On the corner she saw the prisoner CONNOLY, and asked him if he could direct her to the house of JAS. WELSH. He at first replied no; but immediately after another man came up, and CONNOLLY spoke a few words to him aside, and then prisoner said to BRIDGET that if she would go with the other man he would put her in the way of finding the person she sought. Complainant suspected nothing wrong, and never, having seen either of them before, she went with the stranger several doors from the corner to a house in Twenty-second-street. They entered a dark hallway and proceeded upstairs to a room, the door of which was unlocked by her conductor, and she was suddenly and rudely thrust into a dark room. Complainant became frightened at this, and felt confident that she was being foully dealt with. She began to scream as loud as possible, when a hand was quickly thrust over her mouth and she was told that, to make any more noise, would be at the peril of her life. The man continued to hold her down, and did all he could to violate her person. In the struggle her clothes were nearly torn from her person, and she was struck several times by the man in order to keep her still. After a time the prisoner, CONNOLY, made his appearance in the room, and he also assailed her, striking her in the jaw with his fist because she would not comply with his demands. The latter finally lighted a lantern which he had brought with him, and, after several gross insults had been offered to her by the men, they both departed, leaving her in the room alone and in the dark. As soon as possible after they had gone, she got out of the building, and finally found her way to the Eighteenth Precinct Station-house, where she told her story, and described the prisoner CONNOLLY so accurately that Officer HUTCHINSON was able soon after to effect his arrest. The other villain has not been secured. Justice LEDWITH committed CONNOLLY for trial in default of $1,000 bail. The prisoner says he is a native of this City, aged 27 years, resides at No. 349 Second-avenue and is by occupation a wire-drawer.

abstract: British American Confederacy; Steps Toward a
snippet: British American Confederacy; Steps Toward a
lead_paragraph: A Quebec correspondent, whose letter we publish in other columns to-day, gives some particulars supplemental of the telegraphic report, as to the political movements at the Canadian seat of Government. These movements -- if we are to suppose the actors sincere -- are not without interest to the outside world. The faction fights which had brought the Province almost to the verge of anarchy culminated some two weeks ago in the defeat of the Tory Ministry. The latter proposed to appeal from the House of Assembly to the country. But Gov. MONCK, although obliged according to constitutional usage to permit the appeal asked for by his advisers, appears to have urged his Council to make some attempt at cabinet reconstruction before going to the polls. He seems to have feared that a general election would supply no remedy for the sectional antagonism which practically threatened to make common legislation for the Gallic and Anglo-Canadian divisions of the colony impossible. Lord MONCK, doubtless acting according to secret instructions from Downing-street, and under the inspiring influence of the Lombard-street creditors of the Province, is understood to have strongly urged his Ministers to invite a coalition of parties, by making room in the Executive Council for several of the more violent and dangerous members of the Opposition; and he seems indeed to have employed the strongest kind of indirect influence to accomplish his purpose.

abstract: Magazines for July
snippet: Magazines for July
lead_paragraph: -- The Atlantic Monthly (Boston, TICKNOR & FIELDS,) commences with the present number its fourteenth volume, and bears itself proudly, pointing with complacency to an unrivaled list of contributors as an earnest of what may be expected in continuance of the exertions hitherto so conclusively crowned with success. The first article that most readers will turn to is undoubtedly a chapter, by HAWTHORNE, of the romance that he had been for some time engaged in writing for the Atlantic. Resembling his English cotemporary novelist, THACKERAY, in the circumstances of his decease, there is a further similarity in the fact that the last work of both was for the magazines they had been connected with, and the readers of the Cornhill and the Atlantic have alike seen with sadness the last incomplete efforts of their creative minds. HAWTHORNE's scene from the "Dolliver Romance" -- a detached passage elaborated with the finish of a cabinet picture, strikes a chord of psychological romance, which is now mute for a generation, at least. In this walk he had no rivals, and the public would certainly not at present endure mere imitators. "Glorying in the Goad," by GAIL HAMILTON, is full of common sense, and must be taken as a corrective to the pictures of rural elysiums, that are generally the product of a city imagination, "Saadi," by RALPH WALDO EMERSON, is apparently prefatory to the translation of the principal work of that poet, the "Gulistan, or Rose Garden," for some time announced as in preparation by Mr. EMERSON, IK MARVELL, continues his pleasant talks on "Farming, and Country affairs," with agricultural worthies of the last generation. "Meyerbeer," by FRANCIS WILLIAMS, gives some new particulars of that great composer's last days. The poetry, it is enough to say, is contributed by LONGFELLOW, BRYANT, and Dr. O.W. HOLMES.

abstract: Barbarities, Report of Congress Committee
snippet: Barbarities, Report of Congress Committee
lead_paragraph: The news from the Army of the Potomac this morning presents no new feature of striking in- terest. We have additional particulars from two of our correspondents respecting the losses of Wednesday; and we have also the report that on Friday morning LONGSTREET and A.P. HILL commenced moving toward Weldon, having vacated their intrenchments in our immediate front. On Friday the batteries of the Eighteenth portions of the Fifth and Second Corps, commenced firing upon the town of Petersburgh, with what result had not been ascertained. The Petersburgh and Weldon Railroad has also been under our guns for several days -- a circumstance which, taken in connection with the sudden wheeling round of LEE's forces in the direction of our extreme left south of Petersburgh, indicates that LEE means to fight for the maintenance of his southern lines with the whole force at his command. In the direction of Weldon we must look for the early occurrence of a stupendous engagement.

abstract: -- EWENG's Battery, a Pittsburgh organization, has arrived at Wheeling via Beverly, having just left Gen. HUNTER's army. Two of the members of the battery arrived in the city this morning. One of them, a Sergeant, says that when they left Staunton HUNTER's army had gone in the direction of Waynesboro to meet IMBODEN and Mudwall JACKSON. The latter had somehow worked around our army and succeeded in uniting his command with that of IMBODEN. This Sergeant moreover says that just on leaving Beverly, a scout, a courier, had arrived from Staunton, who said that HUNTER had fought JACKSON and IMBODEN's forces, and [???]d-whipped them badly, taking 1,500 prisoners. This news, if true, is important, as it indicates that HUNTER is proceeding in the direction of Charlottesville and Gordonsville rather than of Lynchburgh. We can scarcely, however, think this news reliable, or else STANTON would have first received and told it to the country. We give the report as it reaches us. It may go for what it is worth, -- Pittsburgh Chronicle, [???] 21.

abstract: BURNED. -- Late on Saturday night a fire occurred in the attic of a frame building rear of No. 204 West-street, in the premises of PETER SULLIVAN. The fire was caused by an old woman, named JULIA ROACH, aged 90 years, accidentally setting fire to her bed with a candle. She was rescued by CHAS. QUINN, very badly and probably fatally burned. She was taken to the New-York Hospital. The flames extended into the yard of the ship chandlery store, No. 205, owned by ALBERT VAN WINKLE, and before the firemen extinguished the fire the stock was damaged to the extent of from $5,000 to $8,000; fully insured. Mr. SULLIVAN's loss will be about $400; no insurance. The first floor of No. 204 is used by H.B. THOMAS for storage of lumber; damage about $150; insured. The boiler-shop of COBANKS & THEALL, No. 49 Harrison-street, was damaged by water about $100.

abstract: Rockaway, Pavilion Hotel
snippet: Rockaway, Pavilion Hotel
lead_paragraph: We learn that the Pavilion at Rockaway, together with the cottages within its grounds and several other adjacent buildings, was burned on Saturday afternoon. This will be a serious loss to the many persons in this city who had intended to make it their Summer home. It was a very large hotel, and had just passed into the hands of Mr. WALBRIDGE, formerly of Rochester, who had taken pains to make it specially attractive and agreeable for the season. The proximity of Rockaway to the city, and the excellence of its bathing, had made it a favorite watering place.

abstract: The War is Against
snippet: The War is Against
lead_paragraph: "I am tired of working for Yankee taskmasters. I hate their selfish meanness; and therefore I am in favor of a Western Confederacy." So says MARSHALL ANDERSON, of Ohio, in a letter declining the nomination, by the Democratic State Convention, of Presidential Elector. Mr. ANDERSON, we suppose, is not a lunatic. The Columbus Crisis, which is good "Democratic" authority, remarked of him that "a more worthy gentleman or better Democrat could not have been chosen;" and the Daily News, of this City, republishes his missive under the caption. "A Sound Letter." Whether sound or not, it is certainly frank, and therein to be commended.

abstract: Late last evening a serious affray occurred at the corner of Eighth-avenue and Forty-seventh-street, during which a man named BURNE, (his first name has not transpired,) member of Engine Company No. 1, stabbed four policemen of the Twenty-second Precinct. The names of the wounded officers are MICHAEL COREY, LEWIS BERMHOLE, JOHN C. ELDRODT and MARTIN BYRNS. It seems that the trouble originated between Officers COREY and BYRNS. The latter struck COREY while he was on his post and then ran, followed by a party of BYRN's associates. Word was immediately sent to the Station, when Capt. SLOTT started with a platoon of men for the scene of the trouble. At the corner of Forty-second-street and Eighth-avenue the crowd was overtaken by the officers, but BURNS had got into a house in Forty-second-street, near Eighth-avenue, and the father of Burns locked the door so they could not enter. The father is a police clerk at the Fourth District Court. Up to a late hour no arrest had been made. The policemen are not dangerously injured.
lead_paragraph: Late last evening a serious affray occurred at the corner of Eighth-avenue and Forty-seventh-street, during which a man named BURNE, (his first name has not transpired,) member of Engine Company No. 1, stabbed four policemen of the Twenty-second Precinct. The latter struck COREY while he was on his post and then ran, followed by a party of BYRN's associates. Word was immediately sent to the Station, when Capt. At the corner of Forty-second-street and Eighth-avenue the crowd was overtaken by the officers, but BURNS had got into a house in Forty-second-street, near Eighth-avenue, and the father of Burns locked the door so they could not enter. The father is a police clerk at the Fourth District Court. Up to a late hour no arrest had been made. The policemen are not dangerously injured.

abstract: NIBLO'S GARDEN. The current is the last week of the engagement of Mme. VESTVALI and of "Bel  Demonto," when this lady will retire into the country for two months to recruit her health, after ten months' incessant exertions, for the Fall campaign. abstract: Saturday afternoon a fire broke out on the roof of the building No. 10 Amity-street, occupied by A.S. DE VONVILLE. The flames rapidly spread along the roofs of Nos. 10, 12, 14 and 16, all of which were more or less damaged before the fire could be got under control. The roofs were of wood, and very dry, hence the damage, in spite of the efforts of the firemen. Mr. DE VONVILLE's loss will be about $700; insured for $500 in the New-Amsterdam Insurance Company. No. 12 was occupied by Mrs. G.W. VOOHIES, as a boarding house; loss about $600; insured for $750, in the Peter Cooper Insurance Company. No. 14 was occupied by Mr. ALEXANDER GAW; furniture damaged about $500; insured in the Lorillard Insurance Company. Mr. GAW also owns buildings Nos. 8, 10, 12 and 14. They are damaged to the extent of about $3,500; insured for $7,500, in the Knickerbocke[???] Insurance Company. No. 16 was occupied by Miss MARKS; furniture damaged about $400, by water; fully insured in the Jefferson Insurance Company. The building belongs to the estate of HENRY MARKS. It is damaged about $500; fully insured in the Jefferson Insurance Company. No. 18 was occupied by JAMES H. GOLDEN; furniture damaged by water about $100; no insurance. The building is owned by Mr. MCCADDEN. It is damaged about $200; insured.

abstract: The only fighting that took place yesterday was an attack made by the enemy on Gen. BURNSIDE, but whether intended as a feint to cover some more important move, or an attempt to break through his lines, it was a failure. They opened with a heavy fire of artillery, which was returned by our batteries, and the rebels, making a charge, were driven back in confusion, upwards of one hundred being taken prisoners. This occurred about 8 A.M., and the artillery firing was kept up for an hour, when all became quiet at that point.

abstract: An unusual number of vessels are arriving at this port, having small pox and ship fever on board. They are mostly from England and Ireland. On Friday, Dr. GWINBURNE, Health Officer, quarantined an English vessel having twenty-two cases on board. The most effective measures are taken by him to prevent the introduction of these diseases, and every vessel which is known to have had a case on board during the voyage is detained and quarantine until all danger from it is passed. The sick are sent to Blackwell's Island; the well are detained on the vessels, are vaccinated when there has been small pox, the vaccination proven, &c., where falling the persons revaccinated. The clothing on board is cleansed, and the vessel thoroughly cleaned and fumigated.

abstract: -- The remaining members of Companies I and K, First New-Jersey Regiment, and of HEXAMER's Battery, in all numbering about forty men, enlisted from Hoboken, and who have just been mustered out from the three years service, received a public reception and supper at Hoboken on Saturday night. The supper took place at Otto Cottage Garden, and was given by the Fire Department and citizens. The veterans were welcomed home in an eloquent and patriotic speech by Gen. E.R.V. WRIGHT, on behalf of the Mayor of the City.

abstract: ger of our soldiers before Richmond just now is scurvy. They have an abundance of meat, but lack vegetables, and the effect of such diet both at sea or on land, with salt meat or fresh, is to engender scurvy. In many quarters special efforts are made to send them vegetables, and this ought to be the case everywhere. Onions, particularly, are known to be of the utmost value, yet none are to be had under present circumstances.

abstract: terday by Coroner RANNEY on the body of JAMES MCGRATH, who died from the effects of poison administered by himself. He had been drinking to excess for several days previous, and it is supposed that during a temporary aberration of mind he swallowed a quantity of Paris Green, which had been purchased for the purpose of destroying insects in his house. His wife was present at the time, but all her efforts to arrest the suicidal hand were fruitless. Deceased was a native of Ireland, aged 45 years.

abstract: Hyer, Tom., Pugilist
snippet: Hyer, Tom., Pugilist
lead_paragraph: Coroner NAUMANN was, yesterday, called upon to hold an inquest on the body of THOMAS HYER, a man well known in this community, and especially in sporting circles for many years, as "TOM HYER." Deceased had been complaining for several years, but as a general thing he has not been confined to his house. On Saturday he was out, and returned to his residence, No. 155 East Thirty-fifth-street, between 12 and 1 o'clock yesterday morning. He came in a light wagon, accompanied by a friend. He sat on his front stoop about fifteen minutes, when he complained of illness and asked for ice water, which was furnished. Soon after he was taken to bed and continued to grow worse, breathing shorter and shorter and with greater difficulty until 5:30 o'clock yesterday morning, when he expired. Dr. THOMAS ROBINSON made a post-mortem examination of the body. He found the heart very large and fatty, and the pericardium filled and distended with serum. The liver was also very much diseased, and the whole structure of it entirely degenerated into a schirrus mass. The spleen was enormously large, measuring 10 1/2 inches in length, 8 inches in width and weighed several pounds. The doctor was of the opinion that the immediate cause of death was cardiac dropsy. Deceased was 45 years of age, and a native of New-York.

abstract: Col. WASS, of the Nineteenth Massachusetts Regiment, who reached home to-day on sick-leave, states that among our men captured by the rebels in the affair of Wednesday, was the entire brigade comprising the Fifteenth and Nineteenth Massachusetts, and the Forty-second and Eighty-second New-York Regiments. BARLOW's and GIBBON's divisions being formed in line of battle BARLOW precipitately fell back on receiving the attack of the enemy. From the nature of the ground, which was uneven and covered with a thick undergrowth, this movement was not perceived by GIBBONS, who stood his ground, and before he was aware of it, the bayonets of the enemy were at his back.

abstract: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of all military movements in the different departments from the pens of our special correspondents. Also, all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news, European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, giving the tone of public feeling abroad, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports; items of agricultural and domestic interest, compiled from sources many of which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader; and marriages and deaths of the week.

abstract: The steamship Bavaria, from Southampton 15th inst., arrived at Cape Race yesterday, with two days later advices. The London Times says the comparative ease of the French discount market, and the recovery of the stock of gold in the Bank of France, fail to counteract the chronic distrust of the financial and commercial classes in NAPOLEON's foreign policy. It also says that the high price of gold in New-York indicates the want of confidence the public have in the position of the army in Virginia. A rumor is talked of confidently on 'Change, of the possible break-up of the Cabinet on the Danish question. A Copenhagen dispatch says, that "The Danish Notables, in an address to the King, intimate that the personal union of Schleswig and Holstein with the kingdom would entail the loss of Schleswig, while the incorporation of the Constitution of Schleswig with that of the kingdom would endanger the independence of Denmark. The continued prolongation of the armistice is impossible, unless the basis of a satisfactory peace is proposed." Earl RUSSELL is said to have intimated, that if, when hostilities were resumed, the Austrian fleet should proceed to the Baltic, England would be compelled to send a fleet also. Austria, however, will not send a fleet if the truce is prolonged. The plenipotentiary of the Germanic Confederation is said at a sitting of the conference, to have laid down the principle that no part of Schleswig can be ceded to Denmark without the consent of the population. The pirate Alabama was reported at Cherbourg on the 13th inst.

abstract: a rumor of a very serious accident on the Erie Railroad yesterday, as having occurred on Sunday, and involving the loss of many lives. It proves less fatal than was anticipated, but one life having been lost. A collision occurred early Sunday morning, between a freight and gravel train, near Hohokus, some 27 miles from Jersey City. It was serious enough, however, to interrupt the running of the trains up to some trains yesterday. As a consequences, no milk trains arrived, which occasioned very serious inconvenience. Many hotels and restaurants were without milk the whole day, and as high as $1 per quart was paid for the "swill" article. The usual silly and scandalous reticence of railroad corporations was observed by the officers and employes of the Erie Railroad Company in this instance, and though in possession, at this end of the road, of all the facts, they were withheld until rumor had exaggerated an accident to a catastrophe. When Railroad Companies come to learn that the best policy is the "truth, the whole truth, and nothing but the truth," and the sooner they give it to the public the better, they will save themselves much of undeserved stricture and consequent unpopularity. This suppression and withholding has been, of late, practiced to an offensive extent in this vicinity, and it were better that it was abandoned.

lead_paragraph: Those familiar with the working of party government in England, have all along perceived, since the outbreak of the war between Germany and Denmark, that the actual participation of England in the dispute, must be preceded by the breaking up of the Palmerston Cabinet. abstract: Our advices from the Army of the Potomac are up to Sunday morning. There had been no serious fighting since the previous Wednesday. It seems that on Friday the rebels evacuated the position which they had held in front of the Second Corps, and prolonged their right flank against our left, as if to protect the railroad from our further advance. As our guns command it, and as Gen. WILSON has pretty thoroughly destroyed it some distance below Petersburgh the road can be of no use to the enemy. Our special Washington dispatch gives a concise statement, based upon the very best authority, of the great damage done to LEE's railroad communications, most of which cannot be readily repaired. Gen. SHERIDAN has safely reached the south side of the James River with his cavalry.

abstract: And Military Law; (Suspension of New-York World, >amp;c); Mr. Schenck on the Commutation Clause
snippet: And Military Law; (Suspension of New-York World, >amp;c); Mr. Schenck on the Commutation Clause
lead_paragraph: We don't wonder that the Grand Jury refuse to lend themselves to the attempt of Gov. SEYMOUR to make party capital out of the suspension of the World and the Journal of Commerce. The letter of the Governor to the District-Attorney, breathed a spirit repugnant to the feelings of all true men; and very naturally the Grand Jury resolved that it was "inexpedient to examine into the subject." They felt it their duty not to abet fiction.

abstract: Meeting in New-York; Fremont and Cochrane Ratification Meeting
snippet: Meeting in New-York; Fremont and Cochrane Ratification Meeting
lead_paragraph: The Fremont ratification last night was a curious affair, -- admirably in keeping with the movement itself. It was respectably large, and reasonably enthusiastic, -- but both its size and its enthusiasm were due to everything else than the Fremont element. Inside the meeting seemed to be about equally divided between the friends of MCCLELLAN and those of LINCOLN, -- while outside it was almost exclusively a MCCLELLAN gathering. Occasional cheers were given for FREMONT and COCHRANE, but without any special zest or heartiness. To all intents and purposes it was a Democratic gathering, -- just as the movement itself is neither more nor less than a Democratic demonstration. There was not at the meeting, nor is there anywhere, either in this State or any other, the slightest desire to make FREMONT President -- or the faintest shadow of belief that, upon any ground, personal or political, he ought to be elected. He is used as a willing tool by men who, like himself, have revenges to gratify, or by others who seek a party triumph to aid in the defeat of Mr. LINCOLN. Just now the Democrats are using him to swell the roll of Mr. LINCOLN's enemies. They are trying hard to make it appear that he has a very formidable opposition among those who have formerly been his advocates. When they have made FREMONT sufficiently serviceable in the accomplishment of this purpose, they will throw him aside like any other tool for whom they have no further use. This is the simple meaning of the whole movement.
headline: {'main': 'The Fremont Meeting.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Fremont Meeting.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Speech at New-York Tremont Meeting
snippet: Speech at New-York Tremont Meeting
lead_paragraph: Last night the unterrified Democracy of this City met at the Cooper Institute to aid and abet in the ratification of the nominations of Gen. JOHN C. FREMONT, the Faultfinder -- beg pardon -- the Pathfinder and Gen. JOHN COCHRANE, the Placefinder. The large hall of the Institute had been ornamented with a profusion of small American flags, appended to each of which was a placard containing a motto, such as have been usually displayed on the transparencies of Copperhead gatherings heretofore. Two or three cartoons, exhibiting feeble efforts at wit at the expense of the Administration, were displayed on the platform.

abstract: The $2,000,000 loan recently authorize by the Board of Supervisors for bounties, it not being taken at rapidly at was anticipated, still a sufficient sum has been subscribed to warrant the belief that the amount will remain open for proposals but a short time. Our capitalists are beginning to realize the act that twenty-year bonds of the City, bearing six per cent, interest, will prove a good investment. Nearly a half million ...
lead_paragraph: The $2,000,000 loan recently authorize by the Board of Supervisors for bounties, it not being taken at rapidly at was anticipated, still a sufficient sum has been subscribed to warrant the belief that the amount will remain open for proposals but a short time. Our capitalists are beginning to realize the act that twenty-year bonds of the City, bearing six per cent, interest, will prove a good investment. Nearly a half million dollars have been subscribed at par, or above. The plan adopted by Supervisor BLUNT will be adhered to, and the entire matter of recruiting will be under his immediate supervision. Arrangements with the authorities at Washington have been perfected so that there will be no mistake concerning the manner in which the newly-enlisted men shall be credited to the City under any call of the Government. The want of action on the part of Congress in net deciding as to the repeal or retention of the commutation clause, is an embarrassment in the way of determining what action the Board of Supervisors will take with reference to extra inducements to those desiring to enlist; for should the clause be repealed the prices paid for substitutes would be greater than the county bounty. It is, therefore, necessary to know what action Congress will take in the matter, in order to determine the prospects for rapid enlistments. Although it has been settled that all enlisted men are to be credited to the quota of the County under any new call, yet it is not known what that quota will be, or on what terms the men will be received. There is now an excess in favor of the county, under the old call, of over 1,100 men, which will, of course, be credited to any new quota. The clerks and others who were engaged while the last quota was being filled, although not under pay, are holding themselves in readiness, to resume operations. There are a large number of applications daily at the Park Recruiting Barracks to enlist, all of which are refused, and regretfully so, as hundreds might have been enlisted in anticipation of a new call. It is, however, quite evident that there, will be no difficulty in filling any quota required of the County. The HancocK Substitute Recruiting Committee are doing well, when it is considered that none but aliens are taken. Since Saturday fifteen recently landed foreigners have been enlisted by the committee as substitutes.

abstract: Our advices from Panama bring dates to the 17th inst. A revolution is reported to have broken out in Ecuador against GARCIA MORENO and Gen. FLORES. The movement, was, however, confined to the small village of Manta. The people arose and captured the garrison of twenty-five men, with their Commander. The Governor of the district was at liberty on parole, and negotiations were going on about paying the expenses of the war. Trifling as this may seem, it is thought it may stimulate the people to movements which will result in the displacement of GARCIA MORENO. A force from the French fleet, consisting of 500 infantry and 250 cavalry, are reported to have taken possession of the City of Acapulco. No opposition was made. The blockade of Acapulco was raised.

abstract: The Broadway Tabernacle Church has started a plan for recruiting our armies, which might be followed with advantage by churches all over the land. Last Sunday morning, in a sermon on "Manliness," Dr. THOMPSON appealed to the congregation to exemplify that virtue, by standing up manfully in aid of Gens. GRANT and SHERMAN. He urged that they should have men enough to supply the wastes of the campaign, and to follow up promptly its successes; and proposed that those members of his congregation who are exempt from the draft should take pains at once to send representatives into the field. He named twenty men as a proper quota for the Tabernacle Church, in this extra volunteer service. The church is already well represented in the field by its young men, the pastor himself having sent two sons.

abstract: The suggestion of a special contribution for the procurement of a supply of vegetables for the Army of the Potomac, in view of the approaching holiday, has met with a practical and liberal response in many quarters. Let us repeat our recommendation to the City Government at least to divide its holiday appropriation with the brave soldiers in the field. It will serve as an admirable example to others, and will redound to the highest credit of the donors.

abstract: Official advices from Gen. GRANT, up to Monday, May 27, at 3:30 P.M., are received. No new operations are reported. Our guns in front of Petersburgh are firing upon the bridge over the Appomattox, at a distance of 2,000 yards.
lead_paragraph: Official advices from Gen. GRANT, up to Monday, May 27, at 3:30 P.M., are received. No new operations are reported. Our guns in front of Petersburgh are firing upon the bridge over the Appomattox, at a distance of 2,000 yards. A Petersburgh paper of the 25th, says Gen. WILSON destroyed a train of cars loaded with cotton and furniture, burned the depot buildings, and destroyed the railroad at Burkesville. He was still pushing south. Burkesville is the point of crossing of the Petersburgh and Lynchburgh Railroad and the Richmond and Danville Railroad.

Bird.----The plaintiff sued as administrator with the will annexed, on the estate of Emily Olcott, deceased, to recover the rent of the premises of No.114 Chambers-street. abstract: The Senate Committee on Foreign Affairs had a protracted discussion to-day over the Arguelles case Secretary SEWARD has sent to the committee a very elaborate report upon the subject, in which  she action of the Government in handing ARGUELLES over to the Spanish authorities is not only sustained, but fully justified. The committee adjourned without coming to any decision in the matter. It will undoubtedly go over untill next session.

abstract: Delacy vs. Wood. -- This case was stated in the TIMES of Thursday. The plaintiff claimed for services which she was ready to perform, after the 21st March last, at the Olympic, in the character of "walking lady." The defendant claimed that the season ended at that time, and that the plaintiff was not entitled to pay thereafter under an engagement for the season. The court now rendered decision in favor of the plaintiff, holding that, as no decision had yet determined the length of a theatrical season, and as competent witnesses (Messrs. Davidge and Vincent) had testified that such a season varied from forty to forty-two weeks, the plaintiff must recover.
lead_paragraph: Delacy vs. Wood. -- This case was stated in the TIMES of Thursday. abstract: at the Fremont Meeting
snippet: at the Fremont Meeting
lead_paragraph: In a speech once made in Tammany Hall, JOHN COCHRANE declared that he would "support the regular nominee, FERNANDO WOOD, for Mayor, were he a devil incarnate." Dr. ORESTES A. BROWNSON, in advocating the ticket of FREMONT and COCHRANE, seems to have caught the same frenzy, with a little milder type. He says that he will support any man who can defeat the reelection of ABRAHAM LINCOLN -- even HORATIO SEYMOUR, VALLANDIGHAM, or FERNANDO WOOD.

abstract: New-York, Chatham-street, Furniture Factory, $50,000
snippet: New-York, Chatham-street, Furniture Factory, $50,000
lead_paragraph: -- DAMAGE ESTIMATED AT OVER $60,000. -- Soon after three o'clock yesterday afternoon, flames were discovered issuing from the windows of the fifth floor of the large brick building, known as Nos. 138 and 140 Chatham-street, corner of Baxter. The premises were mainly occupied by Mr. E. KINGMAN, manufacturer and dealer in cabinet furniture. The fire originated in the varnish room, where one of the men was at work at the rime. The cause of it is, however, unknown at present. The Fire-Marshal is engaged making an investigation as to its origin. The three upper floors were entirely destroyed, and all the lower portion of the buildings badly damaged. Mr. KINGMAN's loss on furniture, fixtures, &c., by fire and water will not fall far short of $40,000. He is insured for $30,000 in the North River, Lenox, Tradesmen's, Atlantic, St. Mark's, New-York, Equitable, Firemen's, Astor and other insurance companies. Mr. T. THOMPSON occupied the corner store as a porter-house. His damage to stock and fixtures by fire and water is about $600; insured for $1,500 in the Jefferson Insurance Company. Mr. L. ST. JOHN, who kept a broker's office on the first floor, was damaged to the amount of $200; no insurance. Mr. R. HUTCHINSON occupied a small store under the buildings on the Baxter-street side as a second-hand clothing establishment. A portion of his stock was removed, but he has sustained a loss of about $300. The buildings were owned by Mr. H.B. HOFFMAN. The loss on them is between $12,000 and $15,000; said to be fully insured in City companies. Capt. JOURDAN, with his men of the Sixth Precinct, and also platoons from the Third, Fourth and Twenty-seventh Precincts, were on hand promptly and rendered valuable assistance in saving property.

abstract: The United States steamer Newborn recently brought to this port thirty-one prisoners, captured on board the prize steamer Thistle, in the attempt to violate the blockade of Wilmington.
lead_paragraph: The United States steamer Newborn recently brought to this port thirty-one prisoners, captured on board the prize steamer Thistle, in the attempt to violate the blockade of Wilmington. These prisoners made affidavits that they were British subjects, and twenty-eight of them were discharged by Marshal MURRAY, under the instructions of the Navy Department relating to foreign subjects violating the blockade. The remaining three, whose names were ascertained to be JAMES CROWDERS, CHARLES DRAKE and J.D. ALLISON, were discovered to be Kentuckians, formerly belonging to the guerrilla band of Gen. MORGAN. They had been captured and confined at Camp Chase, Ohio, but contrived to make their escape into Canada, whence they proceeded by way of Halifax to Nassau. From Nassau they sailed in the blockade-runner Thistle, for Wilmington, with the avowed purpose of rejoining Gen. MORGAN. The capture of the Thistle produced an awkward derangement of their plans, and brought them into the custody of Marshal MURRAY. These facts were elicited by a long and close examination, As the prisoners appeared to be possessed of considerable shrewdness and ability, the Marshal transferred them yesterday to Fort Lafayette, under a guard provided by Gen. DIX, whence they will find it a more difficult job to escape than it was to undermine the walls of Camp Chase.

abstract: George the Count Joannes vs. The Bee Printing Company and Horace H. Day. -- This motion was stated in the TIMES of yesterday. The defendants applied for an order requiring the plaintiff to file security for costs as a non-resident. The plaintiff opposed the motion, contending that he was a resident, and setting forth the same facts as used in opposition to a like motion in the Count's suit against John Clancy, in the Common Pleas, where it was held that the plaintiff was a non-resident, and he was required to file security.

abstract: About 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon a company of recruits from Goshen, in charge of a provostguard of eleven men, were passing through Morrisstreet, near Washington, on their way to Pier No.1, where they were to take the boat for Amboy, one of the recruits threw off his knapsack and attempted to make his escape by running down the street at full speed.
lead_paragraph: About 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon a company of recruits from Goshen, in charge of a provostguard of eleven men, were passing through Morrisstreet, near Washington, on their way to Pier No.1, where they were to take the boat for Amboy, one of the recruits threw off his knapsack and attempted to make his escape by running down the street at full speed. The sergeant of the guard called to him to stop, and threatened to shoot him down unless he obeyed. This only served to accelerate his speed; and the sergeant, according to his instruction, ordered his men to fire. Several men fired at the deserter, killing him instantly, and unfortunately wounding two citizens. One of these, named DEMPSEY, residing at No. 18 Morris-street, was slightly wounded in the arm. The other, whose name is JOHN F. JOLEY, received severe wounds in the neck and both legs.

abstract: Schools Investigating Committee
snippet: Schools Investigating Committee
lead_paragraph: -- A morning cotemporary gives place to an insinuation against the Investigating Committee of the Board of Education, which can only be characterized as cowardly. The board is praised for its commendable alacrity in ferreting out the iniquities practiced in the Fourth Ward school. But to this is added the sneaking assertion that "there is an impression abroad that the board shows more zeal in overhauling schools in the Fourth and Sixth Wards, than in those situated in more aristocratic quarters." The answer to this is plain: The Investigating Committee has been instructed to continue its examination into the condition of the Ward schools generally. It neither shirks nor seeks to postpone that duty. And if, as is alleged in the journal from which we have quoted, the Fifteenth Ward schools need overhauling, why are the complaints relating thereto not lodged with the Board of Education, instead of being carried to the office of a partisan journal, which seeks to screen the evil-doers of the Fourth Ward by representing that the committee, while punishing them, has been careful to spare others? The committee needs no apology or defence put forward in its behalf. But it is right that the public should know the baseless character of the charges leveled at it by the organs of the villanous crew which had possession of the public schools in certain wards before the committee commenced its labors.

abstract: The City of London arrived at this port yesterday. She brings the summary of the Sidon, which left Liverpool on the 14th inst. The rebel cruiser Alabama arrived at Cherbourg; France, on the 11th of June, and was admitted to free pratique. She landed forty prisoners, the crews of vessels she had destroyed. She requires exten
lead_paragraph: The City of London arrived at this port yesterday. She brings the summary of the Sidon, which left Liverpool on the 14th inst. The rebel cruiser Alabama arrived at Cherbourg; France, on the 11th of June, and was admitted to free pratique. She landed forty prisoners, the crews of vessels she had destroyed. She requires extensive repairs, and is to be permitted to make them in the dock at Cherbourg. Capt. SEMMES has written a long letter to the London Times, explaining why the Confederate cruisers burn their prices, and says they would much prefer sending them for adjudication into the ports most convenient for the parties concerned. The British Government has sent instructions to Governors of Colonies respecting the treatment of prizes captured by Federal or Confederate cruisers, if brought into British waters. The captors shall be notified immediately to depart and remove the prize. If they do not depart at the time prescribed by the Governor, the prize is to be detained until Her Majesty's pleasure shall be made known. A vessel which has been converted into, and used as a public vessel of war, is not to be deemed a prize within the meaning of these rules. The London Times says that a quantity of forged Confederate Bonds of twenty pounds each, have been put incirculation in England, also that an enormous amount of counterfeit Confederate bonds have been received from New-York and put in circulation. The Daily News says that the plot for overturning the Government is believed to have broken down and been abandoned by its authors. The Morning Herald contends that a new Ministry, under Lord DERBY, would obtain for the Germans the line of the Schlei for the Danish frontier. The Dano-German Conference had been postponed to June 18. There is a rumor in circulation in France that the Emperor of Russia intends visiting Paris in the strictest incognito. Marshal MCMAHON, it is said, will succeed the late Duke of MALAKOFF in the Governorship of Algeria. Advices from Algiers contain the reported death of MARABOUT DE EL ARZEY, one of the leaders of the insurrection. The Emperor of Russia and the King of Prussia are to meet at Kossenten. It is conjectured that a political understanding is aimed at.

abstract: The Navy Department has decided on the course to be pursued in regard to the fleet of lightdraft iron-clad war steamers, whose failure has recently been brought to the notice of the public.
lead_paragraph: The Navy Department has decided on the course to be pursued in regard to the fleet of lightdraft iron-clad war steamers, whose failure has recently been brought to the notice of the public. Orders were received here a few days since, by Admiral GREGORY, instructing him to dispatch at once to Boston one of his best engineers, for the purpose of ascertaining the exact condition of the Chime and her sister ships, the completion of which has been announced. Accordingly, Chief Engineer NEWTON, U.S.N., of the Admiral's Staff, left this City at once, and is now in Boston. He has, we understand, submitted to the Government a detailed statement of the shortcomings of the vessels. Operations have, therefore, been ordered at once to commence on the Chime and her consort, with a view to convert them into some sort of serviceable craft. Mr. NEWTON is assisted by another naval engineer.

abstract: Carples vs. Mark, U. S. Collector; No Injunction Allowed on Collectors
snippet: Carples vs. Mark, U. S. Collector; No Injunction Allowed on Collectors
lead_paragraph: Bernard Carples et al, vs. John Marks, Collector of Internal Revenue for the Fourth District.--Application being made to the court on the part of the plaintiffs for an injunction restraining the defendan from enforcing the collection of a tax of $16,662 assessed by him in his official capacity within his collection district as against the property of the plaintiffs, under the act of Congress entitled "An Act to provide internal Revenue to support the Government and to pay interest on the public debt," approved July 1, 1862; and notice, with a copy of such application being served on the Attorney of the United States, and the said Attorney appearing thereupon in court, and opposing the motion made on such application, but neither the defendant nor the Commissioner of Internal Revenue having entered any formal appearance in court in the matter, or filed any assent in writing, to the proceedings taken on the part of the plaintiffs thereon. And counsel for the plaintiffs and for the United States appearing for those parties respectively, and the premises being fully considered by the court, it is ordered and adjudged by the court that, under the provisions and policy of the act aforesaid, the redress demanded on the part of the plaintiffs is first to be sought for and claimed by appeal, pursuant to the directions of the said act. That whether the Government may rightfully assent to the adjustment before courts of justice of interests and claims litigated solely between individuals, and accept the judicial determination of the interests of the Government connected with such litigation as final to public rights involved therein, is not material to inquire; but in the opinion of the court, it is not permissible to the judiciary to restrain and coerce the executive branch of the Government as demanded in this suit, from collecting the public taxes and revenue according to the provisions of stated law, and draw to itself de novo jurisdiction over such subject matter without first obtaining the direct consent or acquiescence of the Government thereto.

abstract: In the Senate yesterday, the bill for the relief of the officers of the Indian Regiments was passed. The bill amendatory of the laws concerning commercial intercoorse between the loval and insurrectionary States, was brought up amended and passed. The pending motion to reconsider the vote by which the bill to prevent military interfence with the elections was passed, was taken up and reflected.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate yesterday, the bill for the relief of the officers of the Indian Regiments was passed. The bill amendatory of the laws concerning commercial intercoorse between the loval and insurrectionary States, was brought up amended and passed. The pending motion to reconsider the vote by which the bill to prevent military interfence with the elections was passed, was taken up and reflected. The resolution to allow Senators and Representatives to visit the military forts, prisons and hospitals, in their respective States, was rejected. The bill to establish a Bureau of Freedmen's Affairs was then taken up and debated at length. In the evening session no business was transacted. An acrimonious debate between Messrs. WlLKINSON, of Minnesota and DAVIS, of Kentucky, occupied nearly the entire time. Mr. DAVIS disgraced himself.

abstract: -- It will be seen that the Senate Military Committee yesterday struck out the sixty days grace for volunteering in the House Bill. This destroys the hope of compromise on the commutation clause -- unless the Senate reverses the decision of the committee. A provision that ample notice should be given of the draft was the salvation of the bill in the House. But for that provision, most assuredly the three hundred dollar clause would have been retained. It would seem, therefore, that the only hope now of getting the measure through in any workable form will lie in an acceptance by both Houses of what is the clear, unmistakable judgment of the public that there should be a fixed commutation fee, big or little, And in this matter public opinion, as well as merely official theories, must be consulted, to insure cordial cooperation on all hands in the great work before us.

abstract: At a meeting of the Managers of New-York, held at the residence of Mr. WALLACK, in Fourteenth-street, on Tuesday, June 28, it was unanimously resolved that Mr. JAMES W. WALLACK be elected President, Mr. W. STUART Secretary. The subject of the recent increased demands of the musicians being brought before the meeting, it was resolved, on the proposition of Mr. WHEATLEY, seconded by Mr. MAX MARETZEK, the managers being desirous to act in a liberal and generous spirit, are prepared to ac[???]de to the demands of the musicians for a renewed increase of salary to $14 a week for the theatres, and $5 50 for every opera performance, on the distinct understanding that the musicians agree to abide by this, their present demand, for the season of 1864-65, and not again require any additional increase. It was further resolved that the salary of leader of orchestra shall be a matter of private arrangement between managers and leaders.

abstract: The steamship Washington, the first of the new Transatlantic line of steamers, arrived here yesterday, from Havre, with a fair passenger list and a full freight. The Sidon, an extra Cunard boat, also arrived yesterday, bringing nearly four hundred passengers. This constant stream of emigration, and these steady accessions to the great Atlantic ferry lines, supply a practical and satisfactory commentary on the idle talk of the Clanricardes and their fellows, as to the employment of secret recruiting agencies for the United States army abroad. We shall next hear that this new Transatlantic line, of which the Washington is the pioneer, is in receipt of secret bounty-money from the Department of the Provost-Marshal-General. The one story would be quite as feasible as the other. Nay, it would be a far more rational proceeding to subsidize steamship lines, to bring hither the crowds that line the piers of all the chief emigrant ports of the United Kingdom, waiting for passages, than to spend the money in scouring the wilds of Connemara for a few stray Irishmen, under the pretence of recruiting the national army.

abstract: The annual exhibition of the New-York Institution for the Blind took place last evening, in the chapel of the institution. Quite a large audience assembled to witness the wonderful performances of the pupils. The exercises consisted of examinations, singing and playing on the piano, and the proficiency and skill displayed by the young lads and misses was really astonishing. The institution contains at present about 185 pupils, and employs 20 teacher.

abstract: In the Senate yesterday, the resolution to inquire as to what progress has been made in the construction of gunboats contracted for in 1862, was adopted. A report was made in favor of printing the report of the commission over which Gen. MCDOWELL presided, in relation to certain alleged frauds in the Western Department on motion all further proceedings were indefinitely postponed. The House bill for the relief of MARY KELLOG, whose husband was hanged as a spy in Richmond, was passed. The matter of publishing the documents with reference to the French and Mexican Question was referred to the Committee on Printing. The resolution declaring Messrs. FISHBACK and BAXTER, not entitled to seats as Senators from Arkansas was brought up, and after considerable discussion, passed by a vote of 27 yeas to 6 nays. The bill in amendment of the Pension Act of July 14, 1862, was taken up, amended and passed. One of the amendments adopted provides that the benefits of this bill shall extend to the wives and children of colored soldiers, without further proof than the fact that the parties have lived together for two years. The bill to reimburse Pennsylvania for the expenses of the militia in the rebel invasion of last year was brought up and amended. A report was received from the Committee of Conference on the disagreeing amendments to the Tariff Bill. A resolution was adopted requesting the President to appoint a day for humiliation and prayer by the people of the United States. In the evening session the bill relating of the law of evidence in the District of Columbia was passed. The resolution requesting the President to revoke the order which caused the suppression of the Cincinnati Inquirer was brought up, and, after considerable discussion, was lost, by a vote of 8 yeas to 25 nays. The enrollment bill as received from the House was considered at length and finally passed, the principal amendment being the reduction of the sixty days grace for volunteering to forty days.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate yesterday, the resolution to inquire as to what progress has been made in the construction of gunboats contracted for in 1862, was adopted. abstract: The undersigned Colonels of regiments of the National Guard, having determined to celebrate the coming Anniversary of the Declaration of Independence by a parade and review, respectfully request all the regiments in the First Division to unite with them. The senior officer present will take command. The line will be formed on the Battery at 8 1/2 o'clock A.M. precisely. The review will take place by the Mayor and Common Council at the City Hall at 9 1/2 o'clock. The line of march will be up Broadway, Park-row, through the east gate of the Park, Broadway, Fourteenth-street, Fifth-avenue to Twenty-fourth-street, where the parade will be dismissed.
lead_paragraph: The undersigned Colonels of regiments of the National Guard, having determined to celebrate the coming Anniversary of the Declaration of Independence by a parade and review, respectfully request all the regiments in the First Division to unite with them. abstract: Rival Parties in England on Question of
snippet: Rival Parties in England on Question of
lead_paragraph: The latest news from Europe presents the question of a threatened party crisis in England, in a somewhat modified aspect. The Tories have failed to get their courage up to the sticking point in the matter of a vote of censure on the foreign policy of the Government. The trouble of the Opposition, and what makes them so feeble-kneed, is their utter want of sincerity in this matter of standing by Denmark in her unequal struggle for her territorial rights. But for the thorough distrust with which the Liberal friends of the assailed monarchy, in the House of Commons regard the professions of the Tory leaders, the life of the Palmerston Ministry would barely be worth a day's purchase. So long, however, as that distrust remains, there is no prospect of a combination strong enough to supplant the present Cabinet -- unless indeed (which is not improbable) it breaks up from internal dissensions. It was probably to these dissensions that the rumors current on 'Change, noticed in our last, more particularly referred.

abstract: -- The new enrollment, which is now completed, shows an increase of several thousand over the enrollment of last year. This is partially owing to the careful manner in which the different districts have been canvassed, but more particularly to the extraordinary increase of emigration within the past six months of young men, most of whom have declared their intentions, and have settled in the City. The increase of foreign laborers in our iron foundries is alone, within the period mentioned, over 11,000. A large number of these men are liable to draft, and others will join the army as substitutes. Our quota under the new enrollment, if the next call shall not exceed 300,000, will probably not be more than 20,000. That number can be easily raised in less than sixty days, if the present appearances can be relied upon as any indication of the future. There are now hundreds of men in the City who are willing and anxious to enlist, but are waiting for the City Hall Park Recruiting Office to open and pay the $300 County bounty.

abstract: There is very little war news of exciting interest this morning. Everything is reported quiet with Gen. GRANT's army before Petersburgh. A dispatch, dated Tuesday morning, says our left wing has swung around so as to take possession of the Welden Roilroad south of that city. This, it is said, was done without opposition. A report from the front intimates that enormous preparation are going on in our works about Petersburgh, from which the country will soon hear important results.
lead_paragraph: There is very little war news of exciting interest this morning. Everything is reported quiet with Gen. GRANT's army before Petersburgh.
