abstract: Several changes have been made at this institution, which very much improve the premises. A new building, 50 by 100 feet, has been erected on the west side, which is sufficient to accommodate any anticipated increase of applicants, and relieve the over-crowded rooms of the old house. The new structure will be two stories in height, the first story to be used as a play-room for the children during inclement weather, the second as a chapel and school-room. The school-room will be divided into a primary and secondary department, of four classes each. Most of the scholars now instructed in the school-rooms of the old building will be transferred to the new apartments. A new feature has been introduced by the Trustees of the Mission, the purpose of which is to provide for women who owing to habits of dissipation or indigence are unable to take care of themselves. Several such have recently been added to the "family." The families of soldiers, when suffering from want or neglect, are properly cared for, and for those who are able to work employment is found. The new structure stands immediately over Cow Bay -- so named from the fact that until 1776 a small stream of water, running through Centre-street, formed itself into a pond near Worth-street. Here the vagrant cows of the neighborhood quenched their thirst until the days when improvement drained the pool and filled it. The Five Points House of Industry, which is under the Superintendence of Mr. S.B. HALLIDAY, was never in a more flourishing condition than at present.

abstract: An important meeting of the Board of Commissinners of Health, Commissioners of Quarantine, Commissioners of Emigration, and the Senators from New-York, Kings and Richmond Counties, was held at the City Hall, yesterday, to provide some place at which to land and detain well passengers from infected vessels.
lead_paragraph: An important meeting of the Board of Commissinners of Health, Commissioners of Quarantine, Commissioners of Emigration, and the Senators from New-York, Kings and Richmond Counties, was held at the City Hall, yesterday, to provide some place at which to land and detain well passengers from infected vessels. A resolution was adopted for a conference with the United States government, with a view to securing a portion of Bedloe's Island or other place; in the event of this failing, the Quarantine Commissioners to procure barges or scows for the purposes of the required detention.

abstract: -- The Tract Missionary Society held a meeting on Tuesday evening in the Laight-street Baptist Church, Mr. WETMORE in the chair. The missionaries of the Eighth, Fourteenth, Seventeenth and Twentieth Wards, and the missionaries for seamen and Scandinavians made statements, showing, in a variety of particulars, the amount of good accomplished by personal effort. The pastor of the church expressed his great satisfaction in the work, and encouraged the laborers persevere. Among the statistics reported, we note the following: 88,436 tracts distributed; 208 Bibles and Testaments given; 413 gathered into Sabbath schools, day schools and Bible classes; 341 led to church, 331 meetings, and 66 persons brought under the care of pastors and churches.

abstract: Self-delusion at the, on Events of the War
snippet: Self-delusion at the, on Events of the War
lead_paragraph: There is hardly anything more remarkable in the whole history of the war than the lies upon which the people of the South have been fed, as to the results of military movements. It is not very often that we can get any accurate information of the extent of these falsehoods, for the interior of rebeldom is a dark place. But we have abundant evidence that the spirits of the people have been perpetually kept up by accounts of marvelous successes, wherever their forces and ours have come into collision. It is not long since a refugee from Texas mentioned this in our columns, the people where he had been having been repeatedly informed, in the most positive way, of the capture of Washington, the dispersal of the Army of the Potomac, the flight of the President, &c., &c.
headline: {'main': 'Self Delusion at the South.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Self Delusion at the South.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

Exempted persons of either sex may be represented in the army, by furnishing a substitute or paying the price of one, (which price, for the present, the Hancock Committee, of this City, fix at four hundred dollars.)

abstract: Repeal of the Commutation Clause
snippet: Repeal of the Commutation Clause
lead_paragraph: Not a solitary member of the Opposition in the House voted to repeal the commutation clause of the Enrollment Act. Yet after that bill was passed, eighteen months ago, it was that very clause which the same party especially used to arouse popular passion against the Government. Their orators on the platform, their newspapers and their street talk were full of fiery indignation at the tyranny which forced the poor man from his family into the ranks, while the rich man was let off by the payment of money. In vain it was urged that the law, by keeping down the price of substitutes, was really for the poor man's benefit -- that by commuting, and so remitting to the Government the business of finding substitutes, personal exemption was placed within the reach of tens of thousands who otherwise would have no alternative but to quit home and serve. The changes were still rung with the utmost fierceness upon the atrocious distinction of the Government against the poor. It was that one act, incessantly kept up, that did more than all things else to produce the New-York riots, with all their terrible scenes of fire and blood. And yet when an effort is made to put an end to the distinction, the representatives of the party plant themselves dead against it.
headline: {'main': 'The Repeal of the Commutation The Party of Indiscriminate Resistance.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Repeal of the Commutation The Party of Indiscriminate Resistance.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: At the solicitation of Capt. MARSHALL and Mr. BLUNT, the Government has ordered a steamer to be in readiness on Saturday, to take a cargo of vegetables to the Army of the Potomac. Notice of contributions may be given on or before Friday, to either of the gentlemen named, and the donations will be sent for on that day, so that they may be loaded and promptly dispatched in time to reach the army Sunday evening. Those who prefer to help the good cause along by contributing money, may send it to either of the gentlemen who have taken so prominent a part in this praiseworthy movement. Mr. BLUNT acknowledges the following as among the contributions received yesterday: Georgiana Blunt, $62; Jonathan Sturges, $50; Sherman & Wibirt, $25; Charles King, $25; Parker Handy, $25; E. & G.W. Blunt, $25; J.D. Lawson, $10; J. Bridge, $25; total, $247.

abstract: The attention of the Board of Health is called to the vast accumulations of garbage and night-soil on the sidewalks throughout the City. Much of it has lain for four or five days during one of the hottest terms of the season. The overpowering nature of the concentrated stinks which arise at nearly every grocery corner, even in the wide and airy avenues, gives ample warning of the pestilence that must be breeding all around us. In the narrow streets the smells are simply horrible, and it is altogether a matter of wonder that the spread of disease is not ten times more virulent than it is. The City Inspector, we are told, has no funds. Then the Board of Health must find him funds, or find some other means of remedying this evil, and o remedying it to-day. The powers of the board are ample -- illimitable, in fact, in any emergency which threatens an epidemic. The temporary relaxation in the heat of the weather presents an opportunity for removing the accumulations of dirt, without the same risk of spreading infectious disease as will be incurred by postponing the matter perhaps even for another day. Action, immediate action, is what is wanted.

abstract: The Twelfth Massachusetts Regiment, Col. BATES, will probably arrive in this City this evening. This regiment is familiarly known as the Hallelujah Regiment, the song of "Glory Hallelujah" having been dedicated to the late Col. FLETCHER WEBSTER, its original Commander. The Ninth New-York, formerly brigaded with the Twelfth Massachusetts, have tendered an escort to their old comrades upon their arrival here, through a letter from Col. CHALMERS to Col. HOWE, the Massachusetts State Agent, the courtesy of which has been accepted. The Twelfth numbers less than 200 men.

lead_paragraph: The one hundred and tenth Commencement of Columbia College took place yesterday morning, at the Academy of Music, which was crowded by a brilliant and fashionable audience. PresidentCHARLES KING presided. On the platform were the Faculty of the College, and a large number of distinguished gentlemen, among whom were Peter Cooper, Esq., Chancellor Isaac Ferris, President of the New-York University; Rev. Dr. Morgan Dix, Rev. Dr. Thrall, of California; Prof. Francis Lieber, Rev. Dr. McVickar, Rev. Dr. Haight, Rev. Mr. Farrington, Rev. Dr. Ve[???]milye and Rev. Dr. Canfield.
